sequence: An ion thruster, ion drive, or ion engine is a form of electric propulsion used for spacecraft propulsion. It creates thrust by accelerating ions using electricity.An ion thruster ionizes a neutral gas by extracting some electrons out of atoms, creating a cloud of positive ions. These ion thrusters rely mainly on electrostatics as ions are accelerated by the Coulomb force along an electric field. Temporarily stored electrons are finally reinjected by a neutralizer in the cloud of ions after it has passed through the electrostatic grid, so the gas becomes neutral again and can freely disperse in space without any further electrical interaction with the thruster.

Today's New International Version (TNIV) is an English translation of the Bible which was developed by the Committee on Bible Translation (CBT). The CBT also developed the New International Version (NIV) in the 1970s. The TNIV is based on the NIV. It is explicitly Protestant like its predecessor; the deuterocanonical books are not part of this translation. The TNIV New Testament was published in March 2002. The complete Bible was published in February 2005. The rights to the text are owned by Biblica (formerly International Bible Society). Zondervan published the TNIV in North America.

The Ante-Nicene Fathers, subtitled "The Writings of the Fathers Down to A.D. 325", is a collection of books in 10 volumes (one volume is indexes) containing English translations of the majority of Early Christian writings. The period covers the beginning of Christianity until the promulgation of the Nicene Creed at the First Council of Nicaea.PublicationThe series was originally published between 1867 and 1873 by the Presbyterian publishing house T. & T. Clark in Edinburgh under the title Ante-Nicene Christian Library (ANCL), as a response to the Oxford movement's Library of the Fathers which was perceived as too strongly identified with the Anglo-Catholic movement.

Shakespearean tragedy is the designation given to most tragedies written by playwright William Shakespeare. Many of his history plays share the qualifiers of a Shakespearean tragedy, but because they are based on real figures throughout the history of England, they were classified as "histories" in the First Folio. The Roman tragedies—Julius Caesar, Antony and Cleopatra and Coriolanus—are also based on historical figures, but because their sources were foreign and ancient they are almost always classified as tragedies rather than histories. Shakespeare's romances (tragicomic plays) were written late in his career and published originally as either tragedy or comedy.

Tajiks (, Tājīk, Tājek; ) are a Persian-speaking Iranian ethnic group native to Central Asia, living primarily in Afghanistan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. Tajiks are the largest ethnicity in Tajikistan, and the second-largest in Afghanistan and Uzbekistan. They speak varieties of Persian, a Western Iranian language. In Tajikistan, since the 1939 Soviet census, its small Pamiri and Yaghnobi ethnic groups are included as Tajiks. In China, the term is used to refer to its Pamiri ethnic groups, the Tajiks of Xinjiang, who speak the Eastern Iranian Pamiri languages.

Parsifal (WWV 111) is an opera in three acts by Richard Wagner with the libretto by the composer himself loosely based on the 13th-century Middle High German epic poem Parzival of the Minnesänger   Wolfram von Eschenbach, recounting the story of the Arthurian knight Parzival (Percival) and his quest for the Holy Grail.Wagner conceived the work in April 1857, but did not finish it until 25 years later. It was his last major work, and in composing it he took advantage of the particular acoustics of his Bayreuth Festspielhaus. Parsifal was first produced at the second Bayreuth Festival in 1882.

Year 1045 (MXLV) was a common year starting on Tuesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  January 20 – Pope Sylvester III becomes the 146th pope, succeeding Benedict IX, who abdicated during the previous year. January 23 – Edward the Confessor, King of England, marries Edith of Wessex, and begins construction of Westminster Abbey in England. February – Pope Sylvester III is deposed (election deemed invalid); Pope Benedict IX is elected once more, becoming the 147th pope. February 5 – Emperor Go-Reizei ascends the throne of Japan.

The Etruscan civilization  of ancient Italy covered a territory, at its greatest extent, of roughly what is now Tuscany, western Umbria, and northern Lazio, as well as what are now the Po Valley, Emilia-Romagna, south-eastern Lombardy, southern Veneto, and western Campania.The earliest evidence of a culture that is identifiably Etruscan dates from about 900BC. This is the period of the Iron Age Villanovan culture, considered to be the earliest phase of Etruscan civilization, which itself developed from the previous late Bronze Age Proto-Villanovan culture in the same region. Etruscan civilization endured until it was assimilated into Roman society.

Nitrous oxide , commonly known as laughing gas , nitrous , or nos , is a chemical compound , an oxidizer and a gas with high toxicity. It is an ingredient of the nitric oxide and is one of the most potent inhalants known. Nitrous oxide has been the subject of a variety of studies because it was believed to be a major cause of deaths in the 1940s when it was first introduced in the United States. It has since been used in combat settings for the purposes of nerve gas delivery. It was used extensively in the Vietnam War.

Heavy Metal: F.A.K.K. 2 is a third-person shooter video game made by Ritual Entertainment in 2000. The sequel to the Heavy Metal 2000 animated film, the game stars Julie in her quest to save her home planet of Eden from GITH, an ancient entity seeking to conquer the universe. Using a variety of weapons, Julie must fight off GITH's forces while at the same time uncovering a secret hidden deep within the planet.F.A.K.K. 2 allows players to pair up and use two weapons at the same time depending on the situation. Players can block enemy attacks and execute powerful combo moves to deal deadly blows to their enemies.

Arabidopsis (rockcress) is a genus in the family Brassicaceae. They are small flowering plants related to cabbage and mustard. This genus is of great interest since it contains thale cress (Arabidopsis thaliana), one of the model organisms used for studying plant biology and the first plant to have its entire genome sequenced. Changes in thale cress are easily observed, making it a very useful model.StatusCurrently, the genus Arabidopsis has nine species and a further eight subspecies recognised. This delimitation is quite recent and is based on morphological and molecular phylogenies by O'Kane and Al-Shehbaz and others.Their findings confirm the species formerly included in Arabidopsis made it polyphyletic.

Reptilia is Canada 's largest indoor reptile zoo , with of indoor exhibits featuring over 250 reptiles , amphibians and fish . We also have many reptiles and amphibians housed on the roof . Reptilia also houses many native wildlife that live in the wild and are not housed in an aquarium or indoor exhibit . Our zoo has over 50 different types of reptiles , amphibians and fish ranging in size from very small babies to big adults . Our zoo is designed with your comfort and safety in mind so our facilities are safe for all our guests .

The governor general of Canada  is the federal viceregal representative of the . The  is head of state of Canada and the 14 other Commonwealth realms, but  resides in  oldest and most populous realm, the United Kingdom. The , on the advice of  Canadian prime minister, appoints a governor general to carry on the Government of Canada in the 's name, performing most of her constitutional and ceremonial duties. The commission is for an indefinite period—known as serving at  Majesty's pleasure—though five years is the usual length of time. Since 1959, it has also been traditional to alternate between anglophone and francophone officeholders—although many recent governors general have been bilingual.

Genus ( plural genera ) is a taxonomic rank used in the biological classification of living and fossil organisms as a means of identifying them. The generic name is a Latin adjective, from the Greek word γάλλιος (genos), meaning "a whole". Genus is also a noun from the Greek verb γοίνικον (genos) "to generate, form, number" and the neuter plural is genitrōpōn, "generations". The word genus refers to all living species of a single taxonomic rank. This is similar to the word "family" and "order" used as nouns.

A sports governing body is a sports organization that has a regulatory or sanctioning function.Sports governing bodies come in various forms and have a variety of regulatory functions. Examples of this can include disciplinary action for rule infractions and deciding on rulechanges in the sport that they govern. Governing bodies have different scopes. They may cover a range of sport at an international level, such as the International Olympic Committee and the International Paralympic Committee, or only a single sport at a national level, such as the Rugby Football League. National bodies will largely have to be affiliated with international bodies for the same sport.

A frog is any member of a diverse and largely carnivorous group of short-bodied, tailless amphibians composing the order Anura (literally without tail in Ancient Greek). The oldest fossil "proto-frog" Triadobatrachus is known from the Early Triassic of Madagascar, but molecular clock dating suggests their split from other amphibians may extend further back to the Permian, 265 million years ago. Frogs are widely distributed, ranging from the tropics to subarctic regions, but the greatest concentration of species diversity is in tropical rainforest. Frogs account for around 88% of extant amphibian species.

The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) is an international financial institution founded in 1991. As a multilateral developmental investment bank, the EBRD uses investment as a tool to build market economies. Initially focused on the countries of the former Eastern Bloc it expanded to support development in more than 30 countries from Central Europe to Central Asia. Similar to other multilateral development banks, the EBRD has members from all over the world (North America, Africa, Asia and Australia, see below), with the biggest single shareholder being the United States, but only lends regionally in its countries of operations.

Year 1036 (MXXXVI) was a leap year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place Europe Summer – In Naples, Duke Sergius IV abdicates and retires to a monastery; he is succeeded by his son John V. A Zirid expeditionary force invades Sicily and takes Palermo from the Normans, but fails to fully reconquer the island. England  February 5 – Edward the Confessor's younger brother Alfred Aetheling is blinded and murdered, in an apparent attempt to seize the throne of England from Harold I. Africa  June 13 – Caliph al-Zahir li-i'zaz Din Allah dies after a 16-year reign.

Parasports are sports played by people with a disability , including physical and intellectual disabilities . Some parasports are forms of competitive sport or a hobby, while other forms of para sport have a formal sport status such as an Olympic sport, Paralympics event or a World Cup . Many parasport games are organised by disability sports clubs and groups , where the athletes compete in sports such as volleyball, archery, tennis, wheelchair rugby, cycling, wheelchair fencing and others , or compete in paratriathlon, where the athletes participate in one of a number of sports in which there are disabilities .

The BBC World Service is an international broadcaster owned and operated by the BBC, with funding from the British Government through the Foreign Secretary's office. It is the world's largest external broadcaster in terms of reception area, language selection and audience reach. It broadcasts radio news, speech and discussions in more than 40 languages to many parts of the world on analogue and digital shortwave platforms, internet streaming, podcasting, satellite, DAB, FM and MW relays. In 2015, the World Service reached an average of 210 million people a week (via TV, radio and online).

Adenine  (symbol A or Ade) is a nucleobase (a purine derivative). It is one of the four nucleobases in the nucleic acid of DNA that are represented by the letters G–C–A–T. The three others are guanine, cytosine and thymine. Its derivatives have a variety of roles in biochemistry including cellular respiration, in the form of both the energy-rich adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and the cofactors nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and Coenzyme A. It also has functions in protein synthesis and as a chemical component of DNA and RNA.

A seed is an embryonic plant enclosed in a protective outer covering. The formation of the seed is part of the process of reproduction in seed plants, the spermatophytes, including the gymnosperm and angiosperm plants.Seeds are the product of the ripened ovule, after fertilization by pollen and some growth within the mother plant. The embryo develops from the zygote, and the seed coat from the integuments of the ovule. Seeds have been an important development in the reproduction and success of gymnosperm and angiosperm plants, relative to more primitive plants such as ferns, mosses and liverworts, which do not have seeds and use water-dependent means to propagate themselves.

Dotdash Meredith ( formerly About.com ) is an American digital media company that publishes articles and videos about various subjects. The company is headquartered in New York City with offices in both San Francisco and London, UK. The company specializes in social media, web publishing and SEO. The company's mission is to deliver the best content about a topic to its subscribers via various formats including videos, audio, images, and web articles. History

Early history
Dotdash was founded in 1999 as Dotdash Media, Inc.  As Dotdash, Dotdash Media produced web- and mobile-publishing sites for local newspapers and magazines.

Hebron ( ; ) is a Palestinian city in the southern West Bank , south of Jerusalem . Nestled in the hills of Judea and Samaria, it is the administrative headquarters of Hebron. It is bordered to the north by Qalandiya and Nablus , to the west by Beit Jala, and to the south by Qalqilya and Hebron. The town is the third-biggest in the West Bank and the third-largest Palestinian city in the occupied territories. Its population of approximately 2,400,000 (2013 figures) makes it the fourth-largest city in Palestine, after Jerusalem, Jericho, and Ramallah.

Australian Signals Directorate ( ASD ; until 2013 : Defence Signals Directorate , DSD ) is the Australian government agency that regulates the security of information in Australian telecommunications systems. The agency's headquarters is located at the Department of Home Affairs. The agency regulates the collection, recording and processing of information from, and the provision of telecommunications services in, the Australian Defence Force (ADF), as well as some telecommunications services provided by telecommunications providers. The directorate is established by the National Information Infrastructure Act 1994 and its regulations are contained in the Telecommunications Act 2005.

The lungs are the primary organs of the respiratory system in humans and most animals including a few fish, and some snails. In mammals and most other vertebrates, two lungs are located near the backbone on either side of the heart. Their function in the respiratory system is to extract oxygen from the air and transfer it into the bloodstream, and to release carbon dioxide from the bloodstream into the atmosphere, in a process of gas exchange. Respiration is driven by different muscular systems in different species. Mammals, reptiles and birds use their different muscles to support and foster breathing.

Catalase is a common enzyme found in nearly all living organisms exposed to oxygen (such as bacteria, plants, and animals) which catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is a very important enzyme in protecting the cell from oxidative damage by reactive oxygen species (ROS). Catalase has one of the highest turnover numbers of all enzymes; one catalase molecule can convert millions of hydrogen peroxide molecules to water and oxygen each second.Catalase is a tetramer of four polypeptide chains, each over 500 amino acids long. It contains four iron-containing heme groups that allow the enzyme to react with hydrogen peroxide.

Shakespearean tragedy is the designation given to most tragedies written by playwright William Shakespeare . Many of his history plays are considered to be part of the canon of English literature, and, in fact, his play Hamlet (1600) is one of the most frequently performed in the United States. He is the only dramatist whose plays have survived in their entirety for more than a hundred years. He also wrote plays on other subjects, including Oedipus Tyrannus, The Tempest, The Winter's Tale, King Lear, Julius Caesar, and The Tempest.

The Maunder Minimum, also known as the "prolonged sunspot minimum", was a period around 1645 to 1715 during which sunspots became exceedingly rare. During a 28-year period (1672–1699) within the minimum, observations revealed fewer than 50 sunspots. This contrasts with the typical 40,000–50,000 sunspots seen in modern times over a similar timespan.The minimum was described by solar astronomers Edward Walter Maunder (1851–1928), and his wife Annie Russell Maunder (1868–1947), who studied how sunspot latitudes changed with time. Two papers were published in Edward Maunder's name in 1890 and 1894, and he cited earlier papers written by Gustav Spörer.

In celestial mechanics, escape velocity or escape speed is the minimum speed needed for a free, non-propelled object to escape from the gravitational influence of a primary body, thus reaching an infinite distance from it. It is typically stated as an ideal speed, ignoring atmospheric friction. Although the term "escape velocity" is common, it is more accurately described as a speed than a velocity because it is independent of direction; the escape speed increases with the mass of the primary body and decreases with the distance from the primary body.

Paul Leo Molitor ( born August 22 , 1956 ) , nicknamed `` Molly '' and `` The Ignitor '' is an American former wrestler, coach, trainer and commentator. He is better known as the creator and host of the popular wrestling television show ''WrestleReunion''. Molitor was also a trainer under the ring name " The Ignitor " until he was injured on the ring stage during a live event on April 6, 1998 at the Hollywood Athletic Club. It is widely believed he is responsible for injuring the entire cast of ''WrestleReunion'', as well as the entire production crew.

Flavius Odoacer ( ; – 493 AD ) , also spelled Odovacer or Odovacar , was a soldier and statesman during the Late Roman Empire. Odoacer is most known for his role as a soldier and leader of the Gallic War of the Visigoths and Lombards. In AD 562, he led the Visigothic armies that drove the Lombards out of Italy and took over Rome. Odoacer then ruled as a governor in the western part of the Roman Empire for about fifty years and was the most important military leader for the empire. Early life and family
Odoacer was born around AD 570 in Rome.

Toilet humour , or potty or scatological humour ( compare scatology ) , is a type of off-colour humour dealing primarily with the act of using the toilet. Many jokes have been written about the use of the toilet, such as "You can't get a decent night's sleep without using the toilet" or "I can't go to sleep without urinating". In recent years, there is an increase in potty humour and also a reduction in toilet humour in print. Examples of toilet humour include:

"I'll go toilet for a week to get all the poo."

His Dark Materials is a trilogy of fantasy novels by Philip Pullman consisting of Northern Lights ( 1995 ; published in paperback in 1996 by Houghton Mifflin), The Golden Compass ( 2002 ) and Voyage of the Damned ( 2013 ) The first novel in the trilogy, Northern Lights, is a retelling of the first part of William Shakespeare’s play, Love’s Labor’s Lost. The trilogy is based on a collection of essays by Christopher Hitchens called God is Not Great and the essays themselves were collected and published as God is Not Great, Vol 1 & 2.

Isotope separation is the process of concentrating specific isotopes of a chemical element by removing other isotopes . The use of ion sources such as electrospray sources, electron ion sources and the like can concentrate isotopes of elements that are radioactive and/or hazardous. Ion-molecule reaction mass spectrometry (IM-MS), for instance, is a process whereby an ion is used as a source of a chemical element to be determined, in particular an alkali metal or an alkali earth metal ion, by ionizing the ion, and in particular by introducing it to a high vacuum.

Year 1068 ( MLXVIII ) was a leap year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. It had an end date of Thursday, 20 October 984. The name MLXVIII means "Twenty-first March", alluding to the fact that it was in the 21st century (the century of Christ) and the 21st month of the Gregorian year. The denominationMLXVIII was used until 1997. For the years of this calendar, the suffix "-III" is added to year numbers in calendars prior to 1752, before this year's year began on 1 October.

The Collatz conjecture in mathematics asks whether repeating two simple arithmetic operations will eventually transform every positive integer into one. It  concerns sequences of integers in which each term is obtained from the previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous term plus 1. The conjecture is that these sequences always reach 1, no matter which positive integer is chosen to start the sequence.The conjecture is named after mathematician Lothar Collatz, who introduced the idea in 1937, two years after receiving his doctorate.

Avignon ( , ; ; or , ; ) is the prefecture of the Vaucluse department in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France. The city, a center for wine growing since the 13th century, has grown to an area the size of the city of Paris, as well as to a major tourist destination, attracting many tourists who come for its wine-themed attractions and restaurants. In particular, its wineries are world leaders in the production of quality red wines, including the famous Château La Tremblay, Château d'Apt and the Champagne region in France and Spain.

A wide area network ( WAN ) is a telecommunications network that extends over a large geographic area . Wide area networks ( WAN ) are commonly used to exchange large amounts of information, and are widely used to transfer information among a large number of computers or other processing devices. Examples of WANs include the local area networks ( LAN ) that are linked to the Internet, and the wide area networks that transfer information between computers. WANs are often connected by means of links such as cables or wireless links; however, WANs also can be connected directly to the Internet via an access router.

The MGM-31A Pershing was the missile used in the Pershing 1 and Pershing 1a field artillery missile systems . It was first manufactured in 1963. It was the most advanced field artillery missile in the 1970s. It was succeeded by the S-75, which was the successor to the  and  systems. The S-75 had a liquid-propellant propulsion system that was used to fire the missile, as well as an external tank to provide cooling. The S-75 was the first field-artillery missile that had an internal-combustion engine in the nose of the missile as well. The missile could be used in various roles, ranging from artillery to fighter interceptor.

Gregory of Nyssa , also known as Gregory Nyssen ( ; c. 335 – c. 395 ) , was bishop of Magdeburg from 380 to 395 . Gregory is considered a saint in the church of the Roman Catholic Church . His feast day is 16 August . In his life, Gregory is described as the disciple of the apostle of Jesus ( Matthew 28:18 ; Luke 20:29 ; John 20:22 ) . Since he is the only disciple of Jesus' apostles, Gregory is the only disciple of Jesus' apostles whose name is mentioned in the bible.

( ; `` The Master-Singers of Nuremberg '' ) , WWV 96 , is a music drama , or opera , or chamber opera , written in the style of an operetta by Johann Strauss II . Its plot derives from an 18th-century comic opera , produced by Ludwig van Beethoven . It was originally intended for a cast of six singers , but two of them died during the rehearsals and two others did not have enough time for rehearsals . So only three singers were allowed in the production and the orchestra was also reduced from ten pieces to nine , which reduced the production costs and allowed them to have more singers .

Seville ( ; , ) is the capital and largest city of the Spanish autonomous community of Andalusia and the second-most populous city in Andalusia. It is the historical center of the Spanish Empire, the largest of Andalusia's former provinces. With a population of 1.25 million inhabitants, Seville is Spain's largest metropolitan area, and the cultural, commercial and financial heart of Spanish-speaking Europe. It was declared a World Heritage Site in 1978 and is also a major commercial center for Spain. The city is one of Europe's major cultural centers, hosting the annual Spanish-language film festival Eurocine Andaluz, with a history dating back several centuries.

Hex is a two player abstract strategy board game in which players attempt to connect opposite sides of a hexagonal board. Hex was invented by mathematician and poet Piet Hein in 1942 and independently by John Nash in 1948.It is traditionally played on an 11×11 rhombus board, although 13×13 and 19×19 boards are also popular. Each player is assigned a pair of opposite sides of the board which they must try to connect by taking turns placing a stone of their color onto any empty space. Once placed, the stones are unable to be moved or removed.

Pope John XXII ( ; 1244 – 4 December 1334 ) , born Jacques Duèze ( or d'Euse ) , was a French prelate and bishop of Paris. He was Bishop of Paris from 26 February 1325 until 4 December 1334. He was the son of François I, duke of Champagne. He was succeeded in turn by Jean I, Archbishop of Paris (1331–1334). Life
Born around 1240 in the French duchy of Champagne, he was the youngest of seven children of the counts of Faucigny-les-Moulins. After studying theology at the Collège de Beauvais and in Bologna, he became Bishop of Tournai in 1268.

The Palmer Raids were a series of raids conducted in November 1919 and January 1920 by the United States Department of Justice against leaders of Communist and socialist organizations. The Palmer Raids began in November 1918, following the Russian Revolution of November 1917, by targeting leading figures in the American Communist Party, and in October 1919, by targeting the Social Democratic Party of America. The raids also targeted the Knights of Labor, the Workers Defense League (WDL), the American Liberty League, and the New York Labor Against the War.

Thetis ( ; ) , is a figure from Greek mythology with varying mythological roles . She mainly appears as a daughter of Poseidon and Hecate . Thetis is known from numerous myths in Greek literature , including the famous myth of Perseus and the Centaurs . Thetis has a daughter in Greek myth who is identified as the same name as the mythological Tisis or thetis . Thetis is a daughter of Poseidon who was married to Hecate of Actium. In Greek mythology, she was killed by Herakles, son of Poseidon . Her death is recorded in several Greek myths and a legend .

In mathematics and physics , Laplace 's equation is a second-order partial differential equation named after Pierre-Simon Laplace , who first presented it in 1803. This equation is an example of a linearization of the nonlinear Euler equation that has been studied extensively over the last few decades. It describes the motion of small rigid bodies such as spheres and other small spherical objects moving through the nonlinear flow of an ideal or viscous fluid. Laplace equation also plays a role in fluid mechanics, where it arises when describing the motion of a particle immersed in a liquid. These two domains of applications share a similar mathematical structure.

Central Park is an urban park in New York City located between the Upper West and Upper East Sides of Manhattan (USA). It is located within the Manhattan borough of New York and is the largest public park in the city, as well as the sixth largest open space park in North America. It has a surface area of . The park is owned and maintained by New York City, and is open to the public. In 2008, the park received the Environmental Protection Award in recognition of its environmental cleanliness and greenness.

The Martian Chronicles is a science fiction fix-up novel, published in 1950, by American writer Ray Bradbury that chronicles the exploration and settlement of Mars, the home of indigenous Martians, by Americans leaving a troubled Earth that is eventually devastated by nuclear war.SynopsisThe book projects American society immediately after World War II into a technologically advanced future where the amplification of humanity's potentials to create and destroy have both miraculous and devastating consequences.Events in the chronicle include the apocalyptic destruction of both Martian and human civilizations, both instigated by humans, though there are no stories with settings at the catastrophes.

A mass driver or electromagnetic catapult is a proposed method of non-rocket spacelaunch which would use a linear motor to accelerate and catapult payloads up to high speeds. Existing and contemplated mass drivers use coils of wire energized by electricity to make electromagnets, though a rotary mass driver has also been proposed. Sequential firing of a row of electromagnets accelerates the payload along a path. After leaving the path, the payload continues to move due to momentum.Although any device used to propel a ballistic payload is technically a mass driver, in this context a mass driver is essentially a coilgun that magnetically accelerates a package consisting of a magnetizable holder containing a payload.

In economics , inflation refers to a general progressive increase in prices of goods and services in an economy . The increase in the price of goods and services is usually due to increases in the production costs as well as costs of the distribution of goods and services. Inflation refers to price increases that are equal to, or greater than, the original price . In the current environment, most economists believe inflation is a major threat to the world economy and the financial stability of the United States and many other nations. Inflation is one of the main causes of economic downturns.

Twyla Tharp (; born July 1, 1941) is an American dancer, choreographer, and author who lives and works in New York City. In 1966 she formed the company Twyla Tharp Dance. Her work often uses classical music, jazz, and contemporary pop music.From 1971 to 1988, Twyla Tharp Dance toured extensively around the world, performing original works. In 1973 Tharp choreographed Deuce Coupe to the music of The Beach Boys for the Joffrey Ballet. Deuce Coupe is considered the first "crossover ballet", a mix of ballet and modern dance.

Kingston is the capital and largest city of Jamaica, located on the southeastern coast of the island. It faces a natural harbour protected by the Palisadoes, a long sand spit which connects the town of Port Royal and the Norman Manley International Airport to the rest of the island. In the Americas, Kingston is the largest predominantly English-speaking city south of the United States.The local government bodies of the parishes of Kingston and St. Andrew were amalgamated by the Kingston and St. Andrew Corporation Act of 1923, to form the Kingston and St. Andrew Corporation (KSAC).

"Wilhelmus van Nassouwe", usually known just as "Wilhelmus" (; ; English translation: "The William"), is the national anthem of both the Netherlands and the Kingdom of the Netherlands. It dates back to at least 1572, making it the oldest national anthem in use today, provided that the latter is defined as consisting of both a melody and lyrics. Although "Wilhelmus" was not recognized as the official national anthem until 1932, it has always been popular with parts of the Dutch population and resurfaced on several occasions in the course of Dutch history before gaining its present status.

The PDP-7 was a minicomputer produced by Digital Equipment Corporation as part of the PDP series. Introduced in 1964, shipped since 1965, it was the first to use their Flip-Chip technology. With a cost of , it was cheap but powerful by the standards of the time. The PDP-7 is the third of Digital's 18-bit machines, with essentially the same instruction set architecture as the PDP-4 and the PDP-9.HardwareThe PDP-7 was the first wire-wrapped PDP. The computer had a memory cycle time of  and an add time of . I/O included a keyboard, printer, paper-tape and dual transport DECtape drives (type 555).

The Soma cube is a solid dissection puzzle invented by Danish polymath Piet Hein in 1933 during a lecture on quantum mechanics conducted by Werner Heisenberg. Its name is alleged to be derived from the fictitious drug soma consumed as a pastime by the establishment in Aldous Huxley's dystopic novel Brave New World.Seven pieces made out of unit cubes must be assembled into a 3×3×3 cube. The pieces can also be used to make a variety of other 3D shapes.The pieces of the Soma cube consist of all possible combinations of three or four unit cubes, joined at their faces, such that at least one inside corner is formed.

Edward Teller (; January 15, 1908 – September 9, 2003) was a Hungarian-American theoretical physicist who is known colloquially as "the father of the hydrogen bomb" (see the Teller–Ulam design), although he did not care for the title, considering it to be in poor taste. Throughout his life, Teller was known both for his scientific ability and for his difficult interpersonal relations and volatile personality.Born in Hungary in 1908, Teller emigrated to the United States in the 1930s, one of the many so-called "Martians", a group of prominent Hungarian scientist émigrés.

A verb  is a word (part of speech) that in syntax conveys an action (bring, read, walk, run, learn), an occurrence (happen, become), or a state of being (be, exist, stand). In the usual description of English, the basic form, with or without the particle to, is the infinitive. In many languages, verbs are inflected (modified in form) to encode tense, aspect, mood, and voice. A verb may also agree with the person, gender or number of some of its arguments, such as its subject, or object.

Year 931 ( CMXXXI ) was a common year starting on Saturday ( link will display the full calendar ) in the Julian calendar. At the time, it was fixed by the Mutinies of Paris in September 1428 (or at some point during the preceding year), but starting with the Gregorian calendar Year 925 (CMXXXII) calendar year, a leap second was introduced in the Julian calendar that changed the date to an end of year date. This is one of the most important events in the history of England as it marked the end of the last of the five hundred years of continuous monarchy in the country.

Heliox is a breathing gas mixture of helium ( He ) and oxygen ( O2 ) .Heliox is a medical device designed to allow the exchange of helium and oxygen between tissues and the lungs, allowing for the treatment of diseases of the pulmonary and cardiac systems. Heliox is commonly used as a gas-filled balloon catheter for the treatment and diagnosis of congenital lung diseases such as bronchiectasis, pulmonary emphysema, and pulmonary edema. It is also used as a therapeutic agent and diagnostic agent. The Heliox is typically used for pulmonary applications, including the treatment of cystic fibrosis, pneumothorax, and lung collapse.

Don Carlos is a five-act grand opera composed by Giuseppe Verdi to a French-language libretto by Joseph Méry and Camille Pissarro. It was first performed at the Teatro del Liceu in 1853. The opera, in two parts, was produced at the opera house in Verdi's final years. The opera is a tale of love and betrayal set against the backdrop of the French Revolution, the Napoleonic Wars, and the 1848 Revolution. The opera received its world premiere in London in 1953 and its American premiere on November 15, 1966, at the New York State Theater in New York City and was a great success.

Peperomia ( radiator plant ) is one of the two large genera of the family Piperaceae . Most of them are found in eastern Asia, especially in India, Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand and China. The other genus is Picea . They are native to Asia and Europe. Peperomia species are used in Chinese medicine for their antiviral properties and antifungal properties. Geographic distribution 
There are three species of peperomia, P. australiensis from Australia and two from Indonesia. All are native to Asia. Uses

Antiviral and antibiotic

Antiviral effects of peperomia are mediated via the generation of superoxide radicals.

Turbo Pascal is a software development system that includes a compiler and an integrated development environment (IDE) for the Pascal programming language running on CP/M, CP/M-86, and DOS. It was originally developed by Anders Hejlsberg at Borland, and was notable for its extremely fast compiling times. Turbo Pascal, and the later but similar Turbo C, made Borland a leader in PC-based development.For versions 6 and 7 (last), both a lower-priced Turbo Pascal and more expensive Borland Pascal were produced; Borland Pascal was more oriented toward professional software development, with more libraries and standard library source code.

Humour ( Commonwealth English ) or humor ( American English ) is the tendency of experiences to provoke laughter and to make a person feel amused or amused. Humor includes many aspects of comic behavior. The term humor was coined by Edgar Allan Poe in his "Sketch Book". Humour can be expressed in two ways; the more common is "a bit of fun or amusement" with "an element of entertainment or diversion". Humor, like other types of humor, is considered to be a non-threatening and non-threatening to a person that does not feel offended.

A political prisoner is someone imprisoned for their political activity. The political offense is not always the official reason for the prisoner's detention.There is no internationally recognized legal definition of the concept, although numerous similar definitions have been proposed by various organizations and scholars, and there is a general consensus among scholars that "individuals have been sanctioned by legal systems and imprisoned by political regimes not for their violation of codified laws but for their thoughts and ideas that have fundamentally challenged existing power relations". The status of a political prisoner is generally awarded to individuals based on declarations of non-governmental organizations like Amnesty International, on a case-by-case basis.

A drummer is a percussionist who creates music using drums.Most contemporary western bands that play rock, pop, jazz, or R&B music include a drummer for purposes including timekeeping and embellishing the musical timbre. The drummer's equipment includes a drum kit (or "drum set" or "trap set"), which includes various drums, cymbals and an assortment of accessory hardware such as pedals, standing support mechanisms, and drum sticks.Particularly in the traditional music of many countries, drummers use individual drums of various sizes and designs rather than drum kits.

Hugh John Lofting ( 14 January 1886 – 26 September 1947 ) was an English author trained as a civil engineer. Lofting was born in Southport, Lancashire, the son of a coal merchant, and trained as a civil engineer. He began his writing career as a children's author in the early 1910s, penning historical romances for children. In the early 1930s he turned to novels for the adult market. He wrote mainly historical fiction, including the historical romance Man of War (1930), which was made into a Hollywood movie in 1935.

In commutative algebra, the prime spectrum (or simply the spectrum) of a ring R is the set of all prime ideals of R, and is usually denoted by ; in algebraic geometry it is simultaneously a topological space equipped with the sheaf of rings .Zariski topology For any ideal I of R, define  to be the set of prime ideals containing I. We can put a topology on  by defining the collection of closed sets to beThis topology is called the Zariski topology.A basis for the Zariski topology can be constructed as follows.

Antioch on the Orontes ( ; , Antiókheia hē epì Oróntou ; also Syrian Antioch ) was a Hellenistic city-state in southern Anatolia that rose from the ruins of Antioch of the Great in the 7th century, which fell to the Byzantines in the 8th century. It is also the name of a church at Antioch's center. The city was an important cultural center in the Mediterranean world and the Levant during the Byzantine and later Muslim eras. Antioch was eventually destroyed in the early 11th century by an Arab army, and rebuilt in 1236. The city played a major role in the early Byzantine Empire and the Crusader States.

Edward Higgins White II (November 14, 1930 – January 27, 1967) was an American aeronautical engineer, United States Air Force officer, test pilot, and NASA astronaut. He was a member of the crews of Gemini 4 and Apollo 1.After graduating from West Point in 1952 with a Bachelor of Science degree, White was sent to flight training, and assigned to the 22nd Fighter Day Squadron at Bitburg Air Base, West Germany, where he flew the F-86 Sabre and F-100 Super Sabre fighters. In 1958, he enrolled in the University of Michigan to study aeronautical engineering.

A finger is a limb of the body and a type of digit, an organ of manipulation and sensation found in the hands of most of the Tetrapods, so also with humans and other primates. Most land vertebrates have five fingers (Pentadactyly).Land vertebrate fingers The five-rayed anterior limbs of terrestrial vertebrates can be derived phylogenetically from the pectoral fins of fish. Within the taxa of the terrestrial vertebrates, the basic pentadactyl plan, and thus also the fingers and phalanges, undergoe many variations.Morphologically the different fingers of terrestrial vertebrates are homolog. The wings of birds and those of bats are not homologous, they are analogue flight organs.

Theories of political behavior, as an aspect of political science, attempt to quantify and explain the influences that define a person's political views, ideology, and levels of political participation. Political behavior is the subset of human behavior that involves politics and power. Theorists who have had an influence on this field include Karl Deutsch and Theodor Adorno.Long-term influences on political orientationInteraction with the political views of parental figures is often thought of as the primary long-term influence on political orientation and willingness to take part in the political system.Teachers and other educational authority figures are also often thought to have a significant impact on political orientation.

A museum ( ; plural museums or , rarely , musea ) is a building or institution that cares for or collects cultural heritage, or, in the case of museums of natural history and archaeology, for the objects they contain, and presents it for the public in a systematic way, in a series of exhibitions and other activities. A museum typically has a permanent exhibition of exhibits on display, as well as a permanent collection, often of objects in various states of preservation, and a collection of documents and artifacts that can be studied.

Triskaidekaphobia ( ,  ; ) is fear or avoidance of the number . It is also a reason for the fear of Friday the 13th, called paraskevidekatriaphobia  or friggatriskaidekaphobia .The term was used as early as in 1910 by Isador Coriat in Abnormal Psychology.OriginsNorse mythologyAccording to folklore historian Donald Dossey, the unlucky nature of the number "13" originated with a Norse myth about 12 gods having a dinner party in Valhalla. The trickster god Loki, who was not invited, arrived as the 13th guest, and arranged for Höðr to shoot Balder with a mistletoe-tipped arrow.

The PDP-7 was a minicomputer produced by Digital Equipment Corporation as part of the PDP series . Introduced in 1964, it is still popular with computer enthusiasts. It was one of the few models that could be upgraded, making it an expensive upgrade for an existing PDP-7 system. The first model was produced in early 1964 with the second appearing the following year. The PDP-7 series was originally developed for the Bell System's minicomputers based on the CP-70. However, the PDP-3 was an upgraded CP-70-derived model. Both the first and second models used an IBM PS/2 line.

George Michael Dolenz Jr. ( born March 8 , 1945 ) is an American actor , musician , TV producer and director, known as The Rock. He was born in Hollywood, California. In 1982, Dolenz was elected to the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences  and the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences in 1987. Early life 

Michael Dolenz Jr. was the son of the film director/producer Michael Dolenz and the singer and actor Marilyn Dolenz. He has three sisters and one brother. Michael was named after his father by his paternal grandmother.

The boa knot is a modern  binding knot invented by weaver Peter Collingwood in 1996. His intention was to develop a knot that would hold well when the constricted object was cut close to the winds of the knot.The boa knot is related to the strangle knot and the double constrictor knot. It combines both the structure and qualities of these other two knots. The boa knot can be very difficult to untie and is inappropriate when frequent or fast untying is needed. The knotted part needs to lie over a convex surface to hold.Start with making two loops that spiral upwards in a clockwise manner.

The National Academies of Sciences , Engineering , and Medicine ( also known as NASEM or the National Academies ) is the United States government agency with the primary responsibility for making policy recommendations on the use of scientific evidence and research. As a non-profit organization, it is authorized to conduct research, policy research, and analysis on a broad range of topics including the health, safety, and security of the United States, the use of science to prevent disease, mitigate the risks of hazards and disasters, and to promote and improve the health and safety of individuals, populations and the United States.

Year 1103 (MCIII) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Levant  Spring – Bohemond I, Norman prince of Antioch, is released from Seljuk imprisonment at Niksar, after a ransom is paid of 100,000 gold pieces. During his absence, Tancred (Bohemond's nephew) attacks the Byzantines, and re-captures the cities of Tarsus, Adana and Mamistra in Cilicia. Tancred is deprived of his lordship by Bohemond's return, and is rewarded with a small fief within the Principality of Antioch.

In philosophy , systems theory , science , and art , emergence occurs when an entity is observed to have an impact on the course of the system. In the following paper , I provide an overview of various types of emergent properties , and then propose the following question : Which properties can be considered as emergent by an organism? In the process , I highlight the notion of 'complexity' and propose a possible answer . This paper is mainly intended as a preliminary guide to a forthcoming research paper that I am currently editing with my colleagues.

Patch collecting or badge collecting (also, scutelliphily, from Latin scutellus meaning little shield, and Greek phileein meaning to love) is the hobby of collecting patches or badges.Souvenir patchesSouvenir patches are usually shield-shaped and generally contain a coat of arms, a map or a miniature view. The patches can be made of any material, but are usually woven or embroidered fabric, though they can also be made from paper or, increasingly, plastic.Other types of collectible patches include police or service patches, space mission patches, Scout patches, fashion patches, political and sports stickers, walking stick labels, car window pennants, and pin badges.

A brain tumor occurs when abnormal cells form within the brain. There are two main types of tumors: malignant tumors and benign (non-cancerous) tumors. These can be further classified as primary tumors, which start within the brain, and secondary tumors, which most commonly have spread from tumors located outside the brain, known as brain metastasis tumors. All types of brain tumors may produce symptoms that vary depending on the size of the tumor and the part of the brain that is involved. Where symptoms exist, they may include headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting and mental changes.

A terrarium (plural: terraria or terrariums) is usually a sealable glass container containing soil and plants, and can be opened for maintenance to access the plants inside. However, terraria can also be open to the atmosphere rather than being sealed. Terraria are often kept as decorative or ornamental items. Closed terraria create a unique environment for plant growth, as the transparent walls allow for both heat and light to enter the terrarium. The sealed container combined with the heat entering the terrarium allows for the creation of a small scale water cycle.

The Battle of Lechfeld was a series of military engagements over the course of three days from 10–12 August 955, during the Third Crusade. Lechfeld has been described as one of the most dramatic events in the early history of Germany. It is thought by many scholars that the battle was the culmination of a much larger struggle between the German Frankish kingdoms of Bavaria and Brandenburg, as well as the Teutonic kingdoms. The battle took place in the countryside of western Upper Palatinate, and the Frankish troops under King Pepin's son Charlemagne were decisively defeated by the Imperial Frankish troops under the command of Emperor Otto III.

Show jumping , is a part of a group of English riding equestrian events that also includes dressage , eventing and rally jumping , as well as eventing . It is one of the oldest forms of competitive equestrian sport in Europe , and also one of the more prestigious . It was also one of the founding disciplines of the modern Olympic Games , first held at the modern Olympic Games , in London . History

The first event was first held in 1690 , at the end of a competition called the Grand Prix de Paris . It is unclear how the name jumping came into use .

The covalent radius , rcov , is a measure of the size of an atom that forms part of one or more bonds. The size of a molecule is usually given in atomic radii units (a.u), which are a set of numbers that are defined as the distances within the molecule that must exist before and after the formation of any other bond. The covalent radius gives the minimum radius a bond will need to exist. For example a 1.4 carbon atom is considered covalent if and only if it contains at least three carbon atoms within a distance of rcov.

In the Ancient Greek religion, Hestia (; , "hearth" or "fireside") is the virgin goddess of the hearth, the right ordering of domesticity, the family, the home, and the state. In Greek mythology, she is the firstborn child of the Titans Cronus and Rhea.Customarily, in Greek culture, Hestia received the first offering at every sacrifice in the household. In the public domain, the hearth of the prytaneum functioned as her official sanctuary, and, when a new colony was established, a flame from Hestia's public hearth in the mother city would be carried to the new settlement.

The striatum , or corpus striatum ( also called the striate nucleus ) , is a nucleus ( a cluster of cells) whose function is the production of a wide variety of hormones including the neurohormones orexins and hypocretins, and which has been proposed as part of the human reward circuit in both animal studies and human studies . It plays a central role in the reward-processing circuitry of the brain and is critical to the motivation for, and acquisition of, drugs and other rewards . The striatum receives input from several brain areas including the cortex and hippocampus.

Purple is any of a variety of colors with hue between red and blue . In the RGB color model, purple can be represented using a hue and intensity between green and red . In RGB , hue is represented as a number from 0 to 180. For example, a hue of 0 represents a greenish blue color and 180 represents a purple color with hue . There is a third color which is called “deep purple” . This color is blue with a deep hue and a deep value. In deep purple , a hue of 0 represents a blue color.

Alain Marie Pascal Prost ( born 24 February 1955 ) is a French retired racing driver . A four-time Formula One World Drivers' Champion, Prost began his career in Formula One in 1977, and raced in the 1976, 1978 and 1980 World Constructors' Championships. His Formula One career was blighted by an injury sustained during testing, which ruled him out of most of the 1977 season. Following this, Prost moved into the World Super Sports car series, and finished his career with a third-place finish in the 1981 Indianapolis 500, and a second place in the 1981 North American 500.

A knight 's tour is a sequence of moves of a knight on a chessboard such that the knight visits each of the squares in the order in which the knight was placed there before. The knight starts with the knight in white, moves one step forward on each turn until it is at a check or a white queen is in check. Each move the knight makes is followed by the queen's move and the knight's move. When there is no opponent on the board, a check is drawn. A check is drawn in two situations.

Alkanna tinctoria , the dyer 's alkanet or simply alkanet , is a herb in the borage family . Its common name comes from the Hindi word 'kanni' , meaning 'white' and it is found in the eastern half of India as well as in Nepal and Pakistan. The borage is an herbaceous perennial that produces white flowers which vary in colour from a deep blue-green to light yellow. The flowers are borne singly or in small clusters that are often arranged in the form of spikes. The plant flowers in spring. Alkanet is also grown as an ornamental plant and for landscaping use in borders and borders and hedgerows.

The boa knot is a modern binding knot invented by weaver Peter Collingwood in 1996 . His intention was to create an easy and convenient knot for those new to weaving . It has since grown in use by people who find that the knot is an excellent method of attaching threads together . In 2004, a company in the USA was formed to manufacture and market the boa knots. In 2012, the company launched a line of Boa Knots exclusively for Amazon. It was originally intended as a reference point, but has now expanded to cover a large range of fabrics.

Twyla Tharp ( ; born July 1 , 1941 ) is an American dancer , choreographer , and author who is one of only two women choreographed for the film and television industry. Contents

Wyla was born on July 1, 1941. She grew up in California and graduated from UC San Diego, with a Bachelor of Science in Physical Education in 1964. After a year at UCLA she received her Master of Arts degree in dance and theatre from the University of Pennsylvania. [1]

In 1965, she went to Los Angeles to teach dance.

Bristol is a city , ceremonial county and unitary authority in England . Situated on the River Avon , it was created on 1 January 1894, as a county borough. The first council was elected in April 1897, with two wards elected to the council. The first election of members was held on 1 April 1898. The next council was elected in 1900, in which council seats were taken from the borough of Bristol . The next election was held on 2 April 1902. Until the 1960s, Bristol was administered by Bristol Town Council, one of three local government authorities in West Country, along with Cheddar and Dorset.

A mass driver or electromagnetic catapult is a proposed method of non-rocket spacelaunch which would use a linear motor to accelerate a rocket payload, instead of using a conventional rocket as a launch vehicle. A mass driver is a proposed alternative launch system in which an accelerometer is used to generate an electrical pulse when the mass of a rocket is at a certain position, with the pulse then being used by a linear motor in a closed loop configuration to accelerate a payload to an arbitrary position. This would be an entirely new concept, however, it has a number of disadvantages.

Gregory Benford ( born January 30 , 1941 ) is an American science fiction author and astrophysicist who is Professor Emeritus at Stanford University. Benford has written over thirty books, over a hundred short stories and has also contributed to a large number of anthologies and academic journals. He is known for his work on interstellar travel and the history and future of humanity. Biography 
Benford was born to an Italian-Jewish family in Los Angeles. He grew up in Long Beach, CA, where he studied and began his career as an astrophysicist at UCLA, then Stanford, and finally at Harvard, where he taught until retiring in 2002.

Year 959 (CMLIX) was a common year starting on Saturday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  April - May – The Byzantines refuse to pay the yearly tribute. A Hungarian army, led by Apor, invades Macedonia and Thrace. He plunders its territories until reaching Constantinople. On his way back, Apor is defeated during a night attack by Byzantine forces. November 9 – Emperor Constantine VII Porphyrogennetos ("born in the purple") dies at Constantinople after a 46-year reign. He is succeeded by his 21-year-old son Romanos II as ruler of the Byzantine Empire.

George Catlett Marshall Jr.  (December 31, 1880 – October 16, 1959) was an American army officer and statesman. He rose through the United States Army to become Chief of Staff under Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, then served as Secretary of State and Secretary of Defense under Truman. Winston Churchill lauded Marshall as the "organizer of victory" for his leadership of the Allied victory in World War II. After the war, he spent a frustrating year trying and failing to avoid the impending civil war in China.

Indonesian  is the official language of Indonesia. It is a standardized variety of Malay, an Austronesian language that has been used as a lingua franca in the multilingual Indonesian archipelago for centuries. Indonesia is the fourth most populous nation in the world, with over 270 million inhabitants—of which the majority speak Indonesian, which makes it one of the more widely spoken languages in the world.Most Indonesians, aside from speaking the national language, are fluent in at least one of the more than 700 indigenous local languages; examples include Javanese and Sundanese, which are commonly used at home and within the local community.

Barbecue or barbeque (informally BBQ in the UK and US, barbie in Australia and braai in South Africa) is a term used with significant regional and national variations to describe various cooking methods which use live fire and smoke to cook the food. The term is also generally applied to the devices associated with those methods, the broader cuisines that these methods produce, and the meals or gatherings at which this style of food is cooked and served. The cooking methods associated with barbecuing vary significantly but most involve outdoor cooking.The various regional variations of barbecue can be broadly categorized into those methods which use direct and those which use indirect heating.

Numismatics is the study or collection of currency , including coins , tokens , paper money , medals and related items. Currency is a commodity used as medium of exchange between buyers and sellers. It is also used as a form of legal tender. It was originally created by merchants who wanted to make their goods and services more convenient for their customers. Then, it was created for use by the merchants who wanted to protect their goods and services from theft and fraud. Then, it was used in commerce. Now it is used as a tool for the government and the public.

In mathematics, the Dirac delta distribution ( distribution), also known as the unit impulse symbol, is a generalized function or distribution over the real numbers, whose value is zero everywhere except at zero, and whose integral over the entire real line is equal to one.The current understanding of the impulse is as a linear functional that maps every continuous function to its value at zero, or as the weak limit of a sequence of bump functions, which are zero over most of the real line, with a tall spike at the origin.

The Barber of Seville , or The Useless Precaution is an opera buffa in two acts by Gioachino Rossini with a libretto by Francesco Geminiani. The first performance was given on 17 May 1791 at La Scala in Milan. The opera was later performed as The Barber of Seville in London in 1792, in 1794 in Paris, in 1796 in New York and in 1801 in New York City and Washington D.C. This opera is a satirical satire on the pomp and opulence of fashionable Paris. Gioachino Rossini's The Barber of Seville is regarded as his magnum opus and was one of the most successful of his operas.

The fisherman 's knot is a bend ( a knot for joining two lines ) with a symmetrical structure consisting of three parts, the three legs being called arms. The fisherman 's knot is a bend which is used as a safety device to help in keeping the line secure in the water. When one of the knots in a pair is broken, the two knots will not come to be connected to each other. For example, this knot can be used to secure the fishing line. The first knot was invented by Jean-Jacques, the father of mathematician Jean-Bernard Saunier.

The subset sum problem ( SSP ) is a decision problem in computer science . In its most general formulation, the SSP is stated as follows: For any given positive integer n , find a subset of at most n elements such that the sum of the numbers in the subset is least. The SSP is an important class of problems in mathematics and computer science , and it was first considered by D. W. Hamlyn in 1951 . In the special case where n = 1 , it is the minimum sum-of-three set problem , which is also known as the clique problem .

Michael I ( ; 25 October 1921 – 5 December 2017 ) was the last King of Romania , reigning from 1990 to 2017. He and his family ruled as a non-voting hereditary princely family. The most recent in the line, his grandfather, was King Carol I of Romania (). The son of King Carol II and Queen Therese, and the grandson of Carol I, born on 25 October 1921, he was raised in his grandfather's reign. He was the second-eldest child in the line of the Romanian succession, after his grandfather, Carol II, and the first to be called the king.

In the English language, the word nigger is an ethnic slur typically used against black people, especially African Americans. Because it is considered extremely offensive, even if only mentioned and not used as a slur, it is often referred to by the euphemism . It is also in use with a more neutral meaning among African Americans, primarily as nigga. The word originated in the 18th century as an adaptation of the Spanish word negro, a descendant of the Latin adjective niger, which means "black". Over time it took on a derogatory connotation and became a racist insult by the 20th century.

The San Diego Zoo Safari Park, originally named the San Diego Wild Animal Park until 2010, is an 1,800 acre (730 ha) zoo in the San Pasqual Valley area of San Diego, California, near Escondido. It is one of the largest tourist attractions in San Diego County. The park houses a large array of wild and endangered animals including species from the continents of Africa, Asia, Europe, North and South America, and Australia. The park is in a semi-arid environment, and one of its most notable features is the Africa Tram, which explores the expansive African exhibits.

The Hippocratic Oath is an oath of ethics historically taken by physicians. It is one of the most widely known of Greek medical texts. In its original form, it requires a new physician to swear, by a number of healing gods, to uphold specific ethical standards. The oath is the earliest expression of medical ethics in the Western world, establishing several principles of medical ethics which remain of paramount significance today. These include the principles of medical confidentiality and non-maleficence. As the seminal articulation of certain principles that continue to guide and inform medical practice, the ancient text is of more than historic and symbolic value.

The Etruscan civilization of ancient Italy covered a territory , at its greatest extent , of roughly what is now central Italy and the Italian provinces of Campania, Apulia and Calabria. The Etruscan civilization of ancient Italy . The Etruscan civilization of ancient Italy is an archaeological culture that flourished from the 6th century B.C. to the 2nd century B.C. and, after the collapse of the Roman Empire, was known principally to the Greeks and Romans of the Mediterranean area. It was centered on three cities on the south-western coast of Tuscany , and it was the largest and most highly developed society of its period.

Fighting Fantasy is a series of single-player role-playing gamebooks created by Steve Jackson and Ian Livingstone . The first volume, published in 1981, has won the "Fantasy Excellence Award of Excellence" from D&D magazine, as well as being named one of the "10 Most Important RPGs of All Time" by Wizards Magazine. It has also been called "the most innovative role-playing game of the eighties." The books have also been called the most "important RPG of all time." Fantasy is a series of book-based video gamebooks in the tradition of The Lord of the Rings and Star Wars .

was the 68th emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession.Go-Ichijō's reign spanned the years from 1016 through 1036.This 11th century sovereign was named after Emperor Ichijō and go- (後), translates literally as "later;" and thus, he is sometimes called the "Later Emperor Ichijō", or, in some older sources, may be identified as " Emperor Ichijō, the second. "BiographyBefore his ascension to the Chrysanthemum Throne, his personal name (imina) was Atsuhira -shinnō (敦成親王). He was also known as Atsunari-shinnō.Atsuhira was the second son of Emperor Ichijō.

Sir Robert Alexander Watson Watt ( 13 April 1892 – 5 December 1973 ) was a British pioneer of radio and the founder of the Society for International Radio Propagation (SIRC). In addition he was a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering. He was a Director of Radio Corporation of Great Britain Limited (RCA). Watt’s research on radio wave propagation started in the mid-1920s with a PhD thesis in the early 1930s. He published more than 150 articles in scientific journals during the next three decades and founded the Society for International Radio Propagation (SIRC) in 1944.

The Bell OH-58 Kiowa is a family of single-engine, single-rotor, military helicopters used for observation, utility, and direct fire support. Bell Helicopter manufactured the OH-58 for the United States Army based on its Model 206A JetRanger helicopter. The OH-58 was in continuous U.S. Army service from 1969 to 2017, when it was replaced in these roles by the Boeing AH-64 Apache and Eurocopter UH-72 Lakota.The latest model, the OH-58D Kiowa Warrior, is primarily operated in an armed reconnaissance role in support of ground troops. The OH-58 has been exported to Austria, Canada, Croatia, the Dominican Republic, Taiwan, Saudi Arabia, and Greece.

Lieutenant General Henry Shrapnel (3 June 1761 – 13 March 1842) was a British Army officer whose name has entered the English language as the inventor of the shrapnel shell.Henry Shrapnel was born at Midway Manor in Bradford-on-Avon, Wiltshire, England, the ninth child of Zachariah Shrapnel and his wife Lydia.In 1784, while a lieutenant in the Royal Artillery, he perfected, with his own resources, an invention of what he called "spherical case" ammunition: a hollow cannonball filled with lead shot that burst in mid-air. He successfully demonstrated this in 1787 at Gibraltar.

Yorkshire pudding is a baked pudding made from a batter of eggs , flour , and milk or water . It is a rich, creamy, custardy, and generally heavy pudding . It usually consists of about half wheat and half rye flour. It is made in a variety of forms, and although Yorkshire puddings are generally made by hand they can be bought ready made and can be served on the table, in slices, on a platter, or in a small individual bowl. History

The first recorded recipe for Yorkshire pudding dates from the 11th century, and it was known as Yorkshire pudding in the 14th century.

Linus Carl Pauling (; February 28, 1901 – August 19, 1994) was an American chemist, biochemist, chemical engineer,  peace activist, author, and educator. He published more than 1,200 papers and books, of which about 850 dealt with scientific topics. New Scientist called him one of the 20 greatest scientists of all time, and as of 2000, he was rated the 16th most important scientist in history. For his scientific work, Pauling was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1954. For his peace activism, he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1962.

In electronics, a multiplexer (or mux; spelled sometimes as multiplexor), also known as a data selector, is a device that selects between several analog or digital input signals and forwards the selected input to a single output line. The selection is directed by a separate set of digital inputs known as select lines. A multiplexer of  inputs has  select lines, which are used to select which input line to send to the output.A multiplexer makes it possible for several input signals to share one device or resource, for example, one analog-to-digital converter or one communications transmission medium, instead of having one device per input signal.

Henry Richard Enfield ( born 30 May 1961 ) is an English comedian , actor , writer , and director, best known as the character "Richard" in the sitcom The Office. Richard is the pen name of English writer and presenter, and former stand-up comedy writer, Ian Dearnaley. Richard is an avid collector of baseball cards and memorabilia. Contents show]

Background

In the late 1980s, after having appeared in two sitcoms and one drama television series, Richard became a television personality, having appeared in television advertisements and in a number of comedy films as Richard Enfield ("The Office").

Igor Fyodorovich Stravinsky  (6 April 1971) was a Russian composer, pianist and conductor, later of French (from 1934) and American (from 1945) citizenship. He is widely considered one of the most important and influential composers of the 20th century and a pivotal figure in modernist music.Stravinsky's compositional career was notable for its stylistic diversity. He first achieved international fame with three ballets commissioned by the impresario Sergei Diaghilev and first performed in Paris by Diaghilev's Ballets Russes: The Firebird (1910), Petrushka (1911), and The Rite of Spring (1913).

Wheat is a grass widely cultivated for its seed, a cereal grain which is a worldwide staple food. The many species of wheat together make up the genus Triticum; the most widely grown is common wheat (T. aestivum). The archaeological record suggests that wheat was first cultivated in the regions of the Fertile Crescent around 9600 BCE. Botanically, the wheat kernel is a type of fruit called a caryopsis.Wheat is grown on more land area than any other food crop (, 2014). World trade in wheat is greater than for all other crops combined.

The bowline ( or ) is an ancient and simple knot used to form a fixed loop at the end of a rope. It has the virtues of being both easy to tie and untie; most notably, it is easy to untie after being subjected to a load. The bowline is sometimes referred to as King of the knots because of its importance. Along with the sheet bend and the clove hitch, the bowline is often considered one of the most essential knots. The common bowline shares some structural similarity with the sheet bend. Virtually all end-to-end joining knots (i.e., bends) have a corresponding loop knot.

A solvent ( from the Latin solvō , `` loosen , untie , solve '' ) is a substance that dissolves or solvates one or more materials in a liquid or solid phase. The word also has many other senses: it means "to soften or dissolve ", "to moisten", or "to disperse or mix in a substance", as in the following statements: "It's easy for you to put it in, to mix it with the flour". Also, solvents can be classified according to whether they contain water or organic compounds: e.g., "the water-based solvents are more effective".

Willow Rosenberg is a fictional character created for the fantasy television series Buffy the Vampire Slayer (1997–2003). She was developed by Joss Whedon and portrayed throughout the TV series by Alyson Hannigan.Willow plays an integral role within the inner circle of friends—called the Scooby Gang—who support Buffy Summers (Sarah Michelle Gellar), a teenager gifted with superhuman powers to defeat vampires, demons, and other evil in the fictional town of Sunnydale. The series begins as Buffy, Willow, and their friend Xander (Nicholas Brendon) are in 10th grade and Willow is a shy, nerdy girl with little confidence.

A supercomputer is a computer with a high level of performance as compared to a general-purpose computer . The performance of this supercomputer is increased by increasing the memory capacity, and by using high-performance processor. In the supercomputer having a memory, the memory is composed of one or a plurality of banks, and each bank has a memory. The one bank means a bank with only memory, for example. The other banks, which are the banks with memory and the bank having the memory, are connected with the bank with memory. The memory in a bank with only memory is called cache memory.

The lion ( Panthera leo ) is a large cat of the genus Panthera native to Africa and India . This large cat was formerly regarded as one of the largest cats. A member of the family Pantheridae, they are related to the cats of the family Felidae. Description

Adult males reach an average body mass of over . Adult females average about half that of the males. Adult male Panthera leo measure  in tail length. Adult male Panthera fuscata are slightly larger than the adult male Panthera pardus, with a tail length of , while that of the female is only .

Columbina ( in Italian Colombina , meaning `` little dove '' ; in French and English Colombine ) is a city, comune and the capital city of the region of Friuli Venezia Giulia, located in the region of Veneto, Italy. The city counts among it's main attractions the ancient Roman town of Città della Piana and the old town of Siena. It is situated at a short distance from Venice on the banks of the Adige river and has been a cultural centre for centuries. It has been called "The Pearl of the Friuli" for it has one of the most picturesque scenery of the region.

In the Ancient Greek religion , Hestia ( ; , `` hearth '' or `` fireside '' ) is the home of the goddess Hestia , the Earth mother, the goddess of agriculture , the goddess of the hearth, and the patroness of farmers . Hestia, with her sacred hearth , is depicted as a burning fire surrounded by green plants and trees . The hearth was believed to be of a special nature and had the powers to make fire, to heal, to impart wisdom . In ancient times Hestia , with her burning fire , was used in sacrifices to the Gods .

Year 1068 (MLXVIII) was a leap year starting on Tuesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  January 1 – Empress Eudokia Makrembolitissa, wife of the late Emperor Constantine X, marries General Romanos Diogenes (a member of a prominent Cappadocian family) – who is proclaimed co-emperor as Romanos IV of the Byzantine Empire. Autumn – Romanos IV begins a campaign against the Seljuk Turks, leading a Byzantine expeditionary force (which is in poor condition). He is successful in recapturing the fortress city of Hieropolis (modern-day Manbij) near Aleppo in northern Syria.

Crocodiles (family Crocodylidae) or true crocodiles are large semiaquatic reptiles that live throughout the tropics in Africa, Asia, the Americas and Australia. The term crocodile is sometimes used even more loosely to include all extant members of the order Crocodilia, which includes the alligators and caimans (family Alligatoridae), the gharial and false gharial (family Gavialidae) among other extinct taxa.Although they appear similar, crocodiles, alligators and the gharial belong to separate biological families. The gharial, with its narrow snout, is easier to distinguish, while morphological differences are more difficult to spot in crocodiles and alligators.

Gerard Adams (; born 6 October 1948) is an Irish republican politician who was the president of Sinn Féin between 13 November 1983 and 10 February 2018, and served as a Teachta Dála (TD) for Louth from 2011 to 2020. From 1983 to 1992 and from 1997 to 2011, he followed the policy of abstentionism as a Member of Parliament (MP) of the British Parliament for the Belfast West constituency.In 1984, Adams was seriously wounded in an assassination attempt by several gunmen from the Ulster Defence Association (UDA), including John Gregg.

Nuclear engineering is the branch of engineering concerned with the application of breaking down  atomic nuclei (fission) or of combining atomic nuclei (fusion),  or with the application of other sub-atomic processes based on the principles of nuclear physics. In the sub-field of nuclear fission, it particularly includes the design, interaction, and maintenance of systems and components like reactors, power plants, or weaponry. The field also includes the study of medical and other applications of radiation, particularly Ionizing radiation, nuclear safety, heat/thermodynamics transport, nuclear fuel, or other related technology (e.g., radioactive waste disposal) and the problems of nuclear proliferation.

Thermonuclear fusion is the process of atoms combining or “fusing” together with huge amounts of heat.
