Year 984 (CMLXXXIV) was a leap year starting on Tuesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  Spring – German boy-king Otto III (4-years old) is seized by the deposed Henry II (the Wrangler), duke of Bavaria, who has recovered his duchy and claims the regency as a member of the Ottonian Dynasty. But Henry is forced to hand over Otto to his mother, empress consort Theophanu. King Ramiro III loses his throne to Bermudo II (the rival king of Galicia), who also becomes ruler of the entire Kingdom of León (modern-day Spain).

Mary Anning ( 21 May 1799 – 9 March 1847 ) was an English fossil collector , dealer , and philanthropist. Biography
Mary Anning was born at Bishopsgate, London, the second daughter of Charles Anning, by his second marriage. She attended Westminster School (1798), then matriculated at Trinity College in Oxford (1807), where she graduated in 1811 and then became a fellow of Trinity, receiving the degree of BCL on 10 July 1815. She was then employed by Sir John Lothian, who offered her the post of librarian, a post she held for twenty years.

A melody (from Greek μελῳδία, melōidía, "singing, chanting"), also tune, voice or line, is a linear succession of musical tones that the listener perceives as a single entity. In its most literal sense, a melody is a combination of pitch and rhythm, while more figuratively, the term can include other musical elements such as tonal color. It is the foreground to the background accompaniment. A line or part need not be a foreground melody.Melodies often consist of one or more musical phrases or motifs, and are usually repeated throughout a composition in various forms.

In the philosophy of mathematics , the abstraction of actual infinity involves the acceptance ( if the axiom of infinity can be formalized in axiomatic set theory , as it is in [3] or [7]) of the Axioms A1, A3, and A8. In this paper we will look at the implications of these axioms for the notion of "infinitesimals" and "infinites." We will investigate what the consequences of our acceptance of these axioms are. The main motivation behind our investigation is the question whether there are any other "infinitesimals" besides the infinitesimals that exist as actual entities.

An infection is the invasion of an organism 's body tissues by disease-causing agents , their multiplication , and the development of tissue damage and complications resulting from the damage caused. A variety of infectious conditions can be caused either naturally or by the intentional introduction of pathogenic microorganisms into a patient . Such conditions can be divided into two categories, non-bacterial infections , which include viral and bacterial infection , and bacterial infections , which may include an infection due to a bacterium such as, for example, streptomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and antibiotic-associated colitis . Of the two categories, the former is of greater importance .

William Harrison Riker (September 22, 1920 – June 26, 1993) was an American political scientist who is prominent for applying game theory and mathematics to political science. He helped to establish University of Rochester as a center of behavioral revolution in political science.Early lifeWilliam Harrison Riker was born on September 22, 1920, in Des Moines, Iowa. He had 4 children, 2 sons and 2 daughters with wife Mary Elizabeth. He earned his bachelor's degree in economics at Indiana's DePauw University in 1942 and received his Ph.D at Harvard University in 1948.

Theodoret of Cyrus or Cyrrhus (;  AD 393 –  458/466) was an influential theologian of the School of Antioch, biblical commentator, and Christian bishop of Cyrrhus (423–457). He played a pivotal role in several 5th-century Byzantine Church controversies that led to various ecumenical acts and schisms. He wrote against Cyril of Alexandria's 12 Anathemas which were sent to Nestorius and did not personally condemn Nestorius until the Council of Chalcedon. His writings against Cyril were included in the Three Chapters Controversy and were condemned at the Second Council of Constantinople.

Carnival is a Western Christian festive season that occurs before the liturgical season of Lent . The main events typically include carnival games, parades, carnival games, carnival food and beverages, and a carnival parade that lasts for weeks. The Feast of Saint Bartholomew takes place between October and November, followed by Carnival Day, which lasts a week in October and a day in November . The last feast on the Feast of the Apostles takes place around December 8 . The Feast of Saint Martin is the first week of Advent, which falls between December 5 and January 6 .

Adoption is a process whereby a person assumes the parenting of another, usually a child, from that person's biological or legal parent or parents. Legal adoptions permanently transfer all rights and responsibilities, along with filiation, from the biological parents to the adoptive parents.Unlike guardianship or other systems designed for the care of the young, adoption is intended to effect a permanent change in status and as such requires societal recognition, either through legal or religious sanction. Historically, some societies have enacted specific laws governing adoption, while others used less formal means (notably contracts that specified inheritance rights and parental responsibilities without an accompanying transfer of filiation).

Loris is the common name for the strepsirrhine mammals of the subfamily Lorinae ( sometimes spelled Lorisinae ) in the family Rhinocerotidae. There are about 100 species in the family, of which about half are found in Asia, with the remainder spread throughout the Old World. The species vary widely in size, and the largest are up to 20 m long. These mammals are omnivores and omnivorous carnivores and are primarily active at night. Loris is the name often used for any large mammal, but some other genera also include the word loris.

Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) is a U.S. multiprogram science and technology national laboratory sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) and administered, managed, and operated by UT–Battelle as a federally funded research and development center (FFRDC) under a contract with the DOE, located in Oak Ridge, Tennessee.Established in 1943, ORNL is the largest science and energy national laboratory in the Department of Energy system (by size) and third largest by annual budget. It is located in the Roane County section of Oak Ridge, Tennessee.

Erich Armand Arthur Joseph Hückel ( August 9 , 1896 , Berlin – February 16 , 1980 , Marburg ) was a German composer, singer-songwriter, and conductor. His music is based on the folk melodies that were popular during the Weimar Republic of the 1920s, particularly the song "Der Vater der Hunde." He had no formal musical training. But in 1918, he composed a number of songs and arranged them as an orchestra piece. These songs, which he later arranged as symphonic movements, became highly influential in later German and international musical circles.

Ilona Staller (born 26 November 1951), widely known by her stage name Cicciolina ("little chubby one"), is a Hungarian-Italian former porn star, politician, and singer.Early lifeIlona was born in Budapest, Hungary. Her father, László Staller, left the family when she was young. She was raised by her mother, who was a midwife, and her stepfather, who was an official in the Hungarian Ministry of the Interior.In 1964, she began working as a model for the Hungarian news agency, M.T.I.

Jobst of Moravia ( or Jošt Lucemburský ; or Jodokus von Mähren ; c. 1354 – 18 January 1411 ) was a Bohemian noble who rose to a considerable power in Bohemia and later the German Empire. The name Jože is a diminutive from his surname, and his given name, Joža, is a variant of the German name Jodokus. Jože was born the son of Jindrich I of Moravia and Anna, the granddaughter of Duke Henry I of Meissen. He was born into the House of Meissen, and received the title of Count from Emperor Casimir IV the Great when he took over the Bohemian Kingdom.

In music performance and notation, legato (; Italian for "tied together"; French lié; German gebunden) indicates that musical notes are played or sung smoothly and connected. That is, the player makes a transition from note to note with no intervening silence. Legato technique is required for slurred performance, but unlike slurring (as that term is interpreted for some instruments), legato does not forbid re-articulation.Standard notation indicates legato either with the word legato, or by a slur (a curved line) under notes that form one legato group.

Year 976 ( CMLXXVI ) was a leap year starting on Saturday ( link will display the full calendar ) that applied the denomination CMLXXVI to the Julian calendar, the first year of the Roman imperial era, i.e. beginning of the first year of the rule of the emperor Caligula (r. 37–39). This leap year marked the end of the First Cataract, which in the Julian Calendar, had begun on Sunday at noon (link). Events 
 By 
 The Byzantine Empire falls to the Muslims in the Siege of Constantinople by the Muslim Turks.

Squid are cephalopods in the superorder Decapodiformes with elongated bodies , large eyes , eight arms and two tentacles . They also have an aquatic habitat . In the classification of animal families, they are the most basal cephalopods, the oldest-known members of this group . They belong to the family Trionychidae, suborder Squaliforme, and the order Squamiformes. A number of genera are placed in the suborder Squaliforme, while several others are placed in a number of families:
The suborder is divided into:
 order Squaliforme, which contains:
 Trionychidae, the Squids, the largest living cephalopods .

Yucatán ( , also , , ; ) , officially the Free and Sovereign State of Yucatán , is one of the world's largest islands, and the second-most-populous. It is the largest island and the only one to have an airport. Located between the Pacific Ocean to the east and the Caribbean Sea to the west, it borders Mexico to the north and Central America south. The state is named after the Maya kingdom of Yucatán, the country's official language. It has been the site of important battles between both sides since the conquest.

Casimir Jagiellon (; ; ; 3 October 1458 – 4 March 1484) was a prince of the Kingdom of Poland and of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. Second son of King Casimir IV Jagiellon, he was tutored by Johannes Longinus, a Polish chronicler and diplomat. After his elder brother Vladislaus was elected as King of Bohemia in 1471, Casimir became the heir apparent. At the age of 13, Casimir participated in the failed military campaign to install him as King of Hungary. He became known for his piety, devotion to God, and generosity towards the sick and poor.

The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development ( EBRD ) is an international financial institution founded in 1991 . As a World bank in the form of a private non- governmental organization , it is mandated to serve the needs of the developing nations through loans and grants. Its objective is to promote economic growth and economic development in countries of the Developing world . It helps developing countries in a variety of ways, such as by providing infrastructure, social services and technology . The EBRD is also one of the largest private banks in the United States .

Aden ( , ; Yemeni : ) is a city , and since 2015 , the temporary capital of Yemen. Aden is the country's main port and commercial centre and is located on the Red Sea coast. With a land area of around , Aden is one of the most populous cities in Africa and in South Asia with a population of more than 2.9 million people. It is the fourth-most populous city in Sub-Saharan Africa after Lagos in Nigeria, Nairobi in Kenya, and Cairo in Egypt. Aden's main industry includes tourism, agriculture and commerce.

Year 878 ( DCCCLXXVIII ) was a common year starting on Wednesday ( link will display the full calendar ) and a little before Thursday ( link will display the week number in parenthesis ) of the Julian calendar. The Gregorian calendar was begun on Monday of this year and will finish on September 21 of this year. The Common Era would begin on Tuesday ( link will display year number and week number ) of next year. It would end on Sunday ( link will display year number ) on December 31 of next year and would begin on Wednesday the 2nd day of December of this year.

Gregory of Nyssa, also known as Gregory Nyssen (; c. 335 – c. 395), was bishop of Nyssa, Cappadocia, from 372 to 376 and from 378 until his death. He is venerated as a saint in Roman Catholicism, Eastern Orthodoxy, Oriental Orthodoxy, Anglicanism, and Lutheranism. Gregory, his elder brother Basil of Caesarea, and their friend Gregory of Nazianzus are collectively known as the Cappadocian Fathers.Gregory lacked the administrative ability of his brother Basil or the contemporary influence of Gregory of Nazianzus, but he was an erudite theologian who made significant contributions to the doctrine of the Trinity and the Nicene Creed.

Imre Lakatos ( , ; ; November 9 , 1922 – February 2 , 1974 ) was a Hungarian philosopher, essayist and literary critic. He was the author of many books and essays on philosophy and religion, and of a series of short stories in which he satirizes his intellectual and political adversaries. Lakatos is known as the most controversial of the 19th century figures of the Vienna school of analytic philosophy. Although his philosophy has been the subject of a number of philosophical critiques, his work continues to be taught in universities around the world and he was a major figure in the debate between analytic andcontinental philosophy.

Pope Gregory VII ( ; 1015 – 25 May 1085 ) , born Hildebrand of Sovana , was head of the Byzantine Empire in the middle of the 12th century. After his death, his son and successor, John VI Palaiologos became the emperor. Hildebrand was named by his predecessor, Constantine II (), as "the son of one of the foremost knights in the Byzantine army". He was a strong opponent of the Byzantine emperors Basil I (ruling from 965-991) and Theodore I Komnenos (ruling from 1018-1025). Hildebrand inherited the throne from his father's cousin Constantine VII Lekapenos.

Year 980 ( CMLXXX ) was a leap year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. Events 
 By place 
 Asia 
 The Khmer Empire, founded by Khmer monarch Suryavarman II, expands in southern Cambodia. The Khmer Empire expands in the south and the south-west of the Mekong River basin into the Cambodian interior. Britain 
 Prince Edward, Duke of York, is born in Scotland. He goes to live with his mother and father. The House of Windsor, a branch of the House of Anjou that has no male heirs, disinherits Henry, Duke of Gloucester.

Fall back is a feature of a modem protocol in data communication whereby two communicating modems which experience data corruption (due to line noise, for example) can renegotiate with each other to use a lower-speed connection. Fall forward is a corresponding feature whereby two modems which have "fallen back" to a lower speed can later return to the higher speed if the connection improves.A common feature modems was the concept of fallback, allowing them to talk to less-capable modems. During the call initiation the modem would play a series of signals into the line and wait for the remote modem to "answer" them.

Hildegard Frieda Albertine Knef (; 28 December 19251 February 2002) was a German actress, voice actress, singer, and writer. She was billed in some English-language films as Hildegard Neff or Hildegarde Neff.Early yearsHildegard Knef was born in Ulm in 1925. Her parents were Hans Theodor and Friede Augustine Knef. Her father, a condecorated First World War veteran, died of syphilis when she was only six months old, and her mother moved to Berlin and worked in a factory. Knef began studying acting at age 14 in 1940. She left school at 15 to become an apprentice animator with Universum Film AG.

A nuclear thermal rocket (NTR) is a type of thermal rocket where the heat from a nuclear reaction, often nuclear fission, replaces the chemical energy of the propellants in a chemical rocket. In an NTR, a working fluid, usually liquid hydrogen, is heated to a high temperature in a nuclear reactor and then expands through a rocket nozzle to create thrust. The external nuclear heat source theoretically allows a higher effective exhaust velocity and is expected to double or triple payload capacity compared to chemical propellants that store energy internally.NTRs have been proposed as a spacecraft propulsion technology, with the earliest ground tests occurring in 1955.

Dorset (; archaically: Dorsetshire) is a county in South West England on the English Channel coast. The ceremonial county comprises the unitary authority areas of Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole and Dorset. Covering an area of , Dorset borders Devon to the west, Somerset to the north-west, Wiltshire to the north-east, and Hampshire to the east. The county town is Dorchester which is  in the south. After the reorganisation of local government in 1974, the county's border was extended eastward to incorporate the Hampshire towns of Bournemouth and Christchurch.

is a Japanese manga series written and illustrated by Rumiko Takahashi. It was serialized in Big Comic Spirits from November 1980 to April 1987, with the chapters collected into 15 tankōbon volumes by Shogakukan. Maison Ikkoku is a bittersweet romantic comedy involving a group of madcap people who live in a boarding house in 1980s Tokyo. The story focuses primarily on the gradually developing relationships between Yusaku Godai, a poor student down on his luck, and Kyoko Otonashi, a young, recently widowed boarding house manager.The manga was adapted into a ninety-six-episode anime television series created by Studio Deen that ran on Fuji TV from March 1986 to March 1988.

Patch collecting or badge collecting ( also , scutelliphily , from Latin scutellus meaning little shield , and Greek phileein , meaning badge , from Φλεγειάν , phylein meaning badge or coat of arms ) can refer to any activities that are undertaken to obtain a reputation for some achievement or skill. Collecting badges and rewards can take many forms; for example, collecting badges and badges may indicate a member of a group or organization. Collecting badges may indicate membership in a club or association. A badge of honor may be awarded by some organizations to a person or a group for their outstanding achievement.

Psilocybin is a naturally occurring psychedelic prodrug compound produced by more than 200 species of fungi . The most potent of the three isoforms of psilocybin, LSD, is known to exert its biological effects mainly in the limbic areas and is used in the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders, but the potential of psilocybin to induce euphoria is still controversial. Psilocybin has also shown effects similar to those of many other psychotropic drugs . The most important psychedelic substances that have been used for recreational purposes include DMT , magic mushrooms , peyote cactus , DMT , and LSD , which is also called "marihuana" .

The M109 is an American 155 mm turreted self-propelled howitzer, first introduced in the early 1960s to replace the M44. It has been upgraded a number of times, most recently to the M109A7. The M109 family is the most common Western indirect-fire support weapon of maneuver brigades of armored and mechanized infantry divisions.The M109 has a crew of four: the section chief/commander, the driver, the gunner, and the ammunition handler/loader. The chief or gunner aims the cannon left or right (deflection) and up and down (quadrant).The British Army replaced its M109s with the AS-90.

A knight's tour is a sequence of moves of a knight on a chessboard such that the knight visits every square exactly once. If the knight ends on a square that is one knight's move from the beginning square (so that it could tour the board again immediately, following the same path), the tour is closed (or re-entrant); otherwise, it is open.The knight's tour problem is the mathematical problem of finding a knight's tour. Creating a program to find a knight's tour is a common problem given to computer science students.

( All Women Do It , or The School for Lovers ) , K. 588 , is an opera buffa in 4 acts and 13 scenes in French libretto , scored for 1,072 singers, 2 tenors and basso cantabri . It is based on a 15th-century legend in which a girl in love with the son of her step-father turns to prostitution to pay for her dowry, which she cannot afford to pay. The first performance of the opera took place on 20 January 2015 in the Salle Favart at the Opéra-Comique in Paris in Paris.

A verb is a word ( part of speech ) that in syntax conveys an action ( bring , read , write ), in a particular context ( for the purposes of , , , , , , etc , ) , but not in the context of the verb itself . In other words, it is a syntactic construction , that means a construction of words or phrases used as an expression of an action , for the sake of which something is done ( for the purposes of ) or the sake of ( to , etc , ) . Verbs are syntactic verbs .

Dresden (, ; Upper Saxon: Dräsdn; ) is the capital city of the German state of Saxony and its second most populous city, after Leipzig. It is the 12th most populous city of Germany, the fourth largest by area (after Berlin, Hamburg and Cologne), and the third most populous city in the area of former East Germany, after Berlin and Leipzig. Dresden's urban area comprises the towns of Freital, Pirna, Radebeul, Meißen (Meissen), Coswig, Radeberg and Heidenau and has around 790,000 inhabitants.

Keep the Aspidistra Flying , first published in 1936 , is a socially critical novel by George Orwell . It is a fictionalised account of the events that lead to the outbreak of the Second World War in 1937. It is set in a fictional country called London , which Orwell called "The Home Counties" . It is written in third person, based on his own experiences in the period . There are many other characters in the book that have not been named. The main character is John Aspinall , an English aristocrat .

Pali  is a Middle Indo-Aryan liturgical language native to the Indian subcontinent. It is widely studied because it is the language of the Pāli Canon or Tipiṭaka as well as the sacred language of Theravāda Buddhism. In early time, it was written in Brahmi script.Origin and developmentEtymologyThe word 'Pali' is used as a name for the language of the Theravada canon. The word seems to have its origins in commentarial traditions, wherein the Pāli (in the sense of the line of original text quoted) was distinguished from the commentary or vernacular translation that followed it in the manuscript.

Phenylalanine (symbol Phe or F) is an essential α-amino acid with the formula . It can be viewed as a benzyl group substituted for the methyl group of alanine, or a phenyl group in place of a terminal hydrogen of alanine. This essential amino acid is classified as neutral, and nonpolar because of the inert and hydrophobic nature of the benzyl side chain. The L-isomer is used to biochemically form proteins coded for by DNA. Phenylalanine is a precursor for tyrosine, the monoamine neurotransmitters dopamine, norepinephrine (noradrenaline), epinephrine (adrenaline), and the skin pigment melanin.

The AGM-114 Hellfire ( AGM stands for air-to-ground missile ) is an air-to-surface missile ( ASM ) first developed for the U.S. Navy and first deployed in 1982, and which is currently used by the Russian military. The Hellfire's primary purpose is to destroy enemy air-defense radars. A secondary role is as a platform for long range air-to-surface missiles. A single Hellfire missile can destroy multiple enemy targets in about a minute. It has an effective range of approximately 15,000–20,000 km. Unlike other ASM platforms, the Hellfire does not need to be reloaded from a drum.

Courtesan , in modern usage , is a euphemism for a `` kept '' mistress or prostitute , particularly one used for the purposes of sexual service , rather than for the sale of goods or for hire of a sexual slave . The word itself has been in use since about the early 16th century . Contents

The term "ctesanne", which is an old-fashioned contraction of English , has come to be used to designate a sex worker , regardless of profession . It is also used to include all women who provide sexual services such as prostitution, escorting, housekeeping or any other sexual trade .

A software bug is an error , flaw or fault in computer software that causes it to produce an incorrect or unintended output. The term is often employed to indicate a programming error. A bug or flaw in an application can also be called a defect, a defect, a bug or a flaw, depending on how the application is intended to operate. There are different types of computer software applications. The software applications may be written in a variety of languages (e.g., the languages C, C++, Java, J#, Perl, Ruby, C#, C, D, PHP, etc.).

Columbia Business School (CBS) is the business school of Columbia University in the City of New York in Manhattan, New York City. Established in 1916, Columbia Business School is one of six Ivy League business schools and is one of the oldest business schools in the world. In 2022, it was ranked as the 2nd best business school.History The school was founded in 1916 with 11 full-time faculty members and an inaugural class of 61 students, including 8 women. Banking executive Emerson McMillin provided initial funding in 1916, while A. Barton Hepburn, then president of Chase National Bank, provided funding for the School's endowment in 1919.

Activision Publishing , Inc. is an American video game publisher based in Santa Monica , California . It serves as the parent company of a number of independent game companies, most notably the EA studios in Montreal, Quebec City, Montreal , Quebec , Ontario , Ottawa , Ontario , Ottawa , Ontario , Toronto , Ontario , New York New York , California , Toronto , California and New York . As of December 31, 2009, the publishing company was listed by Forbes magazine as the number 7 publisher in the United States with a $2.5 billion market value.

Central Park is an urban park in New York City located between the Upper West and Upper East Sides of Manhattan. It is the fifth-largest park in the city by area, covering . It is the most visited urban park in the United States, with an estimated 42 million visitors annually , and is the most filmed location in the world.Following proposals for a large park in Manhattan during the 1840s, it was approved in 1853 to cover . In 1857, landscape architects Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux won a design competition for the park with their "Greensward Plan".

Garnets are a group of silicate minerals that have been used since the Bronze Age as gemstones and abrasives.All species in this mineral class are typically formed from monosilicate (MgO) precursors which crystallize to octosilicate with Mg(2)(SiO4) and FeO (Fe2O3) phases. The presence of both Fe- and Al-containing minerals in garnets is believed to be the key to understanding garnet chemistry and properties. In addition, a variety of garnet mineral phases, some with different compositions and properties, are reported to be the end product of the garnet crystallization process.

Frame Relay is a standardized wide area network ( WAN ) technology that specifies the physical and data link layers of a WAN and allows communication between devices within that network. Broadly, a relay may be an entity that forwards a signal that is intended to go to another network entity, or a network entity that receives a signal and forwards it to a destination network entity. A network entity may be an end point device or a gateway, or some other entity that processes data that is transmitted to or from a network entity.

Malayalam (; , ) is a Dravidian language spoken in the Indian state of Kerala and the union territories of Lakshadweep and Puducherry (Mahé district) by the Malayali people. It is one of 22 scheduled languages of India and is spoken by 2.88% of Indians. Malayalam has official language status in Kerala, Lakshadweep and Puducherry (Mahé), and is spoken by 34 million people worldwide. Malayalam is also spoken by linguistic minorities in the neighbouring states; with significant number of speakers in the Kodagu and Dakshina Kannada districts of Karnataka, and Nilgiris and Kanyakumari, districts of Tamil Nadu.

The chicken (Gallus domesticus) is a domesticated bird, with attributes of wild species such as the red and grey junglefowl that are originally from Southeastern Asia. Rooster or cock is a term for an adult male bird, and a younger male may be called a cockerel. A male that has been castrated is a capon. An adult female bird is called a hen and a sexually immature female is called a pullet.Originally raised for cockfighting or for special ceremonies, chickens were not kept for food until the Hellenistic period (4th–2nd centuries BC).

The lungs are the primary organs of the respiratory system in humans and most animals including a few fish , and therefore, research on the structure of the lungs in different species is of great importance to understand the evolution and development of lungs, the function of lungs, etc. For this reason, the lung development research in the recent years has become one of the hot research topics. To date, three major research approaches, embryonic development and the adult lung, the lung transplantation and the new generation of tissue-engineered lung, were put forward.

Brighella ( in Bergamasque dialect : Brighèla ) is a comic , masked character from the Italian theatre style Commedia dell'arte. It was one of the most popular masked performers of its era (the first one is known to have appeared in 1891 in Bellagio ) and is famous for its theatrical and comic style. Brighella first appears in the play "Una notte in una camera" by Pietro Coppola (1930), where he plays a masked clown, and in many subsequent productions. The first full-scale theatrical performance of the character dates to 1953 in Milan, where it was performed in the Sala della Repubblica in the Palazzo Reale.

Squid are cephalopods in the superorder Decapodiformes with elongated bodies, large eyes, eight arms and two tentacles. Like all other cephalopods, squid have a distinct head, bilateral symmetry, and a mantle. They are mainly soft-bodied, like octopuses, but have a small internal skeleton in the form of a rod-like gladius or pen, made of chitin.Squid diverged from other cephalopods during the Jurassic and occupy a similar role to teleost fish as open water predators of similar size and behaviour. They play an important role in the open water food web.

Millets  are a group of highly variable small-seeded grasses, widely grown around the world as cereal crops or grains for fodder and human food. Most species generally referred to as millets belong to the tribe Paniceae, but some millets also belong to various other taxa.Millets are important crops in the semiarid tropics of Asia and Africa (especially in India, Mali, Nigeria, and Niger), with 97% of millet production in developing countries. The crop is favored due to its productivity and short growing season under dry, high-temperature conditions.Millets are indigenous to many parts of the world.

Thrust is a reaction force described quantitatively by Newton 's third law . When a system expels or accelerates mass from a chamber, the chamber is said to be at rest or at the top of the force graph. When a system accelerates mass from a chamber, the chamber is said to be at one of two states. In both cases the mass of the chamber is moving either toward or away from the force. The ratio of the forces exerted on the chamber by the external forces is equal to the rate of change of angular momentum of the moving mass.

The Porsche 914 or VW-Porsche 914 is a mid-engined sports car designed, manufactured and marketed collaboratively by Volkswagen and Porsche from 1969 until 1976. It was only available as a targa-topped two-seat roadster powered by either a flat-4 or flat-6 engine.HistoryPre-development By the late 1960s, both Volkswagen and Porsche were in need of new models; Porsche was looking for a replacement for their entry-level 912, and Volkswagen wanted a new range-topping sports coupé to replace the Volkswagen Type 34 Karmann Ghia coupé. At the time the majority of Volkswagen's development work was handled by Porsche as part of an agreement that dated back to Porsche's founding.

Alfa Romeo Automobiles S.p.A. is an Italian luxury car manufacturer and a subsidiary of Stellantis . The company was founded by Giuseppe Alfieri in 1901 in Turin, and is currently headquartered in Sommacampagna, Parma, Italy, with their headquarters in Milano, near Milan. The company produces a total of six models of automobiles, and is well known for its luxury brand, Alfa Romeo cars, which have been built since 1931. The first car produced by Alfieri in this series was the Alfa Romeo 904, which was built in 1931, and was followed in 1932 by the Alfa Romeo 912.

The Jagiellonian University (Polish: Uniwersytet Jagielloński (UJ)) is a public research university in Kraków, Poland. Founded in 1364 by King Casimir III the Great, it is the oldest university in Poland and the 13th oldest university in continuous operation in the world. It is often regarded as Poland's most prestigious academic institution. The university has been viewed as a guardian of Polish culture, particularly for continuing operations during the partitions of Poland and the two World Wars, as well as a significant contributor to the intellectual heritage of Europe.The campus of the Jagiellonian University is centrally located within the city of Kraków.

In the administrative divisions of France, the department  is one of the three levels of government under the national level ("territorial collectivities"), between the administrative regions and the communes. Ninety-six departments are in metropolitan France, and five are overseas departments, which are also classified as overseas regions. Departments are further subdivided into 332 arrondissements, and these are divided into cantons. The last two levels of government have no autonomy; they are the basis of local organisation of police, fire departments and, sometimes, administration of elections.Each department is administered by an elected body called a departmental council ( [sing.

Toilet paper ( sometimes called toilet tissue ) is a tissue paper product primarily used to clean the anus and to absorb body waste. In the United States, toilet paper is sold at retailers such as, for example, drug stores, grocery stores, mass merchandisers and the like. In Europe toilet paper is available in mass merchandiser and retail outlets. Towel bars are commonly used in a variety of applications, and include a wide variety of different materials and designs. A towel bar is typically formed of a flexible material, for instance a rubber or a rubberized material, in order to allow easy cleaning of surfaces.

In mathematics and physics, Laplace's equation is a second-order partial differential equation named after Pierre-Simon Laplace, who first studied its properties. This is often written as or where  is the Laplace operator,  is the divergence operator (also symbolized "div"),  is the gradient operator (also symbolized "grad"),  and  is a twice-differentiable real-valued function. The Laplace operator therefore maps a scalar function to another scalar function.If the right-hand side is specified as a given function, , we haveThis is called Poisson's equation, a generalization of Laplace's equation.

ESP most commonly refers to: Extrasensory perception, a paranormal ability Spain (España) - ISO three-letter country code for SpainESP may also refer to:Arts, entertainmentMusic  ESP Guitars, a manufacturer of electric guitars E.S. Posthumus, an independent music group formed in 2000, that produces cinematic style music ESP-Disk, a 1960s free-jazz record label based in New York The Electric Soft Parade, a British band formed in 2001 Eric Singer Project, side project founded in the 1990s by musician Eric Singer ESP, a collaboration between Space Tribe and other artistsSongs, albums  E.S.P.

Auger electron spectroscopy ( AES ; pronounced in French ) is a common analytical technique used specifically in the study of the chemical and physical properties of organic compounds. The electron spectrum (ES) is a representation of the distribution of electrons in the system under study. ESI allows the detection of functional groups in the molecule in order to characterize the chemistry. ESI is a powerful method for the characterization of the chemical environment of a molecule. ESI is very sensitive and offers a high degree of selectivity, even in the case of complex matrixes such as polar organic liquids.

A shaped charge is an explosive charge shaped to focus the effect of the explosive's energy. Different types of shaped charges are used for various purposes such as cutting and forming metal, initiating nuclear weapons, penetrating armor, or perforating wells in the oil and gas industry.A typical modern shaped charge, with a metal liner on the charge cavity, can penetrate armor steel to a depth of seven or more times the diameter of the charge (charge diameters, CD), though greater depths of 10 CD and above have been achieved.

Nord ( ; officially ; ; , ) , is a department in Hauts-de-France region , France bordering Belgium . Geography
Nord is located in the east of the department, near the French and Belgian border. The department is  above sea level. The departments borders with the departments of Nord-Provence, Nord-Pas-de-Calais, Val-d'Oise, Pas-de-Calais, Limoges and the region of Alsace. It has a humid continental climate characterized by very high temperatures and a long, cold spell in winter. The highest temperature ever recorded in Nord was  on 2 March 2013, the lowest temperature ever recorded on the territory of Nord was  on 28 May 2017.

The First Book of Nephi: His Reign and Ministry , usually referred to as First Nephi or 1 Nephi, is the first book of the Book of Mormon and one of four books with the name Nephi. The original translation of the title did not include the word "first". First and Second were added to the titles of the Books of Nephi by Oliver Cowdery when preparing the book for printing. It is a first-person narrative by a prophet named Nephi, of events that began around 600 BC and recorded on the small plates of Nephi approximately 30 years later.

Year 950 ( CML ) was a common year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. Events 
 By place 
 Byzantine Empire 
 Emperor Romanos II is killed in a battle near Constantinople with his rival, Emperor Theodosios. In accordance with his deathbed wish, Constantine (the future Romanos III) is made emperor by the Byzantine Orthodox church. His regency is in turn contested by his father Constantine VII Monomachus, who seeks his brother Romanos III as regent and conspires for a third regency. The Council of Carthage takes place in Carthage.

Year 1054 ( MLIV ) was a common year starting on Saturday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. The Gregorian calendar was not extended to 1054. As a result, the style of some calendars does not always agree with year 1054 ( MLIV ) which was a leap year. Events 

 January 25–27: The Roman emperor Claudius returns from exile and takes up residence in Rome ( link will display the full calendar ,  and  years). January 26–January 26: The Second Punic War begins, and Roman armies attack Carthage in North Africa.

`` Wilhelmus van Nassouwe '' , usually known just as `` Wilhelmus '' ( ; ; English translation : `` Willemus ' '' )

The English name for the Dutchman Wilhelmus was given to him as a young boy, as it was the same name that the king of Gouda had given to his uncle. It was the name that was known throughout Europe, and his mother was said to have taken it from his father, an official in Gouda. The boy was given the name of Van Nassouwe, because he was named after his uncle.

The Northrop Grumman RQ-4 Global Hawk is a high-altitude , remotely-piloted surveillance aircraft . It was initially designed by Ryan and Associates, a Lockheed Martin subsidiary, in collaboration with Boeing as a successor to the MQ-1A Global Hawk . Following the merger of Lockheed Martin, the Northrop Grumman company was created from the Lockheed Martin and Boeing entities and is the first commercial aircraft company to be publicly traded on any stock exchange. The aircraft was unveiled at the Farnborough Airshow in England in July 2006, where it became the first remotely piloted aircraft. The aircraft was announced at a news conference held on 24 November 2006.

In quantum mechanics , counterfactual definiteness ( CFD ) is the ability to speak `` meaningfully '' of the definiteness of quantum states. It is typically expressed by saying that ``a quantum state is definitly one of the following'', where "definitely" is used here in the traditional sense, to indicate that the state belongs to the relevant class of possible quantum states, e.g. as a state of definite parity. The notion has its origin in the works of Wheeler, Bohm and others. It has recently been revived in quantum information , e.g. in the works of Horodecki and other.

The Story of the Chevalier des Grieux and Manon Lescaut  is a novel by Antoine François Prévost. Published in 1731, it is the seventh and final volume of Mémoires et aventures d'un homme de qualité (Memoirs and Adventures of a Man of Quality).The story, set in France and Louisiana in the early 18th century, follows the hero, the Chevalier des Grieux, and his lover, Manon Lescaut. Controversial in its time, the work was banned in France upon publication. Despite this, it became very popular and pirated editions were widely distributed.

KFC (also known as Kentucky Fried Chicken) is an American fast food restaurant chain headquartered in Louisville, Kentucky that specializes in fried chicken. It is the world's second-largest restaurant chain (as measured by sales) after McDonald's, with 22,621 locations globally in 150 countries . The chain is a subsidiary of Yum! Brands, a restaurant company that also owns the Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and WingStreet chains.KFC was founded by Colonel Harland Sanders, an entrepreneur who began selling fried chicken from his roadside restaurant in Corbin, Kentucky during the Great Depression.

Year 1036 ( MXXXVI ) was a leap year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar (the standard; before 2017 it was the name of an earlier leap year). The leap year starting on Thursday is the most common year for the Christian year. This is the second year that it will fall on a Wednesday, the last year it would fall on a Saturday, and the next two years fall on a Sunday. A leap year will be celebrated in two parts.

Year 980 (CMLXXX) was a leap year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  Peace is concluded between Emperor Otto II (the Red) and King Lothair III (or Lothair IV) at Margut, ending the Franco-German war of 978–980. Lothair renounces his claim on Lower Lorraine, while Otto promises to recognize Lothair's son Louis V as the rightful heir of the West Frankish Kingdom. June 11 – Vladimir I (the Great), grand prince of Kiev, consolidates the Kievan realm from modern Ukraine to the Baltic Sea.

George Catlett Marshall Jr. ( December 31 , 1880 – October 16 , 1959 ) was an American army officer who served in the Philippine Scouts and was awarded the Silver Star and three Bronze Star Medals for his actions in World War I. The Marshall family moved to New York City when he was eight years old, where he later attended and graduated from New York University. The Marshall family moved back to the West Coast when he was a senior at college, settling in the San Francisco Bay Area. He served in the First Cavalry Regiment of the Philippine Scouts.

Padthaway is a small town in the Australian state of South Australia located in the state 's south-east within the Adelaide Region. In the , it had a population of 1,053. The city is the second oldest in South Australia after Adelaide. In addition the Port Adelaide city limits were originally established in the area around what is the current "Port Adelaide Airport". Port Adelaide is on the southern edge of the Adelaide Hills on the edge of the Nullarbor Plain to the south-west and is the most populated urban centre on the coast north of the coast, with a population of 4.7 million.

A cigarette is a narrow cylinder containing burnable material, typically tobacco, that is rolled into thin paper for smoking. The cigarette is ignited at one end, causing it to smolder; the resulting smoke is orally inhaled via the opposite end. Cigarette smoking is the most common method of tobacco consumption. Manufacturers have described the cigarette as "a drug administration system for the delivery of nicotine in acceptable and attractive form." The term cigarette, as commonly used, refers to a tobacco cigarette, but the word is sometimes used to refer to other substances, such as a cannabis (Jazz) cigarette or an herbal cigarette.

Emissions trading is a market-based approach to controlling pollution by providing economic incentives for reducing the emissions of pollutants . . . .” (Emphasis ours). This is not an anti-pollution measure. It is a means of cleaning up a pollution problem, which we all share. And there is nothing “illegal” about any of this. What is wrong with our politicians? “But, and this is an important and common sense point, not all pollution is the same, and some of it is dangerous (and polluting), and some of it is not.

A supercomputer is a computer with a high level of performance as compared to a general-purpose computer. The performance of a supercomputer is commonly measured in floating-point operations per second (FLOPS) instead of million instructions per second (MIPS). Since 2017, there are supercomputers which can perform over 1017 FLOPS (a hundred quadrillion FLOPS, 100 petaFLOPS or 100 PFLOPS). For comparison, a desktop computer has performance in the range of hundreds of gigaFLOPS to tens of teraFLOPS.Since November 2017, all of the world's fastest 500 supercomputers run Linux-based operating systems.

Eagle is the common name for many large birds of prey of the family Accipitridae . Eagles belong to several species, the most notable of which are the bald eagle, the golden eagle, hawks, and eagles, which are all related. The most widespread of the raptors in North America, eagles have been seen in most countries of the Americas, and are also found in Europe, Asia, and Australia. Eagles are native to the Americas, where they have occupied parts of South and Central America, Central America, the Bahamas, the islands of Southeast Asia and the South Pacific.

The bowline ( or ) is an ancient and simple knot used to form a fixed loop at the end of a piece of fabric. It is a classic example of knotting that was first developed by the ancient Egyptians. The technique was improved and perfected by the Romans and was subsequently used in all areas of fabric work, both for decorative purposes (such as the bow-ties in lace) and for use as a form of binding, in which case it is called a bowline binding. The bowline itself is formed in the same way as for the bow knot, i.e.

Reptilia is Canada's largest indoor reptile zoo, with  of indoor exhibits featuring over 250 reptiles, amphibians and arachnids. It is accredited by CAZA.Currently there are two Ontario locations, one in Vaughan and one in Whitby.LocationsThe original Reptilia zoo was established in Vaughan; it is housed in a  facility. In 2018, it opened a second location in Whitby in a former  Rona store. In late 2018, it announced plans to create similar zoos in London and Barrie. London City Council rejected the proposal for a  reptile zoo in Westmount Mall.AttractionsAbout 250 species of reptiles are in the zoo's collection.

Year 959 ( CMLIX ) was a common year starting on Saturday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar ( 20 December 2116 BC ) with a new Gregorian calendar ( 20 March 2045 AD ) which is being retained and continues in force until 21 December 2100. The New Year's Day (1 January 1) and New Year (20 August 2023 AD ) of the Julian calendar will also be used until 21 December 2045 AD when the Gregorian calendar comes to an end. The year is numbered sequentially from 1 through 2039 AD, beginning with the year 1 AD and counting backwards.

In philosophy, systems theory, science, and art, emergence occurs when an entity is observed to have properties its parts do not have on their own, properties or behaviors which emerge only when the parts interact in a wider whole.Emergence plays a central role in theories of integrative levels and of complex systems. For instance, the phenomenon of life as studied in biology is an emergent property of chemistry, and many psychological phenomena are known to emerge from underlying neurobiological processes.In philosophy, theories that emphasize emergent properties have been called emergentism.In philosophyPhilosophers often understand emergence as a claim about the etiology of a system's properties.

The War Game is a 1966 British pseudo-documentary film that depicts a nuclear war and its aftermath . Written , directed by , and produced by Ken Loach, it concerns a fictional military operation in which British forces launch a nuclear bomb into North Vietnam in the Vietnam War . The film is a parody of American war films like Apocalypse Now and Duel , and has been described as a "wacky thriller . . . that is, at least in the case of its subject matter . . ." The film has been released on VHS and DVD.

The National Guard is a state-based military force that becomes part of the reserve components of the United States Army and the United States Air Force when activated for federal missions. It is a military reserve force composed of National Guard military members or units of each state and the territories of Guam, the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, and the District of Columbia, for a total of 54 separate organizations. It is officially created under Congress's Article 1 Section 8 ability to 'raise and support armies'. All members of the National Guard are also members of the organized militia of the United States as defined by .

A nuclear thermal rocket ( NTR ) is a type of thermal rocket where the heat from a nuclear reaction is used to drive a solid-fuel rocket motor to propel the rocket into a high-altitude orbit using a thermo-gravitic rocket motor. This approach has the benefits of being able to propel large payloads into high-altitude orbits at a low cost relative to conventional rocket technology, such as chemical rockets that use propellant derived from petroleum. NTR's are also able to reach the outer solar system and beyond, including to Mars' Red Planet's moon Phobos and other planets.

Edward Teller ( ; January 15 , 1908 – September 9 , 2003 ) was a Hungarian-American theoretical physicist who worked in the field of theoretical atomic and sub-atomic physics. He made significant contributions to the development of quantum mechanics. Early life and career

Early years: 1908–1924
He was born in Budapest, Hungary to Jewish parents whose family had left Hungary during the early part of the 19th Century. His father, Abraham Teller, was also a physician. Teller grew up in Budapest where he studied physics at Budapest Technical College. He then studied physics at the University of Budapest.

Pope Leo II ( – 28 June 683 ) was the bishop of Rome from 17 August 682 to his death. Leo was the second son of Pope John XV and his wife Adelaide, a daughter of Otto III, Duke of Athens. He was the grandson of Pope Boniface VIII, and a nephew of Pope Benedict XIV. He was consecrated a bishop in the Cathedral of St Peter ad Vincola on 28 May 682, and attended to his father's last illness. When his father died on 30 July 682, Leo was elected pope by the Council of Florence.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA  ) is an American scientific and regulatory agency within the United States Department of Commerce that forecasts weather, monitors oceanic and atmospheric conditions, charts the seas, conducts deep sea exploration, and manages fishing and protection of marine mammals and endangered species in the U.S. exclusive economic zone.Purpose and functionNOAA's specific roles include: Supplying Environmental Information Products. NOAA supplies to its customers and partners information pertaining to the state of the oceans and the atmosphere, such as weather warnings and forecasts via the National Weather Service. NOAA's information services extend as well to climate, ecosystems, and commerce.

Thrust is a reaction force described quantitatively by Newton's third law. When a system expels or accelerates mass in one direction, the accelerated mass will cause a force of equal magnitude but opposite direction to be applied to that system.The force applied on a surface in a direction perpendicular or normal to the surface is also called thrust. Force, and thus thrust, is measured using the International System of Units (SI) in newtons (symbol: N), and represents the amount needed to accelerate 1 kilogram of mass at the rate of 1 meter per second per second.

The Bussard ramjet is a theoretical method of spacecraft propulsion proposed in 1960 by the physicist Robert W. Bussard, popularized by Poul Anderson's novel Tau Zero, Larry Niven in his Known Space series of books, Vernor Vinge in his Zones of Thought series, and referred to by Carl Sagan in the television series and book Cosmos.Bussard proposed a ramjet variant of a fusion rocket capable of reasonable interstellar travel, using enormous electromagnetic fields (ranging from kilometers to many thousands of kilometers in diameter) as a ram scoop to collect and compress hydrogen from the interstellar medium.

A complex system is a system composed of many components which may interact with each other . Examples of complex systems include biological systems and social systems, such as human society
A complex system is a collection of parts that are all interconnected and that may interact with each other. The components of a complex system can be in any one of several states: either a steady state, an unstable steady state or a stable state [1]. The components may be interconnected. One component may produce or generate another component or system. A component is an element which is part of a complex system.

Dekker's algorithm is the first known correct solution to the mutual exclusion problem in concurrent programming. The solution is attributed to Dutch mathematician Th. J. Dekker by Edsger W. Dijkstra in an unpublished paper on sequential process descriptions and his manuscript on cooperating sequential processes. It allows two threads to share a single-use resource without conflict, using only shared memory for communication.It avoids the strict alternation of a naïve turn-taking algorithm, and was one of the first mutual exclusion algorithms to be invented.OverviewIf two processes attempt to enter a critical section at the same time, the algorithm will allow only one process in, based on whose turn it is.

The history of Southeast Asia covers the people of Southeast Asia from prehistory to the present in two distinct sub-regions of East Asia: Northeast Asia and Southeast Asia. Both regions share a common culture that is intertwined and interdependent with each other. This article will present an overview of Southeast Asia's history that focuses on the people and their relationship with each other as well as the politics and culture of the different states in Northeast Asia. Southeast Asia has been shaped by a complex and interdependent historical experience, and has been the cradle of many of the civilizations of the region.

Saxony-Anhalt ( ; ) is a state of Germany , bordering the states of Brandenburg , Saxony , Thuringia and Saxony-Anhalt . Geography 

As a part of West Prussia it borders with the Czech Republic, Poland, the Baltic states, Germany and the Czech Republic in the north, Poland, Slovakia and Hungary in the west, the Czech Republic, Hungary and Slovakia to the south, Romania in the east and Belarus, Ukraine and Russia to the southeast . Demographics 

 

 Population 
As of 2002, Saxony-Anhalt had 1,827,000 inhabitants (as at 31 December 2008).

Fidelio , originally titled  (Leonore, or The Triumph of Marital Love), Op. 72, is Ludwig van Beethoven's only opera. The German libretto was originally prepared by Joseph Sonnleithner from the French of Jean-Nicolas Bouilly, with the work premiering at Vienna's Theater an der Wien on 20 November 1805. The following year, Stephan von Breuning helped shorten the work from three acts to two. After further work on the libretto by Georg Friedrich Treitschke, a final version was performed at the Kärntnertortheater on 23 May 1814.

Celebration is a census-designated place (CDP) and a master-planned community in Osceola County, Florida, United States, located near Walt Disney World Resort and originally developed by The Walt Disney Company. The town, whose population was 7,427 at the 2010 census, is part of the Orlando–Kissimmee Metropolitan Statistical Area.After founding Celebration, Disney followed its plans to divest most of its control of the town. Several Disney business units continue to occupy the town's office buildings. Walt Disney World operates two utility companies, Smart City Telecom and Reedy Creek Energy Services, that provide services to the town.

Auger electron spectroscopy (AES; pronounced  in French) is a common analytical technique used specifically in the study of surfaces and, more generally, in the area of materials science. It is a form of electron spectroscopy that relies on the Auger effect, based on the analysis of energetic electrons emitted from an excited atom after a series of internal relaxation events. The Auger effect was discovered independently by both Lise Meitner and Pierre Auger in the 1920s. Though the discovery was made by Meitner and initially reported in the journal Zeitschrift für Physik in 1922, Auger is credited with the discovery in most of the scientific community.

Pope Gregory VII (;  1015 – 25 May 1085), born Hildebrand of Sovana , was head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 22 April 1073 to his death in 1085. He is venerated as a saint in the Catholic Church.One of the great reforming popes, he is perhaps best known for the part he played in the Investiture Controversy, his dispute with Emperor Henry IV that affirmed the primacy of papal authority and the new canon law governing the election of the pope by the College of Cardinals.

Giovanni Pacini ( 17 February 17966 December 1867 ) was an Italian composer , best known for his operas . Pacini was born in Rome and died in Paris . He was born to a poor family. When he was just six years old, his mother, Maria Pacini , gave him lessons. He studied at a music school and with a tutor, Giovanni Cimarosa . He also worked as an actor and as a chorus master in Italian opera houses in Italy . In 1785, he studied at the Rome Conservatoire where he was awarded his first prizes .

The World Federation of Trade Unions ( WFTU ) is an international federation of trade unions . WFTU was established in 1869 and is affiliated with the International Organization of the Labour Movement ( ILO ) and the United Nations . The Union represents over 2,200 unions in over 70 countries in areas such as transportation, communication, postal, transport services, and energy. WFTU is the largest international federation of trade unions worldwide. In June 2018, WFTU announced that it had entered negotiations with United Steelworkers of America to form a new union.

In the administrative divisions of France , the department is one of the three levels of government under the national government and forms part of the Departmental Council. As of 2014, the department has nine regions: Alsace, Ain, Aveyron, Eure-et-Loir, Grand Est, Loire-Atlantique, Nord, Rhône-Alpes, Seine-Maritime. The department is located in the north of France. Subdivisions
There are nine departments in France:
