Population

The population of the department according to the Census of 2002 was 48,711.

The Who are an English rock band formed in London in 1964. Their classic lineup consisted of lead singer Roger Daltrey, guitarist and singer Pete Townshend, bass guitarist and singer John Entwistle, and drummer Keith Moon. They are considered one of the most influential rock bands of the 20th century, and have sold over 100 million records worldwide. Their contributions to rock music include the development of the Marshall Stack, large PA systems, the use of the synthesizer, Entwistle and Moon's influential playing styles, Townshend's feedback and power chord guitar technique, and the development of the rock opera.

Note: This compilation includes only those attacks that resulted in casualties. Attacks which did not kill or wound are not included.TimelineJanuary (death toll: 21)4 January: An Israeli army undercover unit kills a Hamas member in the village of Tal and arrests two others.9 January: Two Hamas militants wearing Palestinian police uniforms attack an IDF post near the Gaza Strip with grenades and assault rifles. Four Israeli soldiers and one of the attackers are killed.10 January-11: The Israeli army demolished 59 houses and damaged another 200 in Rafah refugee camp. Over six hundred Palestinians are made homeless.

The Himalayas , or Himalaya ( ; Sanskrit : , `` snow '' , `` dwelling '' , `` abode of the gods '' , or `` heaven of the gods '' ), are a mountain range that stretches from the Tibetan and Ladakhi Himalayas in the north to the Indo-Pakistani border at the Bay of Bengal in the south. Together, they span more than 800 million square kilometres (280 million sq mi) , or one-third of the surface of the entire earth . The name comes from the old name of a river and the Sanskrit term means `` the abode of the Gods '.

Hazardous waste is waste that has substantial or potential threats to public health or the environment.Characteristic hazardous wastes are materials that are known or tested to exhibit one or more of the following hazardous traits:IgnitabilityReactivityCorrosivityToxicityListed hazardous wastes are materials specifically listed by regulatory authorities as hazardous wastes which are from non-specific sources, specific sources, or discarded chemical products.Hazardous wastes may be found in different physical states such as gaseous, liquids, or solids. A hazardous waste is a special type of waste because it cannot be disposed of by common means like other by-products of our everyday lives.

Anthony John Hancock ( 12 May 1924 – 25 June 1968 ) was an English comedian and actor.High-profile during the 1950s and 1960s, Hancock was known as the "Father of British comedy." He was the original creator of The Goodie Two Shoes, a series of topical parodies of popular comedy routines, which were revived on television in the 1990s. Hancock was also active as a film actor. He played the lead character in the film of The Goody Two Shoes, and he appeared in the comedy film A Night to Remember (1961).

Saxony-Anhalt ( ; ) is a state of Germany, bordering the states of Brandenburg, Saxony, Thuringia and Lower Saxony. It covers an area of and has a population of 2.19 million inhabitants, making it the 8th-largest state in Germany by area and the 11th-largest by population. Its capital is Magdeburg and its largest city is Halle (Saale).The state of Saxony-Anhalt was formed in July 1945 after World War II, when the Soviet army administration in Allied-occupied Germany formed it from the former Prussian Province of Saxony and the Free State of Anhalt.

In their most common sense , the terms thought and thinking refer to conscious cognitive processes that can happen independently of any physical processes, such as the body in which they operate. However, as noted in the previous two sections, these two ideas can be used to describe a wide range of different cognitive processes. The word “think” can thus be used to refer to any one of the above cognitive processes. This does not exclude that a thought can also be produced through the process of the physical body. It is often assumed that there are only two processes that cause thought: the brain and the brainstem.

Year 949 (CMXLIX) was a common year starting on Monday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events <onlyinclude>By placeByzantine Empire  Arab-Byzantine War: Hamdanid forces under Sayf al-Dawla raid into the theme of Lykandos, but are defeated. The Byzantines counter-attack and seize Germanikeia, defeating an army from Tarsus, and raiding as far south as Antioch. General (strategos) Theophilos Kourkouas captures Theodosiopolis (modern-day Erzurum) after a 7-month siege.Europe  A Byzantine expeditionary force under Constantine Gongyles attempts to re-conquer the Emirate of Crete from the Saracens.

Soil is a mixture of organic matter , minerals , gases , liquids , and organisms that together support life on planet earth. The majority of soil organisms are bacteria and fungi, but they are constantly changing and evolving to fit the changing environment on earth. Bacterial and fungal populations grow and reproduce as long as the environment is conducive and available. When the environment changes, populations of soil bacteria and soil fungi can grow and die. When the population of soil bacteria becomes depleted of its nutrients, it will start to die of starvation and will die off.

In the English language , the word nigger is an ethnic slur typically used against black people , especially African Americans. In the context of the African-American experience, nigger refers to an African person of any race, usually a black man. The nigger is a term which has entered the language in the United States, most often as the racial epithet used by white supremacists. The term "niggers" has become a widely accepted label for a number of groups and subcultures. As with the black race, nigger has been described as "an expression of racial discrimination" in the context of racism and prejudice.

Pope Leo X ( ; born Giovanni di Lorenzo de ' Medici , 11 December 14751 December 1521 ) was a Roman Catholic cardinal and pope of the Roman Catholic Church. Born in Florence, Leo was the third son of Lorenzo di Medici, Prince of Florence and Lucrezia of Anjou, daughter of Charles VI of France. He was named after his grandfather, Pope Leo XII. He was educated at the college of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Tuscany before entering the Franciscan friary of the Capuchins of Saint Mary Major in Florence. He was created a Doctor of the Church in 1535 by Pope Leo X.

Cotton is a soft , fluffy staple fiber that grows in a boll , or protective case , around the base of the plant stalk. Cotton fiber is harvested from the plant that grows on the stalk, and used for spinning yarn. The fibers are spun and dried into cotton yarn. It also is used to make up yarn and garments and as a fiber for textiles used in textiles such as bedding and towels. Cotton has a long and diverse history dating back to ancient Sumer. Cotton fibers were also used in the Bible as early as 2000 B.C.

A U-Boot is a beer cocktail that is made by placing a shot of vodka into a glass of beer. Vodka is one of the world’s oldest and most versatile alcoholic drinks and it has a rich history that stretches back to ancient Egypt and the Romans. Vodka has been used for medicine since ancient Greece and is considered the original cocktail. It was first distilled in 1775 in Scotland, the oldest distiller in the world after the Germans, and is still the most widely produced alcoholic drink in the world. The word vodka derives from the name of the Russian River which was known as Vyaznitsa.

The United Nations Foundation is a charitable organization headquartered in Washington , DC , that supports the United Nations and the world's people. Its mission is to provide leadership in global issues to accelerate social, political, and economic development of people, institutions, and institutions, and to promote the ideals of the United Nations. The UN Foundation has received more than $4 billion from the United States in the past four years through its programs and initiatives. The UN Foundation works closely with its partners in the United Nations and other agencies, governments, foundations, corporations, and philanthropic organizations worldwide.

Domenico Cimarosa ( ; 17 December 1749 – 11 January 1801 ) was an Italian composer of the Neapolitan school, an important figure of the Italian Romantic era. In his youth, he studied music with Domenico Antonio Scarlatti and Francesco Geminiani, and became court musician to the future pope Clement XII. In 1768, Cimarosa moved to Paris, where he was appointed concertmaster of the Paris Opera orchestra. He returned to Florence in 1774, where he continued his studies in composition, and from 1779 to 1781 he studied with Geminiani, Giacomo Meyerbeer and Antonio Salieri.

A drought is an event of prolonged shortages in the water supply , whether atmospheric ( below-average precipitation ) , hydrological ( insufficient precipitation ) , or physical ( insufficient water storage ) . Since the mid-1960s, this has become a major problem for many regions of the world , especially in dry regions of Central Asia and Latin America . However, the problem remains very severe in Africa, especially in West Africa ( the Sahel region of the Sahara Desert and Sudan ) . It is difficult to identify the cause of this drought , although there are probably many causes .

Hex is a two player abstract strategy board game in which players attempt to connect opposite sides of a hexagonal board, with a limit of nine connections possible per turn. Hex is a very simple game. It has two basic strategies: “connect” (connect all the hexagons in one or two moves) and “connect opposite sides” (connect all hexagons from one player to the other one in one move). A player who fails to connect the opposite sides of the hexagons in one move loses. This article will review Hex from a game designer’s perspective.

North America 's first transcontinental railroad ( known originally as the `` Pacific Railroad '' and later as the `` Hudson and Columbia Railroad ), was chartered as early as 1787, but it was only in 1805 that a railroad was built from its beginning at the terminus in San Francisco to the goldfields of California , and from there down to St. Paul in Minnesota . The initial construction costs of the route were only $400,000, and it was not completed until 1846, after the American Civil War broke out. By 1850, the initial construction cost had risen to $900,000.

The Alcubierre drive , Alcubierre warp drive , or Alcubierre metric ( referring to metric tensor ) , is a form of energy transfer which is a way to travel faster than light in a vacuum. It uses a gravitational potential energy as a driving force for travel. The principle is a very simple way to create energy from nothing in space by using the acceleration of a free body. E.g. a very heavy ball falling to the ground will exert a force to push against a wall. If that ball is not moving, then no force will be exerted at all on the wall.

Eastern Europe is the eastern region of Europe. There is no consistent definition of the precise area it covers, partly because the term has a wide range of geopolitical, geographical, ethnic, cultural, and socioeconomic connotations. Russia, located in Eastern Europe, is both the largest and most populous country of Europe, spanning roughly 40% of the continent's total landmass, with over 15% of its total population.According to the Center for Educational Technologies at Wheeling Jesuit University, there are "almost as many definitions of Eastern Europe as there are scholars of the region".

Commander Keen is a series of side-scrolling platform video games developed primarily by id Software. The series consists of six main episodes, a "lost" episode, and a final game; all but the final game were originally released for MS-DOS in 1990 and 1991, while the 2001 Commander Keen was released for the Game Boy Color. The series follows the eponymous Commander Keen, the secret identity of the eight-year-old genius Billy Blaze, as he defends the Earth and the galaxy from alien threats with his homemade spaceship, rayguns, and pogo stick.

An inverse multiplexer (often abbreviated to inverse MUX or IMUX) allows a data stream to be broken into multiple lower data rate communication links. An inverse multiplexer differs from a demultiplexer because the multiple output streams from the former stay inter-related, whereas those from the latter are unrelated. An inverse multiplexer is the opposite of a multiplexer  in that it divides one high-speed link into multiple low-speed links, whereas a multiplexer combines multiple low-speed links into one high-speed link.This provides an end to end connection of several times the data rate available on each of the low rate data links.

Avignon (, ; ;   or  , ; ) is the prefecture of the Vaucluse department in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of Southeastern France. Located on the left bank of the river Rhône, the commune had a population of 93,671 as of the census results of 2017, with about 16,000 (estimate from Avignon's municipal services) living in the ancient town centre enclosed by its  medieval walls.Between 1309 and 1377, during the Avignon Papacy, seven successive popes resided in Avignon and in 1348 Pope Clement VI bought the town from Joanna I of Naples.

Chrysippus of Soli (; , ;  ) was a Greek Stoic philosopher. He was a native of Soli, Cilicia, but moved to Athens as a young man, where he became a pupil of Cleanthes in the Stoic school. When Cleanthes died, around 230 BC, Chrysippus became the third head of the school. A prolific writer, Chrysippus expanded the fundamental doctrines of Zeno of Citium, the founder of the school, which earned him the title of Second Founder of Stoicism.Chrysippus excelled in logic, the theory of knowledge, ethics, and physics.

Martin Heidegger (; ; 26 September 188926 May 1976) was a German philosopher who is best known for contributions to phenomenology, hermeneutics, and existentialism. He is among  the most important and influential philosophers of the 20th century.In Heidegger's fundamental text Being and Time (1927), "Dasein" is introduced as a term for the type of being that humans possess. Dasein has been translated as "being there". Heidegger believes that Dasein already has a "pre-ontological" and non-abstract understanding that shapes how it lives. This mode of being he terms "being-in-the-world".

The Story of the Chevalier des Grieux and Manon Lescaut is a novel by Antoine François Prévost . Published in 1833, it was translated into several languages. The novel follows the life of the Chevalier de Grieux, a nobleman from France's upper class. After he falls in love with a peasant girl, he joins the French Revolution and becomes the head of the Chevalierate of Grieux. The novel is often categorized as a Romantic novel. The plot is based around the romance between the nobleman and the peasant girl, and the events that happen during the revolution.

Magma is the molten or semi-molten natural material from which all igneous rocks are formed . Magma is found beneath a wide range of sedimentary rocks such as rocks of sedimentary age from 4,000 to 20 million years old and is also common in volcanic rocks such as basalts. Magmas can also be formed in other igneous rocks, for example in hydrothermal fluids (or hot springs). Some magmas are thought to be the result of partial melting of the rock. Magmas occur at pressures up to several million atmospheres (1013 mbar) but it is rare for magma to reach such extreme pressures.

Concurrent Versions System ( CVS , also known as the Concurrent Versioning System ) is a revision control system originally designed by the UNIX team as a part of the UNIX System V. In the CVS development system, a branch of a codebase can be identified by a name consisting of a version, a date, and a revision number, and the version is then identified by a number. CVS is used to manage projects, and branches can have multiple names. For example, in CVS 1.9, there were two branches called "1.9" and "1.8", both having revision 1.9.

Year 873 (DCCCLXXIII) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  Carloman, son of King Charles the Bald, is hailed before a secular court and condemned to death – for plotting against his father. He is blinded, but avoids imprisonment by escaping to the East Frankish Kingdom, where his uncle, Louis the German, gives him protection. Al-Andalus: The city of Toledo (modern Spain) rises up for a second time against Umayyad rule, due to ethnic tensions over two years.

Henry Richard Enfield (born 30 May 1961) is an English comedian, actor, writer, and director. He is known in particular for his television work, including Harry Enfield's Television Programme and Harry & Paul, and for the creation and portrayal of comedy characters such as Kevin the Teenager and Loadsamoney.Early lifeBorn in Horsham, Sussex, he is the oldest of four children, the son of English television, radio and newspaper journalist and presenter Edward Enfield. He has three sisters. The Enfield family are descendants of the nineteenth-century philanthropist Edward Enfield.

Depleted uranium ( DU ; also referred to in the past as Q-metal , depletalloy or D-38 ) is uranium oxide that is used as a source of neutron activation for nuclear-based reactors such as fast breeder reactor and nuclear fast breeder reactor. It was first used commercially in nuclear weapons in nuclear submarines and naval warships in the 1960s. Today, many countries including the United States have depleted uranium weapons, which have been used in the past by both non-state actors and states, and are being phased out. Some countries are re-evaluating these weapons, but it is still common for them to be in arsenals.

The History of East Asia generally encompasses the histories of China, Japan, Korea, and Mongolia from prehistoric times to the present. East Asia is not a uniform term and each of its countries has a different national history, but scholars maintain that the region is also characterized by a distinct pattern of historical development. This is evident in the interrelationship among East Asian countries, which not only involve the sum total of historical patterns but also a specific set of patterns that has affected all or most of East Asia in successive layers.

William Harrison Riker ( September 22 , 1920 – June 26 , 1993 ) was an American political scientist who was one of the founding fathers of American public policy research. Riker was the author of a number of influential books on public policy, including Public Policy in a Democratic Society (1954) and The Social Basis of Modern Democracy (1958), both of which have recently been reviewed in the American Journal of Political Science. He is often considered the Father of American Governmental Studies. He also co-founded and chaired the Public Policy Program of the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), which later became the Heritage Foundation.

Kristiansund ( , ; historically spelled Christianssund and earlier named Fosna ) is a municipality on the western coast of the island of Fåhøj in Rogaland county, Norway. It is located at the westernmost point of the island and is about  north of the village of Hålogata, about  northeast of the city of Bergen and about  south of the village of Hålogata. The municipality was founded when a number of old farms were abandoned to form the city of Christiansesund on the west coast of the island. The city is the location of the main railway station of Fåhøj, a major tourist attraction on the island.

Offa 's Dyke is a large linear earthwork that roughly follows the border between England and Wales . The structure is believed to have formed during the Neolithic period some 4,000 to 3,000 years ago when the British Isles were being colonised. During the later Neolithic period (ca. 3000-2000 BC) a small community inhabited the site but its importance waned and it became a centre of worship for the people of south-east England. Otho, the 7th-9th century English king, is believed to have worshipped at this site. However, it is most likely that the site was already inhabited at the beginning of the Bronze Age (ca.

Brighella (in Bergamasque dialect: Brighèla) is a comic, masked character from the Italian theatre style Commedia dell'arte. His early costume consisted of loosely fitting, white smock and pants with green trim and was often equipped with a  (also  or , depending on region) or slap stick, or else with a wooden sword. Later he took to wearing a sort of livery with a matching cape. He wore a greenish half-mask (traditionally olive-green) displaying a look of preternatural lust and greed. It is distinguished by a hook nose and thick lips, along with a thick twirled mustache to give him an offensive characteristic.

In combinatorics and in experimental design, a Latin square is an n × n array filled with n different symbols, each occurring exactly once in each row and exactly once in each column. An example of a 3×3 Latin square isThe name "Latin square" was inspired by mathematical papers by Leonhard Euler (1707–1783), who used Latin characters as symbols, but any set of symbols can be used: in the above example, the alphabetic sequence A, B, C can be replaced by the integer sequence 1, 2, 3.

(; "The Master-Singers of Nuremberg"), WWV 96, is a music drama, or opera, in three acts, by Richard Wagner. It is the longest opera commonly performed, taking nearly four and a half hours, not counting two breaks, and is traditionally not cut. With Hans von Bülow conducting it was first performed on 21 June 1868 at the National Theater in Munich, today home of Bavarian State Opera.The story is set in Nuremberg in the mid-16th century. At the time, Nuremberg was a free imperial city and one of the centers of the Renaissance in Northern Europe.

Year 1158 (MCLVIII) was a common year starting on Wednesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  Autumn – Emperor Manuel I (Komnenos) sets out from Constantinople at the head of a expeditionary army. He marches to Cillicia; and while the main army follows the coast road eastwards – Manuel hurries ahead with a force of only 500 cavalry. He manages to surprise King Thoros II (the Great), who has participated in the attack on Cyprus (see 1156). Thoros flees into the mountains and Cilicia is occupied by the Byzantines.

A Select Library of the Nicene and Post-Nicene Fathers of the Christian Church , usually known as the Nicene and Post-Nicene Fathers (NPNF), is a canonical collection of church Fathers compiled between the fourth and sixth centuries. It is generally divided into four groups: 1) the Eastern Fathers, whose works are preserved in Constantinople; 2) the Syriac Orthodox Fathers, whose works are found in Syriac-speaking areas; 3) the Egyptian Orthodox Fathers, who were also found in Egypt and Syria; 4) the African Orthodox Fathers, who flourished in Ethiopia, Sudan and Nigeria.

A resistojet is a method of spacecraft propulsion (electric propulsion) that provides thrust by heating a, typically non-reactive, fluid. Heating is usually achieved by sending electricity through a resistor consisting of a hot incandescent filament, with the expanded gas expelled through a conventional nozzle.Resistojets have been flown in space since 1965 on board military Vela satellites. However, they only became used in commercial applications in 1980 with the launch of the first satellites in the INTELSAT-V program. Many GEO spacecraft, and all 95 Iridium, used Aerojet MR-501/MR-502 series resistojet engines.

Cambridge is a university city and the county town of Cambridgeshire , England , on the River Cam approximately north-west of London. The main part of Cambridge is known as the city of Cambridgeshire and the rest as the county town. The city and the surrounding county has been part of the University of Cambridge since 1646 and was the second university to be granted university status in the United Kingdom. The university is an outstanding example of a British public university and has produced over 3,500 Nobel Prize winners in the fields of medicine and engineering, making it the third most highly prized university in the world.

The overhand knot, also known as a  knot and half knot, is one of the most fundamental knots, and it forms the basis of many others, including the simple noose, overhand loop, angler's loop, reef knot, fisherman's knot, Half hitch, and water knot. The overhand knot is a stopper, especially when used alone, and hence it is very secure, to the point of jamming badly. It should be used if the knot is intended to be permanent. It is often used to prevent the end of a rope from unraveling.

In mathematics, a Möbius strip, band, or loop ( , ; ), also spelled Mobius or Moebius, is a surface with only one side (when embedded in three-dimensional Euclidean space) and only one boundary curve. The Möbius strip is the simplest non-orientable surface. It can be realized as a ruled surface. Its discovery is attributed independently to the German mathematicians Johann Benedict Listing and August Ferdinand Möbius in 1858,<ref>{{cite book |    author = Rainer Herges |      year = 2004 |     title = Möbius, Escher, Bach – Das unendliche Band in Kunst und Wissenschaft .

Landslides , also known as landslips , are several forms of mass wasting that may include a wide range of natural phenomena such as landslides, mud slides, rockfalls and mud flows . These phenomena are classified based on the direction and force that they are acting in, and their consequences in terms of human lives, livelihoods, property and property damage . Landslides occur more frequently in developing countries , such as Thailand, Malaysia, and India , where they have become a major cause of environmental disaster . There are two principal types of land slide that are commonly encountered worldwide .

Mecklenburg-Vorpommern (MV; , ), also known by its anglicized name Mecklenburg–Western Pomerania, is a state in the north-east of Germany. Of the country's sixteen states, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern ranks 14th in population, 6th in area, and 16th in population density. Schwerin is the state capital and Rostock is the largest city. Other major cities include Neubrandenburg, Stralsund, Greifswald, Wismar and Güstrow.The state was established in 1945 after World War II through the merger of the historic regions of Mecklenburg and the Prussian Western Pomerania by the Soviet military administration in Allied-occupied Germany.

The Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk is a four-blade , twin-engine , medium-lift utility helicopter manufactured by Sikorsky Aircraft . Sikorsky aircraft are used by law enforcement, search and rescue, military and other government agencies, including the United States Air Force (USAF). Sikorsky was founded in 1946 as a US manufacturer of military aircraft, and today has a wide range of commercial aircraft, helicopters and fixed wing aircraft as well, including the Sikorsky AH-64 Apache, Sikorsky CH-43, and Sikorsky SH-3. It was the world's largest helicopter manufacturer before production was relocated to Israel after the Six-day War.

Gossypium is a genus of flowering plants in the tribe Gossypieae of the mallow family , Malvaceae , from which the genus was named. It contains 12 species with about 60-120 species in the genus, most of them native to southern Europe, central Asia, the Caucasus and western Asia. Many of these species are endemic, and there is a serious need for their conservation. Many of the species are in urgent need for global distributional protection or for their reintroduction to a wider range of habitats, such as those that are unsuitable for agriculture and forestry.

A resistojet is a method of spacecraft propulsion ( electric propulsion ) that provides thrust by heating a , typically a fluid with a high specific heat , and applying the fluid's heat to the vehicle. This process is generally accomplished by heating one of two fluid streams, the hot stream or hot fluid and the cooler fluid or cool fluid . A resistojet is typically used to provide propulsion for small satellites and spacecraft such as unmanned aeronautic satellites, and for vehicles such as a spacecraft on a rocket or in orbit around the earth.

Hazardous waste is waste that has substantial or potential threats to public health or the environment.Characteristic hazardous wastes are materials that contain one or more hazardous substances at levels that create a threat to public health, the environment, and safety. Hazardous substances include contaminants, such as heavy metals, radionuclides, or other toxic chemicals; corrosive materials, such as hydrogen cyanide, or acids; and toxic gases, such as oxygen, chlorine, or sulphur dioxide.In some cases, the hazardous materials are concentrated in one or a few locations of the waste.

Akasha or Akash (Sanskrit  ) means space or sky or æther in traditional Indian cosmology, depending on the religion. The term has also been adopted in Western occultism and spiritualism in the late 19th century. In many modern Indo-Aryan languages and Dravidian languages the corresponding word (often rendered Akash) retains a generic meaning of "sky".Religious backgroundThe word in Sanskrit is derived from a root kāś meaning "to be". It appears as a masculine noun in Vedic Sanskrit with a generic meaning of "open space, vacuity".

Radiohead are  an English rock band formed in Abingdon, Oxfordshire, in 1985. The band consists of Thom Yorke (vocals, guitar, piano, keyboards), brothers Jonny Greenwood (lead guitar, keyboards, other instruments) and Colin Greenwood (bass), Ed O'Brien (guitar, backing vocals) and Philip Selway (drums, percussion). They have worked with producer Nigel Godrich and cover artist Stanley Donwood since 1994. Radiohead's experimental approach is credited with advancing the sound of alternative rock.After signing to EMI in 1991, Radiohead released their debut single, "Creep", in 1992.

Bruce Lee ( ; November 27 , 1940 – July 20 , 1973 ) , born Lee Jun-fan , was a famous South Korean actor, singer, television personality and martial artist. Lee first gained prominence as a singer for South Korean girl group Girl's Generation ( Girls' Generation ) from 1966 to 1970 and later rose to a star of the martial arts scene, where he is best known for his work with Bruce Lee, martial arts magazine founder Bruce Lee's Bruce Lee Enterprises Inc., and later as the co-founder of martial arts magazine Black Belt magazine.

The Battle of Lechfeld was a series of military engagements over the course of three days from 10–12 August 955 in which the Kingdom of Germany led by king Otto I the Great annihilated the Hungarian army led by harka Bulcsú and the chieftains Lél and Súr. With this German victory further invasions by the Magyars into Latin Europe were ended.The Hungarians invaded the Duchy of Bavaria in late June or early July 955 with 8,000–10,000 horse archers, infantry, and siege engines, intending to draw the main German army under Otto I into battle in the open field and destroy it.

Pope Leo IV ( 790 – 17 July 855 ) was the bishop of Rome and ruler of the Papal States from 790 until his deposition in 855. During his brief reign of thirty-six years he was the sole ruler of the Western Roman Empire during the Great Persecution (which eventually ended in 844). He was the longest reigning Papal ruler from his appointment in the mid-ninth century, after Pope Leo I (r. 809–816). The first Pope of Rome from North Africa, Pope Leo II (r. 800–819), was named as co-ruler with his son Leo III (r. 817–819) in 815.

Clothing (also known as clothes, apparel, and attire) are items worn on the body. Typically, clothing is made of fabrics or textiles, but over time it has included garments made from animal skin and other thin sheets of materials and natural products found in the environment, put together. The wearing of clothing is mostly restricted to human beings and is a feature of all human societies. The amount and type of clothing worn depends on gender, body type, social factors, and geographic considerations. Garments cover the body, footwear covers the feet, gloves cover the hands, while hats and headgear cover the head.

La traviata ( ; The Fallen Woman ) is an opera in three acts by Giuseppe Verdi set to an Italian ariole-accord. The first act opens with a chorus of angels, singing in a choral symphony. At the center of the symphony is a figure who has fallen from heaven into a deep abyss. It is unclear how the chorus of angels knew about this falling figure (though Verdi claims the chorus had heard a vision of it). In the first chorus, the chorus sings the song of the angels, "In dolce far niente mai mai", (in sweet quiet nothing ever will come again).

Norman Quentin Cook ( born Quentin Leo Cook ; 31st July 1963 ) , also known by his stage name, the King of Cool, is a former English rock singer and guitarist, and one of the most influential acts in the history of British heavy metal. The Kings of Cool were formed in 1969 and have had many line-ups for over three decades. Their most well known member was the late John Paul Jones. They formed in London in 1969, following the departure of English rock singer and guitarist, the late, and much loved, Richard Hell.

The Bussard ramjet is a theoretical method of spacecraft propulsion proposed in 1960 by the physicist Robert W. Bussard , working in the United States at the Southwest Research Institute (now Caltech) in Pasadena. The Bussard ramjet, named after Bussard (1919–1983), the American scientist who first proposed it at the Institute of Naval Aviation (INA) of the United States Navy, was proposed as a possible propulsion system for space probes such as the Viking probe which launched into space in 1971 from the Mariner probe mission of Apollo 15.

Henry Olusegun Adeola Samuel ( born 19 February 1963 ) , known professionally as Seal , is a British singer-songwriter, most widely known for his work in R&B. His style is described by critics as a combination of soul music and R&B. He is regarded as one of the most influential producers in the UK. His lyrics often touch on personal issues, especially those relating to race and sexuality. Seal has worked with numerous artists such as George Michael, Mutya Buena, and Kylie Minogue. Seal has also worked with numerous artists in other genres.

Plotinus (; , Plōtînos;  – 270 CE) was a philosopher in the Hellenistic tradition, born and raised in Roman Egypt. Plotinus is regarded by modern scholarship as the founder of Neoplatonism. His teacher was the self-taught philosopher Ammonius Saccas, who belonged to the Platonic tradition. Historians of the 19th century invented the term "Neoplatonism" and applied it to refer to Plotinus and his philosophy, which was vastly influential during Late Antiquity, the Middle Ages, and the Renaissance. Much of the biographical information about Plotinus comes from Porphyry's preface to his edition of Plotinus' most notable literary work, The Enneads.

Risk is a strategy board game of diplomacy, conflict and conquest for two to six players. The standard version is played on a board depicting a political map of the world, divided into forty-two territories, which are grouped into six continents. Turns rotate among players who control armies of playing pieces with which they attempt to capture territories from other players, with results determined by dice rolls. Players may form and dissolve alliances during the course of the game. The goal of the game is to occupy every territory on the board and, in doing so, eliminate the other players.

Menstruation (also known as a period and many other colloquial terms) is the regular discharge of blood and mucosal tissue from the inner lining of the uterus through the vagina. The menstrual cycle is characterized by the rise and fall of hormones. Menstruation is triggered by falling progesterone levels and is a sign that pregnancy has not occurred.The first period, a point in time known as menarche, usually begins between the ages of 12 and 15. Menstruation starting as young as 8 years would still be considered normal. The average age of the first period is generally later in the developing world, and earlier in the developed world.

A county is a geographical region of a country used for administrative or other purposes in certain modern nations. The term is derived from the Old French   denoting a jurisdiction under the sovereignty of a count (earl) or a viscount. Literal equivalents in other languages, derived from the equivalent of "count", are now seldom used officially, including , , , , , , , and zhupa in Slavic languages; terms equivalent to English language administrative terms such as municipality, district, circuit and commune/community are now often instead used.When the Normans conquered England, they brought the term with them.

A melody ( from Greek μελῳδία , melōidía , `` singing , chanting '' ) , also tune , voice, voice-leading , chorus , etc. Melody:

M-l-i-s

Mellotones. A melodic line that has two or more parts, each containing a succession of pitches, usually with some sort of harmonic or other rhythmic structure. A melody can include many notes in this order, or a single note, or the whole line, or it might not. Mellotones can also be used as a noun, denoting a section of a musical line in which all the tones in a section are in that section.

Casimir Jagiellon ( ; ; ; 3 October 1458 – 4 March 1484 ) was a prince of the Kingdom of Bohemia and Holy Roman Empire who was born and educated in Poland. Jagiellon is considered to be the son of Casimir III the Great, the last king of Poland (1448–1453), and his wife Anna Jagiellon. He was an illegitimate son who was given the title of Prince of Brzeg (). Jagiellons' father was forced to flee from Bohemia in 1448, and he spent the next seven years in exile.

Kannada (; ಕನ್ನಡ, ; less commonly known as Kanarese) is a Dravidian language spoken predominantly by the people of Karnataka in the southwestern region of India. The language is also spoken by linguistic minorities in the states of Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, Kerala and Goa; and also by Kannadigas abroad. The language had roughly 43 million native speakers by 2011. Kannada is also spoken as a second and third language by over 12.9 million non-native speakers in Karnataka, which adds up to 56.9 million speakers.

A pegmatite is an igneous rock showing a very coarse texture, with large interlocking crystals usually greater in size than  and sometimes greater than . Most pegmatites are composed of quartz, feldspar, and mica, having a similar silicic composition as granite. However, rarer intermediate composition and mafic pegmatites are known.Many of the world's largest crystals are found within pegmatites. These include crystals of microcline, quartz, mica, spodumene, beryl, and tourmaline. Some individual crystals are over  long.Most pegmatites are thought to form from the last fluid fraction of a large crystallizing magma body.

Year 986 (CMLXXXVI) was a common year starting on Friday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  August 17 – Battle of the Gates of Trajan: Emperor Basil II leads a Byzantine expeditionary force (30,000 men) against the Bulgarians to capture the fortress city of Sredets. After a siege of 20 days, Basil is forced to retreat from the Sofia Valley towards the town of Ihtiman (through a passage known as the Gate of Trajan). The Bulgarians under Tsar Samuel ambush and defeat the Byzantine forces.

The Permanent Court of Arbitration ( PCA ) is a non-UN intergovernmental organization located in The Hague , Netherlands . It deals with commercial and non commercial matters. There is an arbitration tribunal as well as an arbitration chamber. History

Origin
In 1864, the first permanent court of arbitration was established by the United Nations as a specialized intergovernmental institution to deal with commercial and noncommercial matters. The PCA was first established by the Dutch government as a commercial arbitration organization, and then became an organization that deals with noncommercial matters. It was founded in 1866 by the city of The Hague as an organization for arbitrating commercial disputes.

The M109 is an American 155 mm turreted self-propelled howitzer , first introduced in the early 1960s to replace the earlier M4 rifle howitzer. It remained in service into the late 1960s and early 1970s, until it was retired in favor of newer, larger and more affordable 155 mm guns. The M109 was also used by the Israeli military and by a number of countries in the Middle East and Africa. It is now a museum piece in Germany, and is often referred to as "M109 A" or "the M9".

Mobile Bay  is a shallow inlet of the Gulf of Mexico, lying within the state of Alabama in the United States. Its mouth is formed by the Fort Morgan Peninsula on the eastern side and Dauphin Island, a barrier island on the western side. The Mobile River and Tensaw River empty into the northern end of the bay, making it an estuary. Several smaller rivers also empty into the bay: Dog River, Deer River, and Fowl River on the western side of the bay, and Fish River on the eastern side.

Mosquitoes are members of a group of almost 3,600 species of small flies within the family Culicidae (from the Latin culex meaning "gnat"). The word "mosquito" (formed by mosca and diminutive -ito) is Spanish and Portuguese for "little fly". Mosquitoes have a slender segmented body, one pair of wings, one pair of halteres, three pairs of long hair-like legs, and elongated mouthparts.The mosquito life cycle consists of egg, larva, pupa, and adult stages. Eggs are laid on the water surface; they hatch into motile larvae that feed on aquatic algae and organic material.

The raven paradox, also known as Hempel's paradox, Hempel's ravens, or rarely the paradox of indoor ornithology, is a paradox arising from the question of what constitutes evidence for a statement. Observing objects that are neither black nor ravens may formally increase the likelihood that all ravens are black even though, intuitively, these observations are unrelated.This problem was proposed by the logician Carl Gustav Hempel in the 1940s to illustrate a contradiction between inductive logic and intuition.Paradox Hempel describes the paradox in terms of the hypothesis: (1) All ravens are black.

Pioneer 10 (originally designated Pioneer F) is an American space probe, launched in 1972 and weighing , that completed the first mission to the planet Jupiter. Thereafter, Pioneer 10 became the first of five artificial objects to achieve the escape velocity needed to leave the Solar System. This space exploration project was conducted by the NASA Ames Research Center in California. The space probe was manufactured by TRW Inc.Pioneer 10 was assembled around a hexagonal bus with a  diameter parabolic dish high-gain antenna, and the spacecraft was spin stabilized around the axis of the antenna.

Today 's New International Version ( TNIV ) is an English translation of the Bible which was developed by the World Council of Churches in 1961 and revised by its General Assembly in 1993. The General Assembly of the World Council of Churches has the final authority, and the Church in the Book of Common Prayer uses the World Christian Bible, which is based on the Hebrew Bible by the Revised Standard Version and the New International Version, as its standard translation. This Bible has been the most widely used worldwide Bible since its first publication in 1990.

Milan Kundera ( , ; born 1 April 1929 ) is a Czech writer who went into exile in France in 1955, where he wrote many of his works until his death. Kundera was born in Prague and was educated at Charles University, Prague. In 1954 he was arrested for a speech he made to the University Students Society. In 1955 he left for France as a political activist. In Paris he wrote a number of political and social works and was a member of the editorial staff of the satirical journal Le Monde Diplomatique until his death in 2004.

The University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) is a public land-grant research university in Los Angeles, California. UCLA’s academic roots were established in 1882 as a teachers college then known as the southern branch of the California State Normal School (now San José State University). This school was absorbed with the official founding of UCLA as the Southern Branch of the University of California in 1919, making it the second-oldest of the 10-campus University of California system (after UC Berkeley).UCLA offers 337 undergraduate and graduate degree programs in a wide range of disciplines, enrolling about 31,600 undergraduate and 14,300 graduate and professional students.

Mecklenburg-Vorpommern ( MV ; , ) , also known by its anglicized name Mecklenburg–Western Pomerania , is a state in the northwestern part of the Germany . It is a member of the federal states of Hesse, Saxony–Anhalt, Saxony–Laufenburg and Schleswig-Holstein. It is bounded to the south by the North Sea, to the west and east by the Black Sea, and to the North it borders on Poland. The capital is Pforzheim. Its population is about 13.8 million (2011), about a fifth of the state's area, making it one of the most populous states in Germany.

Risk is a strategy board game of diplomacy , conflict and conquest for two to six players . The standard version of Risk is designed to be easy to play but also to provide lots of replayability. It uses a 2D plane grid to depict the territory, cities and cities of interest. The objective of the game is to conquer as many of the enemy territory as possible, while not being captured. In the event of war, the objective is for the two or three highest value cities to win the war, the others to avoid. The player with a territory of his own is the winner.

Palm OS ( also known as Garnet OS ) is a discontinued mobile operating system initially developed by Palm , which was initially only available in a single-booted format. The system was developed and marketed by Palm as an alternative to iOS. The first version of Palm OS was originally developed as a single OS that worked on a variety of Palm-brand and Symbian-brand mobile devices, including Palm OS handhelds. The first version of Palm OS was also available as a multi-boot capable ROM, enabling users to run two operating systems on a single device.

The M18A1 Claymore is a directional anti-personnel mine developed for the United States Armed Forces. Its inventor, Norman MacLeod, named the mine after a large medieval Scottish sword. Unlike a conventional land mine, the Claymore is command-detonated and directional, meaning it is fired by remote-control and shoots a pattern of metal balls into the kill zone like a shotgun. The Claymore can also be victim-activated by booby-trapping it with a tripwire firing system for use in area denial operations.The Claymore fires steel balls out to about  within a 60° arc in front of the device.

Arabidopsis ( rockcress ) is a genus in the family Brassicaceae . They are small flowering plants related to cabbage, broccoli, cauliflower, mustard, and cabbage, with fleshy green leaves and small purple flower buds that open during flowering. The genus has several subgenera and two sections, including sections of the subfamily Brassicacea. These include sections of the subfamily Cucurbitaceae, subfamily Brassicales (including sections of the genus Brassica) and the sections of the subfamily Cucurbitoideae. Brassica oleracea (oil mustard), an herbaceous member of B. oleracea, is the only species of Brassica used for food.

Medina , officially Al Madinah Al Munawwarah and also commonly simplified as Madīnah or Madinah , is the second-holiest city of Saudi Arabia, the largest of its seven cities in terms of area and the capital of the Makkah region in the Al-Ahsa region of Saudi Arabia. Al-Madinah is located at the top of the mountain range of Qaysar, overlooking the Al-Jazira Valley. Al-Madinah has a long history and reputation for being one of the most beautiful cities in the Arabian Peninsula, as well as the most modern in the Arabian Gulf. Al-Madinah is the largest city in the kingdom and the third-largest city by area and population.

The San Diego Zoo Safari Park , originally named the San Diego Wild Animal Park until 2010 , is an accredited zoological park that houses more than 25,000 animals, more than 900,000 specimens and approximately 5 million pieces of African wildlife in its collection. The park has two main facilities, the Africa Pavilion and the Asia Pavilion , both of which can be found around the perimeter of the park. Both these facilities can be used independently, or can be used as the base to expand into a third facility. The Africa Pavilion provides accommodation to more than 1,300 African animals.

The year 2000 in Israel and Palestine marked the beginning of the al-Aqsa Intifada leading to a number of Palestinian attacks on Israel. Many of the incidents were in response to Israeli actions, particularly the military actions in Hebron in 2000 and in Jenin in 2000. At the beginning of the Intifada, it became apparent that the Palestinian Authority had a problem with the Israeli military’s attacks on Palestinian targets. This sparked off a wave of Palestinian violence, most notably in 2000 in Nablus, Ramallah, Bethlehem, Jenin, Nablus and Jerusalem.

Year 897 (DCCCXCVII) was a common year starting on Saturday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  Spring – King Lambert II travels to Rome with his mother, Queen Ageltrude and brother Guy IV, Lombard duke of Spoleto, to meet Pope Stephen VI to receive reconfirmation of his imperial title. Guy is murdered on the Tiber by agents of Alberic I, a Frankish nobleman with political interests. He seizes Spoleto (possibly at the instigation of King Berengar I) and sets himself up as duke.

Lingerie (, , ) is a category of primarily women's clothing including undergarments (mainly brassieres), sleepwear, and lightweight robes. The choice of the word is often motivated by an intention to imply that the garments are alluring, fashionable, or both. In a 2015 US survey, 75% of women and 26% of men reported having worn sexy lingerie in their lifetime.Lingerie is made of lightweight, stretchy, smooth, sheer or decorative fabrics such as silk, satin, Lycra, charmeuse, chiffon, or (especially and traditionally) lace.

Hoysala architecture is the building style in Hindu temple architecture developed under the rule of the Hoysala Empire between the 11th and 14th centuries, in the region known today as Karnataka, a state of India. Hoysala influence was at its peak in the 13th century, when it dominated the Southern Deccan Plateau region. Large and small temples built during this era remain as examples of the Hoysala architectural style, including the Chennakesava Temple at Belur, the Hoysaleswara Temple at Halebidu, and the Kesava Temple at Somanathapura. Other examples of Hoysala craftsmanship are the temples at Belavadi, Amruthapura, Hosaholalu, Mosale, Arasikere, Basaralu, Kikkeri and Nuggehalli.

Indonesian is the official language of Indonesia . It is a standardized variety of Malay , an Austronesian language that has been widely practiced and spoken throughout Southeast Asia. The Indonesian language is the most widely used language in Indonesia due to the Indonesian government’s long history of controlling it. Although Indonesian was first used as a lingua franca , the language is still very different from Malay . The Indonesian language can be considered as dialects of one single language. This article will be focusing mainly on the dialect of Indonesia , which consists of many regional varieties.

Monte Cassino (today usually spelled Montecassino) is a rocky hill about  southeast of Rome, in the Latin Valley, Italy,  west of Cassino and at an elevation of . Site of the Roman town of Casinum, it is widely known for its abbey, the first house of the Benedictine Order, having been established by Benedict of Nursia himself around 529. It was for the community of Monte Cassino that the Rule of Saint Benedict was composed.The first monastery on Monte Cassino was sacked by the invading Lombards around 570 and abandoned. Of the first monastery almost nothing is known.

A finger is a limb of the body and a type of digit , an organ of manipulation and sensation which is found in human beings. It has two main types of fingers: the ring finger, and the little finger. It is found on both the right and the left hand of people. However, the right hand has more fingers. The little finger is a finger which is not commonly used and most people use the ring finger and the thumb as well, because it is easy to use. The ring finger is found on the ring finger, and the little finger on the small finger.

The Avignon Papacy was the period from 1309 to 1376 during which seven successive popes resided in Avignon (then in the Kingdom of Arles, part of the Holy Roman Empire, now in France) rather than in Rome. The situation arose from the conflict between the papacy and the French crown, culminating in the death of Pope Boniface VIII after his arrest and maltreatment by Philip IV of France. Following the further death of Pope Benedict XI, Philip forced a deadlocked conclave to elect the French Clement V as pope in 1305.

The Barber of Seville, or The Useless Precaution  is an opera buffa in two acts by Gioachino Rossini with an Italian libretto by Cesare Sterbini. The libretto was based on Pierre Beaumarchais's French comedy The Barber of Seville (1775). The première of Rossini's opera (under the title Almaviva, o sia L'inutile precauzione) took place on 20 February 1816 at the Teatro Argentina, Rome, with designs by Angelo Toselli.Rossini's Barber has proven to be one of the greatest masterpieces of comedy within music, and has been described as the opera buffa of all "opere buffe".

Alkanna tinctoria, the dyer's alkanet or simply alkanet, is a herb in the borage family. Its main notability is its roots are used as a red dye. The plant is also known as dyers' bugloss, orchanet, Spanish bugloss, or Languedoc bugloss. It is native to the Mediterranean region. In Greece A. tinctoria shows a strong genetic structure that has been shown to be mainly driven by neutral processes. A. tinctoria has 30 chromosomes and is regarded as a dysploid at the tetraploid level (4x + 2).A. tinctoria has a bright blue flower.

The Standby High-Readiness Brigade (SHIRBRIG) was a Danish-led initiative associated with the United Nations that aimed to create a standby force ready for peacekeeping. It was formed largely as a result of the genocide in Rwanda and other atrocities. Its permanent headquarters were in Garderkasernen (Garder barracks), Høvelte 30 kilometres north of Copenhagen in Denmark. It was declared ready for operations on January 1, 2000, and deployed to the Horn of Africa in November 2000 to form the core of the UN Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea (UNMEE) under the command of Royal Netherlands Marine Corps Major General Patrick Cammaert.

Adoption is a process whereby a person assumes the parenting of another , usually a child , from that person’s perspective. Adoption, however, is not a legal act, and it may be done by a professional or someone acting on their behalf . In some countries, adoption is also known as legal guardianship. Adoptions are a legal process where the state takes legal guardianship over the child . In most states , the child’s natural parents are removed from their home, and the adoption is done by the state .

The Novikov self-consistency principle , also known as the Novikov self-consistency conjecture and Larry Niven 's law of conservation of mass, was proposed in the 1980s by Sergey Novikov to explain the mass-energy equivalence between the quantum and classical theories of the Universe. Niven proposed this conjecture as a way to find an elegant way to combine quantum field theory and classical gravity in an unified manner. The conjecture states that a massless spin 2 particle in the context of field theory and a massless spin 0 particle in the context of classical gravity should not be distinguishable from each other.

The Boeing CH-47 Chinook is a tandem rotor helicopter developed by American rotorcraft company Vertol and manufactured by Boeing Vertol. The Chinook is a heavy-lift helicopter that is among the heaviest lifting Western helicopters. Its name, Chinook, is from the Native American Chinook people of Washington state.The Chinook was originally designed by Vertol, which had begun work in 1957 on a new tandem-rotor helicopter, designated as the Vertol Model 107 or V-107. Around the same time, the United States Department of the Army announced its intention to replace the piston engine–powered Sikorsky CH-37 Mojave with a new, gas turbine–powered helicopter.

Chrysippus of Soli ( ; , ; ) was a Greek Stoic philosopher . He was a native of Soli, a city in Euboea. His teacher was Demophilus of Tyre . After a number of his teachers died , Chrysippus began to study in Soli , where his teacher's wife was also a student, and he was later appointed to the city's court. He taught that virtue, which is the sum of all good things, is the same as nature, while the bad are the result of the badness of the good.

Garnets  are a group of silicate minerals that have been used since the Bronze Age as gemstones and abrasives.All species of garnets possess similar physical properties and crystal forms, but differ in chemical composition. The different species are pyrope, almandine, spessartine, grossular (varieties of which are hessonite or cinnamon-stone and tsavorite), uvarovite and andradite. The garnets make up two solid solution series: pyrope-almandine-spessartine (pyralspite) and uvarovite-grossular-andradite (ugrandite).EtymologyThe word garnet comes from the 14th-century Middle English word gernet, meaning 'dark red'. It is borrowed from Old French grenate from Latin granatus, from granum ('grain, seed').

Lucia di Lammermoor is a dramma tragico (tragic opera) in three acts by Italian composer Gaetano Donizetti. Salvadore Cammarano wrote the Italian-language libretto loosely based upon Sir Walter Scott's 1819 historical novel The Bride of Lammermoor.Donizetti wrote Lucia di Lammermoor in 1835, when he was reaching the peak of his reputation as an opera composer. Gioachino Rossini had recently retired and Vincenzo Bellini had died shortly before the premiere of Lucia leaving Donizetti as "the sole reigning genius of Italian opera". Not only were conditions ripe for Donizetti's success as a composer, but there was also a widespread interest in the history and culture of Scotland.

Stephanie Lynn Nicks ( born May 26 , 1948 ) is an American singer , songwriter , and producer known as the “Queen of American Pop”, and the most popular girl group of the 1960s. In the United States and several countries, she was a top recording artist and a recording star of the 1960s, and the bestselling female artist from the United States during the 1970s and 1980s. She was a member of the 1970s American girl group Destiny's Child. She was the best-selling artist of the 1960s in the United States.

Crocodiles ( family Crocodylidae ) or true crocodiles are large semiaquatic reptiles that live throughout the tropics in Africa , South America, and India. They are found in a number of freshwater and saltwater crocodilian habitats. The largest crocodile species found in Australia is the Nile Crocodile, but they are also present around the Indian Ocean and in the Pacific Ocean. The crocodilian species listed in this guide are considered threatened by the World Conservation Union ( IUCN ). The largest crocodile known to have lived during the Mesozoic Era in the Cretaceous period was Perythorax ludwigii , estimated at ,  long, or  at its largest.

Note : This compilation includes only those attacks that resulted in casualties . Attacks which did not kill or wound were not included. In some cases a number of attackers were reported, but not all, and they were included. Some attacks included in this compilation may have been included in previous releases - see this list for a list of releases

The following compilation includes the following attacks and the number of casualties in each:

Attack Type: Bomb
Number of Casualties: 2
Victim of Attack: 2, both females
Victim of Injury: 1

Notes:

This list only includes those attacks that resulted in casualties.

The fisherman's knot is a bend (a knot for joining two lines) with a symmetrical structure consisting of two overhand knots, each tied around the standing part of the other. Other names for the fisherman's knot include: angler's knot, English knot, halibut knot, waterman's knot.Though the fisherman's knot is associated with fishing, it can slip when tied in nylon monofilament and other slippery lines; however, if more holding strength is required, the overhand knots can be made with more turns, as in the double fisherman's knot, and so on.

Oak Ridge National Laboratory ( ORNL ) is a U.S. multiprogram science and technology national laboratory sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy. ORNL's primary scientific goal is to identify, characterize and mitigate environmental and societal risks to the nation's critical infrastructure. ORNL is the largest laboratory dedicated to the research of the physical, chemical and biological sciences for the benefit of the American and global economy and national security. ORNL operates in partnership with universities, research institutions, industry partners, and non-profit environmental, national security and defense corporations.

Sir Robert Alexander Watson Watt  (13 April 1892 – 5 December 1973) was a British pioneer of radio direction finding and radar technology.Watt began his career in radio physics with a job at the Met Office, where he began looking for accurate ways to track thunderstorms using the radio signals given off by lightning. This led to the 1920s development of a system later known as high-frequency direction finding (HFDF or "huff-duff"). Although well publicized at the time, the system's enormous military potential was not developed until the late 1930s.

The United Nations Foundation is a charitable organization headquartered in Washington, DC, that supports the United Nations and its activities. It was established in 1998 with a $1 billion gift to the United Nations by philanthropist Ted Turner, who believed the UN was crucial for addressing the world's problems. Originally primarily a grantmaker, the UN Foundation has evolved into a strategic partner to the UN, mobilizing support to advance the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and help the UN address issues such as climate change, global health, gender equality, human rights, data and technology, peace, and humanitarian responses.

Mobile Bay is a shallow inlet of the Gulf of Mexico , lying within the state of Alabama in the United States. It is a natural inlet to the Gulf stream, and is considered to be part of its "Great Inlet." Located at a high altitude of around 1,600 feet (520 meters) above sea level, Mobile Bay is a site for offshore oil and gas drilling. It also serves as a vital shipping point for offshore transportation of crude oil. Efforts to extract fossil fuel reserves from the area of the Gulf of Mexico have continued in the face of opposition by environmentalists.

Psilocybin  is a naturally occurring psychedelic prodrug compound produced by more than 200 species of fungi. The most potent are members of the genus Psilocybe, such as P. azurescens, P. semilanceata, and P. cyanescens, but psilocybin has also been isolated from about a dozen other genera. Psilocybin is itself biologically inactive but is quickly converted by the body to psilocin, which has mind-altering effects similar, in some aspects, to those of LSD, mescaline, and DMT. In general, the effects include euphoria, visual and mental hallucinations, changes in perception, a distorted sense of time, and perceived spiritual experiences.

Asperger syndrome (AS), also known as Asperger's, is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by significant difficulties in social interaction and nonverbal communication, along with restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior and interests. It is an autism spectrum disorder (ASD), but differs from other ASDs by relatively unimpaired language and intelligence. The syndrome is named after the Austrian pediatrician Hans Asperger, who, in 1944, described children in his care who struggled to form friendships, did not understand others' gestures or feelings, engaged in one-sided conversations about their favourite interests, and were clumsy.

The raven paradox , also known as Hempel 's paradox , Hempel 's ravens , or rarely the paradox of the ravens , is one of the most well-known paradoxes in philosophy . The paradox involves the question of whether or not a raven in an environment with ravens is a raven. As such, the question of whether or not a bird is a bird is asked. This is a question which, by its nature, is ambiguous . However, the raven paradox can be stated to the effect that there is an absolute answer to this question and that there is an absolute non-answer to this question .

The Avignon Papacy was the period from 1309 to 1376 during which seven successive popes resided in Avignon ( then in the region of Provence in southern France). Pope Benedict XII was elected in 1309, taking the name of Saint John Chrysostom. This was not an election but rather a pontificate. The election of Pope Benedict of Nursia was not until 1350, by Pope Clement VI. This pope was one of only three popes to have lived in Italy. He was also one of the three to use the Latin language, and this was not a foreign language, at least to contemporaries.

The Bell OH-58 Kiowa is a family of single-engine , single-rotor , military helicopters used for observation , utility , air-sea rescue and transport missions throughout the world. The OH-58 Kiowa is used for both training and demonstration purposes. Its standard mission was to transport men and materiel, although it may have been used for ground attack or a variety of other missions. History
The Kiowa was the world's first turboprop powered helicopter, designed during World War II for military purposes. Designed by the United States Army and produced under license by Lockheed, it was the first helicopter to be mass-produced in this form.

Niacin, also known as nicotinic acid, is an organic compound and a form of vitamin B3, an essential human nutrient. It can be manufactured by plants and animals from the amino acid tryptophan. Niacin is obtained in the diet from a variety of whole and processed foods, with highest contents in fortified packaged foods, meat, poultry, red fish such as tuna and salmon, lesser amounts in nuts, legumes and seeds. Niacin as a dietary supplement is used to treat pellagra, a disease caused by niacin deficiency. Signs and symptoms of pellagra include skin and mouth lesions, anemia, headaches, and tiredness.

David is a masterpiece of Renaissance sculpture, created in marble between 1501 and 1504 by the Italian artist Michelangelo. David is a  marble statue of the Biblical figure David, a favoured subject in the art of Florence.David was originally commissioned as one of a series of statues of prophets to be positioned along the roofline of the east end of Florence Cathedral, but was instead placed in a public square, outside the Palazzo Vecchio, the seat of civic government in Florence, in the Piazza della Signoria, where it was unveiled on 8 September 1504.

The IAI RQ-5 Hunter unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) was originally intended to serve as the United States Army's Short Range UAV system for division and corps commanders. It took off and landed (using arresting gear) on runways. It used a gimbaled EO/IR sensor to relay its video in real time via a second airborne Hunter over a C-band line-of-sight data link. The RQ-5 is based on the Hunter UAV that was developed by Israel Aerospace Industries.Design and developmentSystem acquisition and training started in 1994 but production was cancelled in 1996 due to concerns over program mismanagement.

Depleted uranium (DU; also referred to in the past as Q-metal, depletalloy or D-38) is uranium with a lower content of the fissile isotope  than natural uranium. Natural uranium contains about  , while the DU used by the U.S. Department of Defense contains   or less. The less radioactive and non-fissile  constitutes the main component of depleted uranium. Uses of DU take advantage of its very high density of   ( denser than lead).Civilian uses include counterweights in aircraft, radiation shielding in medical radiation therapy and industrial radiography equipment, and containers for transporting radioactive materials.

was the 69th emperor of Japan , according to the traditional order of succession.Go-Suzaku 's reign spanned the years from 794 to 794 A.D., and is often seen as the golden age of the Heian period, but was also notable for the expansion of political control, the expansion of Buddhism, the expansion of agriculture, and the appearance of the city of Heian-kyō in 795. In 795 A.D. he was proclaimed emperor by the Buddhist Council of Heian-kyō in Nagaoka, Japan . Kōkaku had several wives, among which was a daughter with the title of Heian-kyō (, literally "Eastern Princess").

The World Federation of Trade Unions (WFTU) is an international federation of trade unions. WFTU was established in 1945 to replace the International Federation of Trade Unions.HistoryRiseIts mission was to bring together trade unions across the world in a single international organization, much like the United Nations. After a number of Western trade unions left it in 1949, as a result of disputes over support for the Marshall Plan, to form the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, the WFTU was made up primarily of unions affiliated with or allegedly sympathetic to communist parties.

Gaelic football (; short name ), commonly known as simply Gaelic, GAA or Caid, is an Irish team sport. It is played between two teams of 15 players on a rectangular grass pitch. The objective of the sport is to score by kicking or punching the ball into the other team's goals (3 points) or between two upright posts above the goals and over a crossbar  above the ground (1 point).Players advance the football up the field with a combination of carrying, bouncing, kicking, hand-passing, and soloing (dropping the ball and then toe-kicking the ball upward into the hands).

Gregory Benford (born January 30, 1941) is an American science fiction author and astrophysicist who is Professor Emeritus at the Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of California, Irvine. He is a contributing editor of Reason magazine.Benford wrote the Galactic Center Saga science fiction novels, beginning with In the Ocean of Night (1977). The series postulates a galaxy in which sentient organic life is in constant warfare with sentient electromechanical life.In 1969 he wrote "The Scarred Man", the first story about a computer virus, published in 1970.Biography Benford was born in Mobile, Alabama and grew up in Robertsdale and Fairhope.

Year 884 (DCCCLXXXIV) was a leap year starting on Wednesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  March 1 – Diego Rodríguez Porcelos, count of Castile, founds and repopulates (repoblación) Burgos and Ubierna (Northern Spain), under the mandate of King Alfonso III of Asturias. Summer – King Carloman II reverts to the former fall-back of 'pay and pray', buying (with Danegeld) a truce at Amiens, while he raises 12,000 lbs of silver for the Vikings to depart. December 12 – Carloman II dies after a hunting accident.

Year 1155 ( MCLV ) was a common year starting on Saturday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. The " M " will display the full calendar. Events

January–March 
 January 11 – Death of King William II in battle (d. 1344). January 14 – Battle of St. Gilles, Guienne: English forces (2nd Duke of Normandy, King John II and King Henry V) win the Battle of Guienne. February 3 – In the Second War of the League of Cognac: Charles VII and Francis II of France take up arms.

A brain tumor occurs when abnormal cells form within the brain . There are two main types of tumors : medulloblastoma, the most common of which affects children under the age of 18 years and diffuse astrocytomas, which occurs in adults older than 40 years and can be fatal . While the two tumors are both benign, each has different risk factors. What Causes Diffuse Glioblastoma? The most common form of brain cancer is the more benign astrocytoma, which accounts for approximately 70 percent of all brain tumors . The second most common type of brain cancer is the more aggressive diffuse glioma .

Eugène Adrien Roland Georges Garros (; 6 October 1888 – 5 October 1918) was a French pioneering aviator and fighter pilot during World War I and early days of aviation. In 1928, the Roland Garros tennis stadium was named in his memory; the French Open tennis tournament takes the name of Roland Garros from the stadium in which it is held.Biography Eugène Adrien Roland Georges Garros was born in Saint-Denis, Réunion, and studied at the Lycée Janson de Sailly and HEC Paris.At the age of 12, he contracted pneumonia, and was sent to Cannes to recuperate.

Padthaway is a small town in the Australian state of South Australia located in the state's south-east within the Limestone Coast region about  south east of the state capital of Adelaide and about  south-east of the municipal seat of Bordertown. The name is derived from the Potawurutj, the Aboriginal name for Good Water. Padthaway is in the Tatiara District Council, the state electorate of MacKillop and the federal Division of Barker.The 2016 Australian census which was conducted in August 2016 reports that Padthaway had a population of 418 people.Wine regionPadthaway is also the name of a wine region surrounding the town.

Catalase is a common enzyme found in nearly all living organisms exposed to oxygen ( such as bacteria , plants ) . The enzyme is present in two forms , alpha and beta . The alpha form is usually present in very small amounts and plays a role in the oxidation of glucose , and the beta form is more abundant and can account for up to 75% of total enzymatic activity. In humans, it accounts for about 10% of the total hemoglobin of red blood cells . In the presence of oxygen, the enzyme converts hemoglobin to methemoglobin .

The Circus Maximus (Latin for "largest circus"; Italian: Circo Massimo) is an ancient Roman chariot-racing stadium and mass entertainment venue in Rome, Italy. In the valley between the Aventine and Palatine hills, it was the first and largest stadium in ancient Rome and its later Empire. It measured  in length and  in width and could accommodate over 150,000 spectators. In its fully developed form, it became the model for circuses throughout the Roman Empire. The site is now a public park.Events and uses The Circus was Rome's largest venue for ludi, public games connected to Roman religious festivals.

Relative density, or specific gravity, is the ratio of the density (mass of a unit volume) of a substance to the density of a given reference material. Specific gravity for liquids is nearly always measured with respect to water at its densest (at ); for gases, the reference is air at room temperature . The term "relative density" is often preferred in scientific usage. If a substance's relative density is less than 1 then it is less dense than the reference; if greater than 1 then it is denser than the reference.

In chemistry , a nucleophile is a chemical species that forms bonds with electrophiles by donating an electron pair . A nucleophilic substitution reaction involves the addition of an atom (or group) to a chiral compound, often with concomitant formation of a new stereocentre. If an electron is removed from the anion by the nucleophilic site, a nucleophile can be re-activated, such as by reaction with a leaving group. A nucleophilic attack may lead to the formation of either an enantiomeric excess or a racemic mixture of the products of the cyclization.

Liberation theology is a Christian theological approach emphasizing the liberation of the oppressed. In certain contexts, it engages socio-economic analyses, with "social concern for the poor and political liberation for oppressed peoples." In other contexts, it addresses other forms of inequality, such as race or caste.Liberation theology is best known in the Latin American context, especially within Catholicism in the 1960s after the Second Vatican Council, where it became the political praxis of theologians such as Gustavo Gutiérrez, Leonardo Boff, and Jesuits Juan Luis Segundo and Jon Sobrino, who popularized the phrase "preferential option for the poor".

This list of Anuran families shows all extant families of Anura . Anura is an order of animals in the Anura family. This family contains many species and many genera that are endemic to the islands of Oceania. Anura is a clade within the vertebrate order Anura, which is represented by around 300 species (including about half of the island species of Australia) in 13 genera and 5 families. There are more than 600 species of Anura living in a wide range of habitats in Oceania (including Australia). This list is not exhaustive, but this is the best resource I could locate for families of Anura.

David is a masterpiece of Renaissance sculpture , created in marble between 1501 and 1504 by the Italian artist Michelangelo Buonarroti. He is considered the most important sculpture of the 16th century and was used as a basis for the ceiling of the Florence cathedral that same year, as it has been since. David was made to commemorate the victory of the Jewish people over the forces of Goliath (Joshua 1:1) in ancient times. There is a story about the original David, who was killed and then buried in a secret spot at Mount Moriah by the Israelites.

Tristan Tzara (; ; born Samuel or Samy Rosenstock, also known as S. Samyro;  – 25 December 1963) was a Romanian and French avant-garde poet, essayist and performance artist. Also active as a journalist, playwright, literary and art critic, composer and film director, he was known best for being one of the founders and central figures of the anti-establishment Dada movement. Under the influence of Adrian Maniu, the adolescent Tzara became interested in Symbolism and co-founded the magazine Simbolul with Ion Vinea (with whom he also wrote experimental poetry) and painter Marcel Janco.

Salmon is the common name for several species of ray-finned fish in the family Salmonidae . Other fish in the family are catfish, carp, bream and eel. The family Salmonidae are distributed across the Northern Hemisphere and are found around the coasts of North America. They are a diverse group of fish that inhabit fresh water. There are approximately 20 species of salmon in the family Salmonidae, with many of them found around the world in freshwater streams and rivers.
