The majority of species in the Salmonidae, including the species in the genus Salmon, occur in cold, fresh water.

In quantum mechanics, counterfactual definiteness (CFD) is the ability to speak "meaningfully" of the definiteness of the results of measurements that have not been performed (i.e., the ability to assume the existence of objects, and properties of objects, even when they have not been measured). The term "counterfactual definiteness" is used in discussions of physics calculations, especially those related to the phenomenon called quantum entanglement and those related to the Bell inequalities. In such discussions "meaningfully" means the ability to treat these unmeasured results on an equal footing with measured results in statistical calculations.

Pope Leo VII (; died 13 July 939) was the bishop of Rome and nominal ruler of the Papal States from 3 January 936 to his death.Election Leo VII's election to the papacy in 936, after the death of Pope John XI, was secured by Alberic II of Spoleto, the ruler of Rome at the time. Alberic wanted to choose the pope so that the papacy would continue to yield to his authority. Leo was the priest of the church of San Sisto Vecchio in Rome, thought to be a Benedictine monk.

Sparta ( Doric Greek : Σπάρτα , Spártā ; Attic Greek : Σπάρτη , Spártē ) was a prominent city-state, which existed for about 200 years in the northern Peloponnese (modern-day Peloponnese peninsula, southern Greece) until about the mid-8th century BCE, during the period of Persian rule. In antiquity the city was known as Atticonia or Atticos (Άθουανίων). As the city was not a permanent settlement with a strong governing body, it was not ruled by the same people who founded it (see also Athenian polis). It is not known whether the city was destroyed in a fire or simply abandoned after 200 years.

A jubilee is a particular anniversary of an event , usually denoting the 25th , 40th , 50th , 60th , 70th , 80th , 90th , or the 100th birthday of an individual. Many countries celebrate jubilations on such occasions, and there has often been some debate as to which is the best jubilee celebration in that country. This article aims to give you a brief guide to the various jubilant traditions in different countries, including those in the Middle East and Southeast Asia. Some of these are not universal to all countries, but most are.

Audio Video Interleave ( also Audio Video Interleaved and known by its initials and filename extension AVI , usually pronounced as AVI ). This is the same method of storing multiple video frames of the same scene as if the video sequence has been split into two separate frames of video, one for each of the first two images. It is also known as 2:2:4 interleaving , 2:1:1 interleaving, and interleaving . Video interleaving is a feature of digital video compression systems, used to store the video frames of a series of video frames in one compressed data file.

In chemistry, an aldehyde  is an organic compound containing a functional group with the structure −C(H)=O. The functional group itself (i.e. without the "R" side chain) is known as an aldehyde or formyl group. Aldehydes are common and play important roles in the technology and biological spheres.Structure and bondingAldehydes feature a carbon center that is connected by a double bond to oxygen and a single bond to hydrogen and single bond to a third substituent, which is carbon or, in the case of formaldehyde, hydrogen. The central carbon is often described as being sp2-hybridized.

A terrarium ( plural : terraria or terrariums ) is usually a sealable glass container containing soil and plants , usually of the form of a glass jar. It is used as a home garden, for hobbyists and for educational purposes. Many kinds of terraria are used for decoration, such as for Halloween, Easter, Christmas. The terrarium usually comes in two parts, one half of a glass jar or a polystyrene one. The first part of the terrarium has a transparent lid which can be screwed on when the top part is put in the ground.

Lewiston is a city and the county seat of Nez Perce County, Idaho, United States, in the state's north central region. It is the second-largest city in the northern Idaho region, behind Coeur d'Alene, and ninth-largest in the state. Lewiston is the principal city of the Lewiston, ID-WA Metropolitan Statistical Area, which includes all of Nez Perce County and Asotin County, Washington. As of the 2020 census, the population of Lewiston was 34,203 up from 31,894 in 2010.Lewiston is located at the confluence of the Snake River and Clearwater River,  upstream and southeast of the Lower Granite Dam.

The chicken ( Gallus domesticus ) is a domesticated bird , with attributes of wild species such as the red jungle fowl ( Capra ursina ) and the common chicken ( Leucetta aspera ), and as such it is considered an ornamental bird and a traditional game bird of the tropics. It is the most popular chicken breed in the United States, Canada, and many other parts of the world, particularly Europe. It is an important commercial species in the United States, and it is raised for laying and egg production. It is a key poultry breeder, as well as a highly profitable commercial species.

Zooarchaeology ( sometimes incorrectly archaeozoology ) , also known as faunal analysis , is a branch of archaeology that studies the remains of the animal or plants that inhabited prehistoric and historic ecosystems, with emphasis placed on the preservation of the biological and ecological systems rather than on the archaeological remains . The name comes from the Latin word archetypal or archeo- - which means archetypical, characteristic or typical . The use of this word in archaeozoology may refer to the study of the physical characteristics of the prehistoric ecosystem, as opposed to those in the archaeological environment. However, there are few studies that investigate the biological characteristics of prehistoric environments.

The RQ-3 DarkStar ( known as Tier III- or `` Tier three minus '' during development ) is an unmanned drone that has been upgraded to take the place of the UAVs in many conflicts in Afghanistan and elsewhere in the Middle East. The US has been utilizing these drones in many places, such as Afghanistan, Somalia, and Yemen to counter the threat of militant groups. The US has used them in other conflict zones, including the Philippines and Iraq, for example. In Afghanistan, drones are now being operated by special forces from the elite Special Forces Group, known as Delta Force .

In the philosophy of mathematics, the abstraction of actual infinity involves the acceptance (if the axiom of infinity is included) of infinite entities as given, actual and completed objects. These might include the set of natural numbers, extended real numbers, transfinite numbers, or even an infinite sequence of rational numbers. Actual infinity is to be contrasted with potential infinity, in which a non-terminating process (such as "add 1 to the previous number") produces a sequence with no last element, and where each individual result is finite and is achieved in a finite number of steps.

Salmon  is the common name for several species of ray-finned fish in the family Salmonidae. Other fish in the same family include trout, char, grayling, and whitefish. Salmon are native to tributaries of the North Atlantic (genus Salmo) and Pacific Ocean (genus Oncorhynchus). Many species of salmon have been introduced into non-native environments such as the Great Lakes of North America and Patagonia in South America. Salmon are intensively farmed  in many parts of the world.Typically, salmon are anadromous: they hatch in fresh water, migrate to the ocean, then return to fresh water to reproduce.

Budapest ( , ; ) is the capital and most populous city of Hungary . It is the ninth-largest city of Hungary by total population, the eighth-largest in terms of area, and the fourth-most populous city in terms of the metropolitan area. Budapest's economy is based on tourism, with about two-thirds of its city area consisting of popular tourist resorts. Budapest is a popular city among many European capitals for its proximity to Austria and the Carpathians, a short ferry flight to Vienna, and easy public transportation by air, rail, and roads.

The subset sum problem (SSP) is a decision problem in computer science. In its most general formulation, there is a multiset  of integers and a target-sum , and the question is to decide whether any subset of the integers sum to precisely . The problem is known to be NP-complete. Moreover, some restricted variants of it are NP-complete too, for example: The variant in which all inputs are positive. The variant in which inputs may be positive or negative, and . For example, given the set , the answer is yes because the subset  sums to zero.

Hilbert's paradox of the Grand Hotel  (colloquial: Infinite Hotel Paradox or Hilbert's Hotel) is a thought experiment which illustrates a counterintuitive property of infinite sets. It is demonstrated that a fully occupied hotel with infinitely many rooms may still accommodate additional guests, even infinitely many of them, and this process may be repeated infinitely often. The idea was introduced by David Hilbert in a 1924 lecture "Über das Unendliche", reprinted in , and was popularized through George Gamow's 1947 book One Two Three... Infinity.The paradoxConsider a hypothetical hotel with a countably infinite number of rooms, all of which are occupied.

Menstruation ( also known as a period and many other colloquial terms ) is the regular discharge of blood and other bodily fluids (such as mucus) by a female for her reproductive system to become ready for sexual intercourse. In humans, it is a necessary part of normal female physiology to achieve and maintain a period, or the absence of one. The term menstruation ( from Latin menstrua , "menses", "period", and menstrual, "period" ) may also describe the time period from the first day of menstruation to the next menses.

François Marie Adrien Maurice Mitterrand ( 26 October 19168 January 1996 ) served as President of France from 1981 to 1996; was the only president to resign before he became President, and the only to be elected president twice. Mitterrand is also known for being the first non-French President to die in office, and for being one of the few French Presidents to make his own funeral arrangements. He spent his entire Presidency with his second wife, Danielle, and they had three children. Born in Paris, Mitterrand began his political career in the early 1970s as a leader of the Action française.

The overhand knot , also known as a knot and half knot , is one of the most fundamental knots in the world of mathematics. It is well-known in the community of knot theorists and in the mathematical field of geometry. It was first introduced by M. V. Kupavskii and E. I. Zelenov in 1973 and then by A. V. Zaliznyak in 1975. This example of a half knot is based on the diagram of the same knot. The two arcs in this diagram represent the two half twists, which are shown in red and green, respectively.

Henry Olusegun Adeola Samuel (born 19 February 1963), known professionally as Seal, is a British singer-songwriter. He has sold over 20 million records worldwide, with hit songs "Crazy" and "Killer", the latter of which went to number one in the UK, and his most celebrated song, "Kiss from a Rose", which was released in 1994. Seal is renowned for his distinctive soulful singing voice. Seal has won multiple awards throughout his career, including three Brit Awards; he won Best British Male in 1992, as well as four Grammy Awards and an MTV Video Music Award.

Offa's Dyke  is a large linear earthwork that roughly follows the border between England and Wales. The structure is named after Offa, the Anglo-Saxon king of Mercia from AD 757 until 796, who is traditionally believed to have ordered its construction. Although its precise original purpose is debated, it delineated the border between Anglian Mercia and the Welsh kingdom of Powys.The earthwork, which was up to  wide (including its flanking ditch) and  high, traversed low ground, hills and rivers. Today it is protected as a scheduled monument.

Audio Video Interleave (also Audio Video Interleaved and known by its initials and filename extension AVI, usually pronounced ), is a proprietary multimedia container format and Windows standard introduced by Microsoft in November 1992 as part of its Video for Windows software. AVI files can contain both audio and video data in a file container that allows synchronous audio-with-video playback. Like the DVD video format, AVI files support multiple streaming audio and video, although these features are seldom used.Many AVI files use the file format extensions developed by the Matrox OpenDML group in February 1996.

Lewiston is a city and the county seat of Nez Perce County , Idaho , United States , in the eastern reaches of the Canadian Rocky Mountains. It was founded on May 3, 1881. It is the only city in Idaho which is within the contiguous United States. Contents

History

Early history (1798-1907)

Nez Perce is located on the Columbia River. The area was initially settled by a number of different groups, such as the Cheyenne and Arapaho, and the Nez Perce who had settled in the area in 1805.

La traviata (; The Fallen Woman) is an opera in three acts by Giuseppe Verdi set to an Italian libretto by Francesco Maria Piave. It is based on La Dame aux camélias (1852), a play by Alexandre Dumas fils adapted from his own 1848 novel. The opera was originally titled Violetta, after the main character. It was first performed on 6 March 1853 at La Fenice opera house in Venice.Piave and Verdi wanted to follow Dumas in giving the opera a contemporary setting, but the authorities at La Fenice insisted that it be set in the past, "c. 1700".

Till Death Us Do Part is a British television sitcom that aired on BBC1 from 1965 to 1975. The show was first broadcast as a Comedy Playhouse pilot, then in seven series until 1975. In 1981, ITV continued the sitcom for six episodes, calling it Till Death.... The BBC produced a sequel from 1985 until 1992, In Sickness and in Health.Created by Johnny Speight, Till Death Us Do Part centred on the East End Garnett family, led by patriarch Alf Garnett (Warren Mitchell), a reactionary white working-class man who holds racist and anti-socialist views.

Harlequin ( ; ; ) is the best-known of the zanni or comic servant characters from the Italian commedia dell'arte. The word Harlequin comes directly from a French verb meaning to play, in the sense of "play tricks" (or "show tricks"), and it was the Italian Harlequin that gained the fame of the first Italian comediennes, and in its modern sense was used by the most successful Italian comic writers of the 20th century, including Enzo Alberoni (La cenerentola, 1922), Vincenzo Mazzola (Il barbero, 1926), and Renato Castagno (Nembro della cenerentola, 1936).

Delhi (;  Dillī;  Dillī;  Dêhlī), officially the National Capital Territory (NCT) of Delhi, is a city and a union territory of India containing New Delhi, the capital of India. Straddling the Yamuna river, but primarily its western or right bank, Delhi shares borders with the state of Uttar Pradesh in the east and with the state of Haryana in the remaining directions. The NCT covers an area of . According to the 2011 census, Delhi's city proper population was over 11 million, while the NCT's population was about 16.8 million.

The Martian Chronicles is a science fiction fix-up novel , published in 1950 , by American writer Ray Bradbury that details a futuristic battle between the U.S. Army and the Soviet Red Army. It takes place during World War II, during a battle of the North American theatre that pits the American and Soviet armies. Its setting is an unnamed future in North America. In the early days the Soviets had taken the North American North American continent as part of their vast, vast empire, which included much of Asia, Africa, the Near East, Russia, and China.

A drummer is a percussionist who creates music using drums.Most contemporary western bands that play rock , pop , jazz and blues instruments usually use drummers to help them play their instruments. They help the musician get in tune with what the band is playing, so that the drums can hit the notes they need to hear. They also play some of the instruments that are required for the music, but do not have much to do with that particular song.Drummer's also come in many other styles, including classical and folk music and funk.Drummer's have been used by many different cultures and people in many different places.

Steven C. McConnell is an author of software engineering textbooks such as Code Complete , Rapid Development , and Software Testing: Principles and Practices. In 2012, the author was the recipient of the Outstanding Scholar Award of the ACM Software Engineering Symposium (SES 2012). The author also served as editor of the Journal of C# Software Construction (2011-2013) and was the co-author of C# 6.2: A Comprehensive Guide, published by the . The author has received or will receive research grants and awards for work in the fields of software testing and software quality.

The Buran program (, , "Snowstorm", "Blizzard"), also known as the "VKK Space Orbiter programme" , was a Soviet and later Russian reusable spacecraft project that began in 1974 at the Central Aerohydrodynamic Institute in Moscow and was formally suspended in 1993. In addition to being the designation for the whole Soviet/Russian reusable spacecraft project, Buran was also the name given to Orbiter K1, which completed one uncrewed spaceflight in 1988 and was the only Soviet reusable spacecraft to be launched into space. The Buran-class orbiters used the expendable Energia rocket as a launch vehicle.

Astrid Anna Emilia Lindgren ( ; ; 14 November 1907 – 28 January 2002 ) was a Swedish writer of detective fiction and a Nobel Prize-winning writer. She was best known for her detective work, but also wrote other genres, short fiction and poems. Her work was noted for its social and moral messages and is seen as part of the new wave of Nordic modernism. As a novelist she was noted for her social and moral themes. She wrote detective fiction, but also wrote several other genres, including short fiction and poetry.

Bread is a staple food prepared from a dough of flour (usually wheat) and water, usually by baking. Throughout recorded history and around the world, it has been an important part of many cultures' diet. It is one of the oldest human-made foods, having been of significance since the dawn of agriculture, and plays an essential role in both religious rituals and secular culture.Bread may be leavened by naturally occurring microbes (e.g. sourdough), chemicals (e.g. baking soda), industrially produced yeast, or high-pressure aeration, which creates the gas bubbles that fluff up bread.

The Australian Secret Intelligence Service ( ASIS ) is the foreign intelligence agency of Australia , tasked with the covert collection of foreign intelligence . The agency was created in 1965 and is responsible for intelligence sharing, foreign intelligence collection, cyber espionage and the provision of information to Australian military forces and government . The agency is headquartered in Canberra and has offices around the world . Australian SIGINT units have also been deployed around the world to collect information on foreign political and military entities . The agency has been described as " one of the world's best secret intelligence agencies . " .

Metaphone is a phonetic algorithm, published by Lawrence Philips in 1990, for indexing words by their English pronunciation. It fundamentally improves on the Soundex algorithm by using information about variations and inconsistencies in English spelling and pronunciation to produce a more accurate encoding, which does a better job of matching words and names which sound similar. As with Soundex, similar-sounding words should share the same keys. Metaphone is available as a built-in operator in a number of systems.Philips later produced a new version of the algorithm, which he named Double Metaphone.

George Shipway (25 May 1908–1982) was a British author best known for his historical novels, but he also tried his hand at political satire in his book The Chilian Club.Military careerGeorge Frederick Morgan Shipway was born on 25 May 1908 at Allahbad in India and was educated at Clifton. He then attended the Royal Military College, Sandhurst and was commissioned on to the Unattached List for the Indian Army on 30 August 1928. He arrived in India on 5 October 1928 and was attached to a British regiment: the 2nd Battalion The Prince of Wales's Volunteers (South Lancashire), for one year from 14 October 1928.

Clothing ( also known as clothes , apparel , and attire ) are items worn on the body . Typically they are items worn around the body . Clothing has many different uses , but the primary use of clothing is to cover one's body to keep it warm and to protect the body from the elements . Clothing may be made of cloth, leather, rubber, metal, plastic, or any combination of the three . Clothing may also be made or worn under clothing , and it may be worn over clothing . Clothing is commonly referred to as apparel .

An infection is the invasion of an organism's body tissues by disease-causing agents, their multiplication, and the reaction of host tissues to the infectious agents and the toxins they produce. An infectious disease, also known as a transmissible disease or communicable disease, is an illness resulting from an infection.Infections can be caused by a wide range of pathogens, most prominently bacteria and viruses. Hosts can fight infections using their immune system. Mammalian hosts react to infections with an innate response, often involving inflammation, followed by an adaptive response.Specific medications used to treat infections include antibiotics, antivirals, antifungals, antiprotozoals, and antihelminthics.

Year 1170 (MCLXX) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place   Levant  Winter – Egyptian forces led by Saladin invade Palestine and besiege Darum on the Mediterranean coast. Its defenses are weak and though Saladin has no siege-engines with him, its fall seems imminent. King Amalric I withdraws his Templar garrison from Gaza, to assist him in defending Darum. Saladin raises the siege and marches on Gaza, where he captures the lower town (despite the stiff resistance ordered by Lord Miles of Plancy), and massacres the inhabitants.

An adverb is a word or an expression that modifies a verb , adjective , another adverb , determiner , noun , pronoun , or a combination. Adverb can also be used as an adverb to modify a noun . Adverbs can be used to modify clauses , sentences , and words in clauses . The adverb  is a modal auxiliary in English, and can be used with verbs , nouns , adjectives , adjectival forms of adjectives , verbs , etc. Example:

adverb (modal) adjective [adjectival] (adverb)

The noun or noun phrase that immediately follows is a dependent noun.

Powaqqatsi (or Powaqqatsi: Life in Transformation) is a 1988 American non-narrative film directed by Godfrey Reggio and the sequel to Reggio's experimental 1982 film, Koyaanisqatsi. It is the second film in the Qatsi trilogy.Powaqqatsi is a Hopi neologism coined by Reggio meaning "parasitic way of life" or "life in transition". While Koyaanisqatsi focused on modern life in industrial countries, Powaqqatsi, which similarly has no dialogue, focuses more on the conflict in Third World countries between traditional ways of life and the new ways of life introduced with industrialization.

The unexpected hanging paradox or surprise test paradox is a paradox about a person's expectations about the timing of a future event which they are told will occur at an unexpected time. The paradox is variously applied to a prisoner's hanging, or a surprise school test. It was first introduced to the public in Martin Gardner's March 1963 Mathematical Games column in Scientific American magazine.There is no consensus on its precise nature and consequently a canonical resolution has not been agreed on. Logical analyses focus on "truth values", for example by identifying it as paradox of self-reference.

Wool is the textile fibre obtained from sheep and other animals , including cashmere and mohair from goats , qiviut sheep, and cashmere from alpacas. It has the highest strength per unit weight and is also the lightest natural fiber known. It is produced on a worldwide scale through many processes, such as: carding wool, spinning and weaving. It is the second most popular wool fiber after polyester. Wool is an important animal material used in clothing, furniture and home furnishings, and it can be used as a fiber for clothing and other textile products. What is wool?

Bikram Yoga is a system of hot yoga , a type of yoga as exercise , devised by Bikram Choudhury , who is known as a yogini . It is a yoga form of practice which combines the traditional yoga poses with elements of meditation and chanting. To start a practice of yoga, a student must be physically fit and able to lie on a mat for some 30 minutes . Bikram yoga starts with a series of poses , known as asanas. These poses can be modified according to the needs of each person, as well as for his or her specific body structure and condition .

A Select Library of the Nicene and Post-Nicene Fathers of the Christian Church, usually known as the Nicene and Post-Nicene Fathers (NPNF), is a set of books containing translations of early Christian writings into English. It was published between 1886 and 1900. Unlike the Ante-Nicene Fathers which was produced by using earlier translations of the Ante-Nicene Christian Library (ANCL), the Nicene and Post-Nicene Fathers was printed simultaneously in Europe and in America, by T. & T. Clark, by Christian Literature Company and other American editors. The translations were in the main revised versions of those made for the Oxford Movement Library of the Fathers series.

Year 984 ( CMLXXXIV ) was a leap year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar )
or Sunday
with an ordinary Gregorian calendar year of 985 ( a full year of 49 ) if it has one, and 984 (a full year of 48 ) if it does not. This is only one of several possible calendar combinations of the year. It was also a leap year starting on Monday and lasting for one day, so it was also a leap year
beginning on Tuesday or Sunday with an ordinary calendar year of 985 or 986,
depending on which of the above options you choose.

Svante August Arrhenius ( , ; 19 February 1859 – 2 October 1927 ) was a Swedish scientist . Originally from a noble family with close ties to the upper class, he studied at several institutions in the late 19th century and became a notable member of a generation of scientists and inventors in Sweden . He spent his entire career in industry, mostly in Sweden. In his youth Arrhenius received a scholarship to study in Germany and his early career was spent working as a patent lawyer . Later, he became an engineer and a businessman.

The Burrows–Wheeler transform ( BWT , also called block-sorting compression ) rearranges a character string into runs of similar characters. This transformation is important in various applications of computer vision. For example, the BWT transforms are used to convert character strings representing words to words. It is widely used for image recognition. Conventional approaches to convert a given text string to a run of characters are to sort each string of characters according to some similarity measure and then join them into a single string, or to sort and join the input string according to some similarity measure and then convert the resulting runs to strings.

A bong ( also known as a water pipe ) is a filtration device generally used for smoking cannabis , with the water being filtered and purified. Types of bongs include:

Shish-kebab ( Shishka-Kebab ) - Shishka-kebab or Shishka-ka'ebab is a type of bong that is very similar in design to a standard water pipe ( pipe of water ), but with a ceramic filter. Shish-kebab filters are used in places where water is contaminated by mold, mildew or other types of bacteria. The water will be filtered by a ceramic or plastic filter and then boiled to extract the bacteria which may then be burned and discarded.

The Lhotshampa or Lhotsampa  people are a heterogeneous Bhutanese people of Nepalese descent. "Lhotshampa", which means "southern borderlanders" in Dzongkha, began to be used by the Bhutanese state in the second half of the twentieth century to refer to the population of Nepali origin in the south of the country. Starting in 2007, most of the Lhotshampas, or Bhutanese Refugees, were resettled to various countries, such as the United States, Canada, Australia, the United Kingdom, and other European countries. the number of Lhotshampa in Nepal is significantly lower than that in the United States and other countries where they have resettled.

Montevideo  is the capital and largest city of Uruguay. According to the 2011 census, the city proper has a population of 1,319,108 (about one-third of the country's total population) in an area of . Montevideo is situated on the southern coast of the country, on the northeastern bank of the Río de la Plata.The city was established in 1724 by a Spanish soldier, Bruno Mauricio de Zabala, as a strategic move amidst the Spanish-Portuguese dispute over the platine region. It was also under brief British rule in 1807, but eventually the city was retaken by Spanish criollos.

Albert the Magnanimous KG, elected King of the Romans as Albert II (10 August 139727 October 1439) was king of the Holy Roman Empire and a member of the House of Habsburg. By inheritance he became Albert V, Duke of Austria. Through his wife he also became King of Hungary, Croatia, Bohemia, and inherited a claim to the Duchy of Luxembourg.BiographyAlbert was born in Vienna as the son of Albert IV, Duke of Austria, and Joanna Sophia of Bavaria.He succeeded to the Duchy of Austria at the age of seven on his father's death in 1404.

The Boeing CH-47 Chinook is a tandem rotor helicopter developed by American rotorcraft company Vertol and manufactured by Boeing Vertol. It is a four-seat rotorcraft that can carry up to two soldiers or up to four passengers. It is also known as "Pinnacle". It is the main UH-60 Blackhawks of the UH-60 Blackhawk choppers. History 
On June 25, 1959, the "Pinnacle" was first flown by Charles E. Smith, US Navy, Lieutenant (USNR), to test the helicopter at Edwards AFB. On August 26, 1960, the Pinnacle was delivered to the USAF.

See also History of UnitarianismA number of notable people have considered themselves Unitarians, Universalists, and following the merger of these denominations in the United States and Canada in 1961, Unitarian Universalists. Additionally, there are persons who, because of their writings or reputation, are considered to have held Unitarian or Universalist beliefs. Individuals who held unitarian (nontrinitarian) beliefs but were not affiliated with Unitarian organizations are often referred to as "small 'u unitarians. The same principle can be applied to those who believed in universal salvation but were not members of Universalist organizations.

The heart is a muscular organ in most animals, which pumps blood through the blood vessels of the circulatory system. The pumped blood carries oxygen and nutrients to the body, while carrying metabolic waste such as carbon dioxide to the lungs. In humans, the heart is approximately the size of a closed fist and is located between the lungs, in the middle compartment of the chest.In humans, other mammals, and birds, the heart is divided into four chambers: upper left and right atria and lower left and right ventricles.

Bi-curious is a term for a person , usually someone who is a heterosexual , who is curious or open minded , who is looking for something or someone new , to explore a bit . This person may not be interested in the sexual act itself but just curious about something new . It is also a good way to distinguish someone who is into something or someone who is not interested in anything . For bi-curious, this means you might not necessarily be interested in gay sex but just want to try things out . This is a good thing .

The European Men 's Handball Championship is the official competition for senior men 's national handball teams of Europe and has been taking place each year since 1972. As of 2014, the European Handball Championships is organized by the European Men's Handball Association (EMAHA). The tournament is contested by teams that have qualified through various tournaments. It is the second most popular European Handball event. The European Men 's Handball Championships is usually held in early July or early August in European cities such as Madrid, London, Paris, Amsterdam, Rome, Brussels, Lille, Frankfurt, Stuttgart, Hamburg, Dortmund and Cologne.

Year 1164 (MCLXIV) was a leap year starting on Wednesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  Battle of Renfrew: A Norse-Gaelic army led by Lord Somerled, ruler of the Isles, invades Scotland and is routed by the Scottish forces under the command of Walter fitz Alan and Herbert of Selkirk, bishop of Glasgow. England  January 30 – King Henry II tries to delimit spiritual and royal jurisdictions in the Constitutions of Clarendon, written in large part by his councilor Richard de Luci.

A musician is a person who composes, conducts, or performs music. According to the United States Employment Service, "musician" is a general term used to designate one who follows music as a profession. Musicians include songwriters who compose music as well as write lyrics for songs, conductors who direct a musical performance, or performers who perform for an audience. A music performer is generally either a singer who provides vocals or an instrumentalist who plays a musical instrument. Musicians may perform on their own or as part of a group, band or orchestra.

His Dark Materials is a trilogy of fantasy novels by Philip Pullman consisting of Northern Lights (1995; published as The Golden Compass in North America), The Subtle Knife (1997), and The Amber Spyglass (2000). It follows the coming of age of two children, Lyra Belacqua and Will Parry, as they wander through a series of parallel universes. The novels have won a number of awards, including the Carnegie Medal in 1995 for Northern Lights and the 2001 Whitbread Book of the Year for The Amber Spyglass.

Cambridge  is a university city and the county town of Cambridgeshire, England, on the River Cam approximately  north of London. At the United Kingdom Census 2011, the population of the Cambridge built-up area (which is larger than the remit of Cambridge City Council) was 158,434 including 29,327 students. Cambridge became an important trading centre during the Roman and Viking ages, and there is archaeological evidence of settlement in the area as early as the Bronze Age. The first town charters were granted in the 12th century, although modern city status was not officially conferred until 1951.The University of Cambridge was founded in 1209.

Nitrous oxide, commonly known as laughing gas, nitrous, or nos, is a chemical compound, an oxide of nitrogen with the formula . At room temperature, it is a colourless non-flammable gas, with a slight metallic scent and taste. At elevated temperatures, nitrous oxide is a powerful oxidiser similar to molecular oxygen.Nitrous oxide has significant medical uses, especially in surgery and dentistry, for its anaesthetic and pain reducing effects. Its colloquial name, "laughing gas", coined by Humphry Davy, is due to the euphoric effects upon inhaling it, a property that has led to its recreational use as a dissociative anaesthetic.

Cotton is a soft, fluffy staple fiber that grows in a boll, or protective case, around the seeds of the cotton plants of the genus Gossypium in the mallow family Malvaceae. The fiber is almost pure cellulose, and can contain minor percentages of waxes, fats, pectins, and water. Under natural conditions, the cotton bolls will increase the dispersal of the seeds.The plant is a shrub native to tropical and subtropical regions around the world, including the Americas, Africa, Egypt and India. The greatest diversity of wild cotton species is found in Mexico, followed by Australia and Africa.

Nansen passports , originally and officially stateless persons passports , were internationally recognized refugee travel documents from 1922 to 1938. Some countries, in particular Norway, Sweden and Iceland, have also adopted the passport for non-stateless persons. Contents of Norwegian passports and identification

In the following sections, the first part of each article deals with the official stateless persons passports, while the second part focuses on stateless persons identification documents. The Official Stateless Persons Passport (FolkePass) is issued to Norwegian nationals who are not Norwegian citizens or are stateless and do not have Norwegian citizenship to apply for refugee status (Article 7).

Kevin James Anderson (born March 27, 1962) is an American science fiction author. He has written spin-off novels for Star Wars, StarCraft, Titan A.E. and The X-Files, and with Brian Herbert is the co-author of the Dune prequel series. His original works include the Saga of Seven Suns series and the Nebula Award-nominated Assemblers of Infinity. He has also written several comic books, including the Dark Horse Star Wars series Tales of the Jedi written in collaboration with Tom Veitch, Dark Horse Predator titles, and The X-Files titles for Topps.

The 8 inch ( 203 mm ) M110 self-propelled howitzer is an American-made self-propelled artillery system consisting of an M115A1 105-mm gun, four M113 81-mm guns, four towed M113 90-mm mortars, a 120 mm mortar, two 105-mm gun-turrets and an M113A1 coaxial launcher. It is currently manufactured by the Northrop Grumman company. The howitzer is the largest in the United States and second largest in the world after the US Marine Corps' M109 .50-caliber howitzer. Its role in the war in Afghanistan has become a symbol of success against an enemy that has outgrown the US-made military hardware it was designed and developed for.

Halebidu (IAST: Haḷēbīḍ, literally "old capital, city, encampment" or "ruined city") is a town located in Hassan District, Karnataka, India. Historically known as Dorasamudra or Dwarasamudra, Halebidu became the regal capital of the Hoysala Empire in the 11th century CE. In the modern era literature it is sometimes referred to as Halebeedu or Halebid as the phonetic equivalent, a local name after it was damaged and deserted after being ransacked and looted twice by the forces of the Delhi Sultanate in the 14th century.Halebidu is home to some of the best examples of Hindu and Jain temples with Hoysala architecture.

In the history of cryptography , Typex ( alternatively , Type X or TypeX ) machines were British cipher machines designed in 1875 and built from 1878 to 1891 as part of a government-funded project to upgrade the existing Colossus type machines . Although they were developed for military use, in practice they were also used for civil communications and mail delivery. The machine was based on the designs of Colossus , and was developed by a team from the Royal Engineers. The machine was initially built by Sir Charles Wheatcroft, then the Director of Military Engineering of the Ministry of Munitions until 1891, when he left to take up other positions.

Larry Simon Gelbart (February 25, 1928 – September 11, 2009) was an American television writer, playwright, screenwriter, director and author, most famous as a creator and producer of the television series M*A*S*H, and as co-writer of the Broadway musicals A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum and City of Angels.BiographyEarly lifeGelbart was born in Chicago, Illinois, to Jewish immigrants Harry Gelbart, "a barber since his half of a childhood in Latvia," and Frieda Sturner, who migrated to America from Dąbrowa Górnicza, Poland.

Pope Leo VIII ( 915 – 1 March 965 ) was a Roman prelate who claimed the Holy See from the Emperor Henry II in his first year, and the first Pope during Henry's reign who was not of German birth. His papacy began when he became the first Pope after the Battle of Benevento (933) during the Third Crusade. His pontificate ended with his death and the death of Henry II, in his coronation on 15 June 965. He was succeeded by Gregory VII as the first Pope of the Byzantine Empire in his absence.

Budapest (, ; ) is the capital and most populous city of Hungary. It is the ninth-largest city in the European Union by population within city limits; the city has an estimated population of 1,752,286 over a land area of about . Budapest, which is both a city and county, forms the centre of the Budapest metropolitan area, which has an area of  and a population of 3,303,786, comprising 33% of the population of Hungary.The history of Budapest began when an early Celtic settlement transformed into the Roman town of Aquincum, the capital of Lower Pannonia.

Eastern Europe is the eastern region of Europe . There is no consistent definition of the precise area it covers, however, it is often used to represent Europe's westernmost and northernmost extremity, the Baltic Sea and North Sea. Contents

Europe

Europe is defined by its climate and geography. Europe is a continent made up of a series of individual countries with varying climatic and geometrical characteristics. The climate is the most important factor in determining its geographical characteristics. The European continent is the most well known part of Europe. It was the home of the oldest civilizations and the birthplace of the greatest civilizations throughout history.

A county is a geographical region of a country used for administrative or other purposes in certain modern nations . The use of this term is a recent development in the United States of America and Australia. The US and Australia use the term counties to describe their respective geographic regions. The term has been used in other countries for centuries, for instance in the Caribbean, Africa and North Africa . The term is used in modern English as well as many foreign countries. In the United States the term is generally used for counties, but is also used within the United States as a synonym to the word "county ".

An intranet is a computer network for sharing information , easier communication , collaboration tools , operational systems , and other resources among computers, such as networked servers and other computers. An Intranet can be a standalone network or a virtual network that is connected to the Internet or an extranet which is not connected to the Internet via an IP address. Introduction to Intranets. A Networked Virtual Private Network (VPN or vpn) is a software application or hardware appliance that provides users a way to connect to other people's networks and computers outside of their organization's network.

Pope Leo V was the bishop of Rome and nominal ruler of the Papal States from July 903 to his death in 933, when he passed the papal throne to his brother Pope Urban I (934-1120) and became "Archbishop of Constantinople" ( _papas archi_ ). During his long reign, he ruled through a council held by himself and other popes from 8 October 912 to 15 October 916, and then by the papal council held from 12 November 916 to 5 February 917. The council ended in a definitive settlement of all questions between the papacy and other Christian authorities in the eastern churches.

Montague Rhodes James ( 1 August 1862 – 12 June 1936 ) was an English author , medievalist scholar and soldier. He was a soldier in the British Army during World War I, and later served in India, where he was known as a member of the Indian Scout Movement. He also published works in other languages, such as Hebrew, French and Italian. He served as Regius Professor of Arabic at Oxford University from 1892 until his retirement from that position in 1924. He died on 12 June 1936. Education and military career
Rhodes was born in Leicester, the son of the Reverend Samuel Rhodes.

Year 968 (CMLXVIII) was a leap year starting on Wednesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  Emperor Nikephoros II receives a Bulgarian embassy led by Prince Boris (the son of Tsar Peter I of Bulgaria), with a plea for help against the invading Kievan Rus'. Nikephoros, occupied in the East, is unable to support him. Instead he sends envoys to summon the Pechenegs to aid Boris. They besiege Kiev, but Grand Prince Sviatoslav I (on campaign in Bulgaria) returns with a Kievan relief force, and defeats the Pechenegs.

Year 870 ( DCCCLXX ) was a common year starting on Sunday ( link will display the full calendar ) and a leap day was also a Sunday . This is a link to the page on DCCL, which contains the full calendar . The links to the years starting on Sunday display only the years with a Sunday year, and a few with no years. Contents

For a full list of events, see DCCLXIV or DCCLIX

Events

April 17–18, 478
Darius I becomes the king of Persia, reigning from 497 to 524. Darius becomes the first king of the Sasanian dynasty.

Humour (Commonwealth English) or humor (American English) is the tendency of experiences to provoke laughter and provide amusement. The term derives from the humoral medicine of the ancient Greeks, which taught that the balance of fluids in the human body, known as humours (Latin: humor, "body fluid"), controlled human health and emotion.People of all ages and cultures respond to humour. Most people are able to experience humour—be amused, smile or laugh at something funny (such as a pun or joke)—and thus are considered to have a sense of humour.

The Novikov self-consistency principle, also known as the Novikov self-consistency conjecture and Larry Niven's law of conservation of history, is a principle developed by Russian physicist Igor Dmitriyevich Novikov in the mid-1980s. Novikov intended it to solve the problem of paradoxes in time travel, which is theoretically permitted in certain solutions of general relativity that contain what are known as closed timelike curves. The principle asserts that if an event exists that would cause a paradox or any "change" to the past whatsoever, then the probability of that event is zero.

was the 68th emperor of Japan , according to the traditional order of succession.Go-Ichijō 's reign spanned the years from 968 to 971. His successor was  who reigned for the next two decades, until the establishment of the Heihachō by the Emperor Go-Funō. Go-Ichijō's reign was characterized by a rapid expansion of the territory, a rapid growth of the number of government offices, and the construction and development of the capital of Nara. His reign also saw the consolidation of a number of regional power centers, including Nara's position as the administrative center for the entire southern Kōzō region.

Giovanni Paisiello (or Paesiello; 9 May 1740 – 5 June 1816) was an Italian composer of the Classical era, and was the most popular opera composer of the late 1700s. His operatic style influenced Mozart and Rossini, and his music was championed by Haydn and Beethoven.LifePaisiello was born in Taranto in the Apulia region and educated by the Jesuits there. He became known for his beautiful singing voice and in 1754 was sent to the Conservatorio di S. Onofrio at Naples, where he studied under Francesco Durante, and eventually became assistant master.

A wide area network (WAN) is a telecommunications network that extends over a large geographic area. Wide area networks are often established with leased telecommunication circuits.Businesses, as well as schools and government entities, use wide area networks to relay data to staff, students, clients, buyers and suppliers from various locations around the world. In essence, this mode of telecommunication allows a business to effectively carry out its daily function regardless of location. The Internet may be considered a WAN.Design optionsThe textbook definition of a WAN is a computer network spanning regions, countries, or even the world.

This is a list of monarchs who ruled over East Francia, and the Kingdom of Germany (Regnum Teutonicum), from the division of the Frankish Empire in 843 until the collapse of the German Empire in 1918.Note on titlesThe Kingdom of Germany started out as the eastern section of the Frankish kingdom, which was split by the Treaty of Verdun in 843. The rulers of the eastern area thus called themselves rex Francorum ("king of the Franks"), rex Francorum orientalium ("king of the East Franks"), and later just rex.

Dementia manifests as a set of related symptoms, which usually surface when the brain is damaged by injury or disease. The symptoms involve progressive impairments in memory, thinking, and behavior, which negatively impact a person's ability to function and carry out everyday activities. Aside from memory impairment and a disruption in thought patterns, the most common symptoms include emotional problems, difficulties with language, and decreased motivation. The symptoms may be described as occurring in a continuum over several stages. Consciousness is not affected. Dementia ultimately has a significant effect on the individual, caregivers, and relationships in general.

Willow Rosenberg is a fictional character created for the fantasy television series Buffy the Vampire Slayer ( 1997–2003 ) . Willow is one of the main characters who are the main characters in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer television series, which is set in the city of Sunnydale. Witch Slayer
Witch Slayer is the character that is responsible for killing the other characters in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer television series. He was introduced in the first season when Willow is killed by a werewolf, and he has been the main character of the show since the third season.

The Who are an English rock band formed in London in 1964 . Their classic lineup consisted of lead singer and guitarist Pete Townshend (vocals, guitars, keyboards), drummer Keith Moon (vocals, guitars), bassist John Entenza (vocals, guitars) and singer Roger Daltrey (bass guitar). Their most famous album was the 1971 album Quadrophenia, which reached No.2 on the Billboard album chart for five weeks. Other notable releases were their 1970 album Who's Next, followed by their 1975 and 1979 albums Back in Black. The latter was also a hit in the United States, peaking at No.

In linguistics , an adjective ( abbreviated ) is a word that modifies a noun or noun phrase or describes its properties. Adjectives can come from several grammatical categories. In English, all adjectives come from the first of the three grammatical categories, adjectival noun phrases. These include adjectives used as noun modifiers, adjectival noun phrases, as adjectival determiners (or adjectival pronouns). In most cases, the word for an adjective has a special meaning; that is, in some cases the word means something like "a noun modifier of an adjective" or "an adjective used as a noun".

This list of Anuran families shows all extant families of Anura. Anura is an order of animals in the class Amphibia that includes frogs and toads. More than 5,000 species are described in the order. The living anurans are typically divided into three suborders: Archaeobatrachia, Mesobatrachia, and Neobatrachia. This classification is based on such morphological features as the number of vertebrae, the structure of the pectoral girdle, and the morphology of tadpoles.TaxonomyThe archaeobatrachians are the most primitive of frogs. These frogs have morphological characteristics which are found mostly in extinct frogs, and are absent in most of the modern frog species.

An ion thruster , ion drive , or ion engine is a form of electric propulsion used for spacecraft propulsion, in space travel or other space-related applications. An ion thruster uses electricity to move ions through a gap between two electrodes (or electrodes and a beam). As ions pass from one electrode into the gap and move to the opposite one, they emit particles (photons or ions) when they encounter a collision with the wall or another ion. An ion drive uses electricity to move ions through the gap and create a pressure wave which accelerates ions.

A radionuclide ( radioactive nuclide , radioisotope or radioactive isotope ) is a nuclide that has excess nuclear energy , as in a supernova or other such event , and which decays into other elements of the same family. The term is used to describe a series of radioactive substances that emit gamma rays or beta decay to other radionuclides , with the rate of decay of radioactive nuclei determined by the time interval between the emission of a photon and its detection. The radionuclides of a particular isotope family are called radionuclides . Radioactive nuclei emit radiation or beta radiation in the process of nuclear decay.

Year 950 (CML) was a common year starting on Tuesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  Arab–Byzantine War: A Hamdanid army (30,000 men) led by Sayf al-Dawla raids into  Byzantine theme Anatolia. He defeats Bardas Phokas, but is then ambushed on his return and heavily defeated by Leo Phokas. Europe  November 22 – King Lothair II dies at Turin (possibly poisoned by Berengar of Ivrea). Berengar is crowned king of Italy and imprisons Lothair's now 19-year-old widow, Adelaide for four months at Como.

Dorset ( ; archaically : Dorsetshire ) is a county in South West England on the English Channel coast . The name is derived from a Celtic word meaning “deep” and “hollow” and it was later used to name a small area of land in what is now the Cotswolds region of the West Country. It is best known today as the home of the Dorset Saints and their successors in the Anglican Church and of a few other denominations, as well as of the Dorset Caves. Geography and topography

Geographically, it is an elongated county extending southwards into Dorset from Somerset.

Poznań University of Technology, PUT (Polish name: Politechnika Poznańska) is a university in Poznań, Poland. Poznań University of Technology is known as one of the best technical universities in Poland. URAP ranked PUT as in top 6% of world universities and Webometrics ranked it at no. 842 in the world by Google citations for the year 2015. In 1995 it became the first Polish university to become a member of the Conference of European Schools for Advanced Engineering Education and Research (CESAER), an organization comprising the best technical universities in Europe.

A white cane is a device used by many people who are blind or visually impaired. A white cane primarily allows its user to scan their surroundings for obstacles or orientation marks, but is also helpful for onlookers in identifying the user as blind or visually impaired and taking appropriate care. The latter is the reason for the cane's white colour, which in many jurisdictions is mandatory.Variants Long cane: Designed primarily as a mobility tool used to detect objects in the path of a user. Cane length depends upon the height of a user, and traditionally extends from the floor to the user's sternum.

An anti-tank guided missile ( ATGM ) , anti-tank missile , anti-tank guided weapon ( ATGW ) or anti-armor guided weapons ( AGW ) is a weapon system designed to penetrate armor on the battlefield. It differs from a tank, in that armor protection is not provided; rather, armor is designed to limit the ability of the weapon to penetrate it. In contrast, an anti-armor guided ( AGA ) or anti-aircraft weapon is capable of destroying a target with the same armor as it is being used on. The term anti-tank missile (ATM) has been used in this context for many years.

Millets are a group of highly variable small-seeded grasses , widely grown around the world as cereal crops or grains . They are characterized by being high yielding, and in some cases are even resistant to pests and diseases. The most important feature of the grain is the size of its kernels. The flour is made up of many small particles of the endosperm of the wheat, and its protein is mostly in the form of small globular proteins . The most important type of the protein is gluten. Grains have to have the correct proportion of gluten and protein.

Cell division is the process by which a parent cell divides into two or more daughter cells. Cell division usually occurs as part of a larger cell cycle. In eukaryotes, there are two distinct types of cell division; a vegetative division, whereby each daughter cell is genetically identical to the parent cell (mitosis), and a reproductive cell division, whereby the number of chromosomes in the daughter cells is reduced by half to produce haploid gametes (meiosis). In cell biology, mitosis (/maɪˈtoʊsɪs/) is a part of the cell cycle, in which, replicated chromosomes are separated into two new nuclei.

SPARC (Scalable Processor Architecture) is a reduced instruction set computing (RISC) instruction set architecture originally developed by Sun Microsystems. Its design was strongly influenced by the experimental Berkeley RISC system developed in the early 1980s. First developed in 1986 and released in 1987, SPARC was one of the most successful early commercial RISC systems, and its success led to the introduction of similar RISC designs from a number of vendors through the 1980s and 90s.The first implementation of the original 32-bit architecture (SPARC V7) was used in Sun's Sun-4 workstation and server systems, replacing their earlier Sun-3 systems based on the Motorola 68000 series of processors.

Mercury ( ; ) is a major god in Roman religion and mythology , being one of the 12 Dii Divi Numeri, and one of the 20 Dii Mai Mundi. He is the Roman god of the sun , and the sun is a symbol of Mercury. The Romans worshipped Mercury on the day of his birth, and this was considered a great day. It was believed that he would be reborn as a baby, and that he was born on January 1, with the first day of the solar year being January 1.

Year 874 (DCCCLXXIV) was a common year starting on Friday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  Salomon, duke ('king') of Brittany, is murdered by a faction which includes his son-in-law Pascweten and Gurvand, son-in-law of late ruler Erispoe. After Salomon's death they divide the country, and Pascweten and Gurvand co-rule Brittany. Svatopluk I, ruler (knyaz) of Great Moravia, concludes a peace treaty at Forchheim (Northern Bavaria). He is able to expand his territories outside the Frankish sphere, and subjugates the Vistulans.Kirschbaum 2007, p. 121.

Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous – Shoemaker (NEAR Shoemaker), renamed after its 1996 launch in honor of planetary scientist Eugene Shoemaker, was a robotic space probe designed by the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory for NASA to study the near-Earth asteroid Eros from close orbit over a period of a year. It was the first spacecraft to successfully orbit an asteroid and also land on an asteroid. In February 2000, the mission succeeded in closing in with the asteroid and afterwards orbited it several times. On February 12, 2001, the mission succeeded in touching down on the asteroid.

The PalmPilot Personal and PalmPilot Professional are the second generation of Palm PDA devices produced by Palm Inc ( then a subsidiary of Compaq), and are equipped with touch-screen display. Originally developed by Palm Inc and released by Compaq in 1992, the Palm PDA became popular with people who wanted to keep track of their finances in a simple handheld device with a touchscreen, allowing users to save, exchange, manage and store their bank balances in a few simple clicks of the finger. Palm Inc. marketed the Palm PDA as "Pocket Money" in order to attract customers.

Year 1054 (MLIV) was a common year starting on Saturday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  Sultan Tughril leads a large Seljuk army out of Azerbaijan into Armenia, possibly to consolidate his frontier, while providing an incentive to his Turkoman allies in the form of plunder. Tughril divides his army into four columns, ordering three to veer off to the north to raid into central and northern Armenia, while he takes the fourth column towards Lake Van. The Seljuk Turks capture and sack the fortress city of Artchesh, after an 8-day siege.

Lanford Wilson ( April 13 , 1937March 24 , 2011 ) was an American playwright . His work , as noted in his Wikipedia biography, includes a number of theatrical plays , including the musical Broadway: The Musical . A native of the Bronx , Wilson spent most of his adult life in Manhattan. "The most difficult work of all is the theater, because there isn't anything to do. You can sit and stare into space but it doesn't mean anything unless somebody else sees it." — Lanford Wilson on Broadway: The Musical .

Anthony John Hancock (12 May 1924 – 25 June 1968) was an English comedian and actor.High-profile during the 1950s and early 1960s, he had a major success with his BBC series Hancock's Half Hour, first broadcast on radio from 1954, then on television from 1956, in which he soon formed a strong professional and personal bond with comic actor Sid James. Although Hancock's decision to cease working with James, when it became known in early 1960, disappointed many at the time, his last BBC series in 1961 contains some of his best-remembered work (including "The Blood Donor" and "The Radio Ham").

Thermonuclear fusion is the process of atoms combining or “ fusing ” together with huge amounts of heat . There are a great many theories on what makes this happen , and I have read and watched a multitude of books and documentaries . I have watched a documentary on it, and I have a strong opinion on it , because it seems that everyone has it wrong . If you are interested in learning more, go to the Wikipedia link . If not, there are hundreds of videos available that explain what happens, and I have read a great deal on this .

In combinatorics and in experimental design , a Latin square is an n × n array filled with n different symbols that share no symbol. In other words, it is a square where the diagonals are filled. A Latin square is called a mirror square if an element is repeated on the right side. Latin squares 
 A Latin square has the same number of rows and columns. If the rows are numbered from 1 to n and the columns are numbered from 1 to m, there are m−1 squares on the first row, m squares on the first column and n squares on the last row.

Medina, officially Al Madinah Al Munawwarah  and also commonly simplified as Madīnah or Madinah , is the second-holiest city in Islam and the capital of the Medina Province of Saudi Arabia. , the estimated population of the city is 1,488,782, making it the fourth-most populous city in the country. Located at the core of the Medina Province in the western reaches of the country, the city is distributed over , of which  constitutes the city's urban area, while the rest is occupied by the Hejaz Mountains, empty valleys, agricultural spaces and older dormant volcanoes.Medina is generally considered to be the "cradle of Islamic culture and civilization".

The MGM-31A Pershing was the missile used in the Pershing 1 and Pershing 1a field artillery missile systems. It was a solid-fueled two-stage ballistic missile designed and built by Martin Marietta to replace the PGM-11 Redstone missile as the primary nuclear-capable theater-level weapon of the United States Army and replaced the MGM-1 Matador cruise missiles operated by the German Air Force. Pershing later replaced the European-based MGM-13 Mace cruise missiles deployed by the United States Air Force and the German Air Force. Development began in 1958, with the first test missile fired in 1960, the Pershing 1 system deployed in 1963 and the improved Pershing 1a deployed in 1969.

Wool is the textile fibre obtained from sheep and other animals, including cashmere and mohair from goats, qiviut from muskoxen, hide and fur clothing from bison, angora from rabbits, and other types of wool from camelids.Wool consists of protein together with a small percentage of lipids. In this regard it is chemically quite distinct from cotton, which is mainly cellulose.CharacteristicsWool is produced by follicles which are small cells located in the skin. These follicles are located in the upper layer of the skin called the epidermis and push down into the second skin layer called the dermis as the wool fibers grow.

Sir Philip Nicholas Outram Pullman ( born 19 October 1946 ) is an English writer . His books include the bestsellers The Secret Garden and The Wind in the Willows. He is the author, most recently, of The Tale of Tin Men, which describes an early attempt to build an electric train in Victorian England. Pullman was born in South Africa, and raised in South Africa in the 1940s and 1950s, then lived for some time in England, and then returned briefly to the US. In 2005, Pullman received the Nobel Prize in Literature .

A drought is an event of prolonged shortages in the water supply, whether atmospheric (below-average precipitation), surface water or ground water. A drought can last for months or years, or may be declared after as few as 15 days. It can have a substantial impact on the ecosystem and agriculture of the affected region and harm to the local economy. Annual dry seasons in the tropics significantly increase the chances of a drought developing and subsequent bush fires. Periods of heat can significantly worsen drought conditions by hastening evaporation of water vapour.Drought is a recurring feature of the climate in most parts of the world.

Year 1107 (MCVII) was a common year starting on Tuesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Scotland January 8 – King Edgar (the Valiant) dies at Edinburgh Castle after a 9-year reign. He is succeeded by his brother Alexander I (the Fierce), who is married to Sybilla of Normandy (an illegitimate daughter of King Henry I). A split of unity, between Alexander and his younger brother David I, makes David co-ruler in Lothian and Strathclyde (Southern Scotland). He does not receive the title of king, but of "Prince of the Cumbrians".

Montevideo is the capital and largest city of Uruguay . According to the 2011 census , the city proper has a population of 947,891 inhabitants. It is the largest in Uruguay by land area with a total area of 632.7 km² and it is also the most populated by population of Uruguayan capital. It is the home of the National Theatre of Uruguay and is one of the few cities in the world that can be considered a major tourist destination. It was the capital city of Uruguay from 1853 to 1856, then it was the capital of the Argentine Republic until 1858.

A seal is a device for making an impression in wax, clay, paper, or some other medium, including an embossment on paper, and is also the impression thus made. The original purpose was to authenticate a document, or to prevent interference with a package or envelope by applying a seal which had to be broken to open the container (hence the modern English verb "to seal", which implies secure closing without an actual wax seal).The seal-making device is also referred to as the seal matrix or die; the imprint it creates as the seal impression (or, more rarely, the sealing).

Linus Carl Pauling ( ; February 28 , 1901 – August 19 , 1994 ) was an American chemist , professor , researcher and author. He was born on 28 February 1901 in New York City, where he completed his first exams at age 12. In 1911, he attended New York University, graduating in June 1912. Later he graduated from Columbia University in 1917 with a Bachelor of Science in chemistry and was awarded a Ph.D. in 1919. In 1920, he completed a post-graduate diploma at Columbia University, and was appointed to the faculty of Columbia University in 1920.

Year 926 ( CMXXVI ) was a common year starting on Sunday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. The only exception was a leap day occurring in August, Saturday, not on Sunday, which was the day the calendar was reformed. The Julian calendar introduced the leap second, a second added on Sunday to every second Sunday of the previous calendar year, causing an additional day every year, and changing the hour of the clock used in measuring time. The next calendar reform occurred in 3 September 478, and the next reform will occur on 1 January 2060.

Pope Leo VII ( ; died 13 July 939 ) was the bishop of Rome and nominal ruler of the Western Roman Empire until his death on 13 July 939, after which his son and successor was elected by the Pope, John III. Early life and episcopacy
Leo was born to Leo IV, who in turn was descended from Emperor Constantine V, and was the son of his brother Theophanes I of Alexandria, the brother of Empress Constans, and of the younger son of his own mother, Constantine V, Constantine's brother.

In the 1980s, the telecommunications industry expected that digital services would follow much the same pattern as voice services did on the public switched telephone network, and conceived an end-to-end circuit switched service, known as Broadband Integrated Services Digital Network (B-ISDN).HistoryBefore B-ISDN, the original ISDN attempted to substitute the analog telephone system with a digital system which was appropriate for both voice and non-voice traffic. Obtaining worldwide agreement on the basic rate interface standard was expected to lead to a large user demand for ISDN equipment, hence leading to mass production and inexpensive ISDN chips.

The Palmer Raids were a series of raids conducted in November 1919 and January 1920 by the United States Department of Justice under the administration of President Woodrow Wilson to capture and arrest suspected socialists, mostly Italian immigrants and Eastern European immigrants and especially anarchists and communists, and deport them from the United States. The raids particularly targeted Italian immigrants and Eastern European Jewish immigrants with alleged leftist ties, with particular focus on Italian anarchists and immigrant leftist labor activists. The raids and arrests occurred under the leadership of Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer, with 3,000 arrested.

A gold standard is a monetary system in which the standard economic unit of account is based on a fixed quantity of gold. The gold standard was the basis for the international monetary system from the 1870s to the early 1920s, and from the late 1920s to 1932 as well as from 1944 until 1971 when the United States unilaterally terminated convertibility of the US dollar to gold foreign central banks, effectively ending the Bretton Woods system. Many states still hold substantial gold reserves.Historically, the silver standard and bimetallism have been more common than the gold standard.

Rococo (, also ), less commonly Roccoco or Late Baroque, is an exceptionally ornamental and theatrical style of architecture, art and decoration which combines asymmetry, scrolling curves, gilding, white and pastel colors, sculpted molding, and trompe-l'œil frescoes to create surprise and the illusion of motion and drama. It is often described as the final expression of the Baroque movement.The Rococo style began in France in the 1730s as a reaction against the more formal and geometric Louis XIV style. It was known as the "style Rocaille", or "Rocaille style".

A gold standard is a monetary system in which the standard economic unit of account is based on a fixed commodity or standard commodity that is the same in all parts of the economy. A commodity can be defined as any tangible physical object of economic or monetary significance. A standard commodity can also be defined as a set of comparable goods that share some common physical characteristics or are produced by the same methods. Gold, as a standard, is the best-established commodity in monetary systems as it is widely used for the calculation of monetary units. Gold has many other advantages as a monetary unit over silver.

Parsifal ( WWV 111 ) is an opera in three acts by Richard Wagner with the libretto by the composer. It was first performed on 24 April 1876 at Bayreuth under the auspices of the Gesellschaft für Opern- und Tanztheater ( Society for Opera and Theatrical Performance ) based in Bayreuth. The music, composed between 1851 and 1855, has been hailed as a landmark in the evolution of music drama. Background
In 1851 Wagner began work on Parsifal with his friend, the German critic and librettist Theobald Buhl, in an opera that was originally called Die Walpurgisnacht.

Year 881 (DCCCLXXXI) was a common year starting on Sunday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  February 12 – King Charles the Fat, the third son of the late Louis the German, is crowned as Holy Roman Emperor by Pope John VIII at Rome. August 3 – Battle of Saucourt-en-Vimeu: The West Frankish kings Louis III, and his brother Carloman II, rout Viking raiders (near Abbeville). Britain  Battle of the Conwy: King Anarawd of Gwynedd (Wales) initiates a revenge attack on the Mercian armies, and defeats them on the River Conwy.

Year 952 (CMLII) was a leap year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events <onlyinclude>By placeEurope  Summer – At the Reichstag in Augsburg (assembled by King Otto I), joined by German nobles and bishops, Berengar of Ivrea pays homage. He becomes a vassal of the East Frankish Kingdom. Otto leaves a strong garrison at Pavia in the hands of his son-in-law Conrad the Red, duke of Lotharingia.Scotland  King Constantine II dies at the monastery of St. Andrews (where he has been retired since 943).

Turbo Pascal is a software development system that includes a compiler and an integrated development environment ( IDE ) for building application programs (programs) that can be executed on either the PDP-11 or the HP-20 computers. It was initially written from scratch to support the IBM-compatible PDP-10, but it evolved to support IBM compatible PC-BSD and other computer systems as well. It is an open source product licensed under the AGPL. The Turbo Pascal code base is organized in several modules: compiler, debugger, interpreter, source code compiler (SCC), compiler and debugger, interpreter, linker, utilities, library and documentation, and documentation.

Albert the Magnanimous KG , elected King of the Romans as Albert II ( 10 August 139727 October 1439 ) , was the second son of Henry the Young King of the Romans ( King Henry VIII ) and his wife Catherine ( KG ) , sister of Henry V ( King Henry IV ) and the future Richard II ( Richard III ) of England. His father, the Young King, was the only male heir of the Kingdom of England and therefore a direct descendant of King Stephen. Henry the Young King also had two other daughters - Mary and Elizabeth.

Zooarchaeology (sometimes incorrectly archaeozoology), also known as faunal analysis, is a branch of archaeology that studies remains of animals from archaeological sites. Faunal remains are the items left behind when an animal dies. These include bones, shells, hair, chitin, scales, hides, proteins and DNA. Of these items, bones and shells are the ones that occur most frequently at archaeological sites where faunal remains can be found. Most of the time, a majority of these faunal remains do not survive. They often decompose or break because of various circumstances.

The European Organization for Nuclear Research , known as CERN ( ; ; derived from the name ) , is a major physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland . It was founded by the French Nobel laureate Pierre Duhem in 1954, and the first nuclear reactor built there was opened in 1957. , it is home to approximately one hundred scientists working in nuclear research and physics, as well as more than 150 graduate students. It has more than 5,000 staff, of whom about half work on accelerator research, and the rest in nuclear physics research and analysis.

Year 884 ( DCCCLXXXIV ) was a leap year starting on Wednesday ( link will display the full calendar )

20 October 1285 ( Monday)

The following year would be a leap year starting on Thursday, but on Saturday it would no longer be a leap day. Instead, from Monday to Saturday it would be a sabbatical day, and the following Sunday would be a leap day. However, that is not the way that leap days are reckoned in the Julian calendar. The Gregorian calendar, in effect at this stage, is based on the calendar used in England, but with leap days.

A monopropellant rocket ( or `` monochemical rocket '' ) is a rocket that uses a single chemical as its fuel. A rocket can have multiple fuels and, for a number of uses, can be used to carry an aero engine of some kind. A rocket is used for space launch, military launch, medical or other applications where one might use a rocket to deliver payloads, or where it is useful to transport the payloads through space in a capsule, for example. The term "rocket" is often used in reference to both types of rockets.

Pizza Hut is an American multinational restaurant chain and international franchise founded in 1958 in Wichita, Kansas by Dan and Frank Carney. They serve their signature pan pizza and other dishes including pasta, breadsticks and desserts.The chain has 17,639 restaurants worldwide as of 2020,making it the world's largest pizza chain by number of locations.It is a subsidiary of Yum! Brands, Inc., one of the world's largest restaurant companies.HistoryPizza Hut was founded on June 15, 1958, by two brothers, Dan and Frank Carney, both Wichita State students, as a single location in Wichita, Kansas.

Year 1155 (MCLV) was a common year starting on Saturday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  Siege of Tortona: German forces capture the citadel of Tortona (after a two-month siege). The city is razed to the ground, including the graves. June 18 – King Frederick I (Barbarossa) is crowned as Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire by Pope Adrian IV at St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. Arnold of Brescia is exiled by Adrian IV and forced to flee. He is arrested by imperial forces; hanged and his body burned at the stake in Rome.

Mercury (;  ) is a major god in Roman religion and mythology, being one of the 12 Dii Consentes within the ancient Roman pantheon. He is the god of financial gain, commerce, eloquence, messages, communication (including divination), travelers, boundaries, luck, trickery, and thieves; he also serves as the guide of souls to the underworld.In Roman mythology, he was considered to be either the son of Maia, one of the seven daughters of the Titan Atlas, and Jupiter, or of Caelus and Dies.

In mathematics , a Möbius strip , band , or loop ( , ; ) , also spelled Mobius or Moby, is an invariant closed curve in the plane that is tangent to the complex plane at two points, and whose image by the inverse function is a single point .
