Möbius strips were introduced in the 18th century. A Möbius strip that does not enclose a point on the real line or a complex number has the shape of a figure eight. (It is called a figure eight because its sides are two lines drawn from the two given points.)

Poznań University of Technology , PUT ( Polish name : Politechnika Poznańska ) is a university in Poznań , Poland, with about 8 000 students and 6 000 professors. It has two departments: Computer Engineering and Electrical Engineering. It also offers a Master Degree, Bachelor Degree, and Diploma Degree in several disciplines. Its headquarters are located in Gmina Złocienice 1. It is a member of European Association of National Universities

History

1792. Founded as a private university
1912. Founded as an Institute of Higher Technical Education by Royal decree
1924. Founded as a National Technical College of Agriculture and Commerce
1925.

Civil liberties are guarantees and freedoms that governments commit not to abridge, either by constitution, legislation, or judicial interpretation, without due process. Though the scope of the term differs between countries, civil liberties may include the freedom of conscience, freedom of press, freedom of religion, freedom of expression, freedom of assembly, the right to security and liberty, freedom of speech, the right to privacy, the right to equal treatment under the law and due process, the right to a fair trial, and the right to life.

Keep the Aspidistra Flying, first published in 1936, is a socially critical novel by George Orwell. It is set in 1930s London. The main theme is Gordon Comstock's romantic ambition to defy worship of the money-god and status, and the dismal life that results.BackgroundOrwell wrote the book in 1934 and 1935, when he was living at various locations near Hampstead in London, and drew on his experiences in these and the preceding few years. At the beginning of 1928 he lived in lodgings in Portobello Road from where he started his tramping expeditions, sleeping rough and roaming the poorer parts of London.

Giovanni Pacini (17 February 17966 December 1867) was an Italian composer, best known for his operas. Pacini was born in Catania, Sicily, the son of the buffo Luigi Pacini, who was to appear in the premieres of many of Giovanni's operas. The family was of Tuscan origin, living in Catania when the composer was born.His first 25 or so operas were written when Gioachino Rossini dominated the Italian operatic stage. But Pacini's operas were "rather superficial", a fact which, later, he candidly admitted in his Memoirs.

Pope Leo VI (880 – 12 February 929) was the bishop of Rome and nominal ruler of the Papal States for just over seven months, from June 928 to his death. His pontificate occurred during the period known as the Saeculum obscurum.Family and early careerLeo VI was born into a Roman family, and his father was Christophorus, who had been primicerius under Pope John VIII around the year 876. Tradition has it that he was a member of the Sanguini family. Before his pontificate, Leo served as the cardinal-priest of Santa Susanna.PontificateLeo was elected pope around June 928, during a period of anarchy.

Hebron ( ;  ) is a Palestinian city in the southern West Bank,  south of Jerusalem. Nestled in the Judaean Mountains, it lies  above sea level. The largest city in the West Bank, and the second largest in the Palestinian territories after Gaza, it has a population of over 215,000 Palestinians (2016), and seven hundred Jewish settlers concentrated on the outskirts of the Old City of Hebron. It includes the Cave of the Patriarchs, which Judeo-Christian and Islamic traditions all designate as the burial site of three key patriarchal/matriarchal couples.

Radiohead are an English rock band formed in Abingdon , Oxfordshire , in 1985 . The band consists of Thom Yorke , a Scottish-born composer of electronic music , vocalist Robert Plant , keyboardist Roger Daltrey and bass guitarist Colin Greenwood . They gained popularity when they released the EP The Singles in 1986, and were signed by EMI . The following year saw their debut single "Wake Up Dead" reach number three in the UK singles chart and was featured on MTV's Video Hits of the Week, and their second single, "I Will Wait", reached number five on the UK singles chart .

Isis (;  Ēse; ; Meroitic:  Wos[a] or Wusa) was a major goddess in ancient Egyptian religion whose worship spread throughout the Greco-Roman world. Isis was first mentioned in the Old Kingdom  as one of the main characters of the Osiris myth, in which she resurrects her slain brother and husband, the divine king Osiris, and produces and protects his heir, Horus. She was believed to help the dead enter the afterlife as she had helped Osiris, and she was considered the divine mother of the pharaoh, who was likened to Horus.

East Malaysia , also known as Sabah, Sarawak and Labuan  or Malaysian Borneo, is the part of Malaysia on and near the island of Borneo, the world's third largest island. It consists of the Malaysian states of Sabah and Sarawak, as well as the Federal Territory of Labuan. Labuan is an island in a small archipelago near the coast of Sabah. East Malaysia lies to the east of Peninsular Malaysia (also known as West Malaysia), the part of the country on the Malay Peninsula. The two are separated by the South China Sea.East Malaysia is less populated and has less developed settlements than West Malaysia.

`` The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas '' is a 1973 work of short philosophical fiction by American writer Richard Powers. It is the second of two books on the metaphysical theme. The story takes place in the early 20th century and centers on the death of a family of people who, like the protagonist in the first volume of the trilogy, have "walked away from Omelas." It is the first of three collections of philosophical essays in the form of "epic" stories by Powers. The fourth volume of these was published in 1975.

The pancreas is an organ of the digestive system and endocrine system of vertebrates . In humans , it is the largest endocrine organ and plays an important role in the metabolic regulation and energy balance. Pancreatic β cells secrete hormones such as glucagon and insulin, and secrete insulin in the early stage of diabetes. Pancreatic α cells synthesize insulin, which in turn, regulates the glucose homeostasis. Pancreatic D cells synthesize and release glucagon . Glucagon is the major hormone secreted from the pancreatic α cells to stimulate gluconeogenesis. In addition to this, pancreatic D cells also release insulin-like peptides (IRP), such as amylin .

Paul Lansky ( born June 18 , 1944 , in New York ) is an American composer.BiographyPaul Lansky ( born June 18 , 1944 , in New York )is an American composer.He received the Academy of Distinguished Music Composers Award.He is also known as an educator and a composer in his work.His music has been performed in concerts and films by a variety of artists, including David Byrne, Sarah McLachlan, Steve Miller, Tim Burton, Tim Rice, and others.Lansky has written over 40 works for films and television. Lansky is also known as an educator. He was a visiting professor at Yale University from 1987 to 1991.

The Lhotshampa or Lhotsampa people are a heterogeneous Bhutanese people of Nepalese descent . `` Lhotshampa '' , which means the people are more peaceful , is also a synonym of Nepalis and Nepalis are often called as lhotshampa as well. The Lhotshampa are a group of Bhutanese refugees who have settled down in India and Nepal. In the early 1990s, the Indian government of India and the Government of Nepal, as part of an anti-Bengali campaign, started a campaign to convert Bhutanis into Hindu. In the process, a great many Bhutanis lost their land, homes and livelihood.

In economics, inflation refers to a general progressive increase in prices of goods and services in an economy. When the general price level rises, each unit of currency buys fewer goods and services; consequently, inflation corresponds to a reduction in the purchasing power of money. The opposite of inflation is deflation, a sustained decrease in the general price level of goods and services. The common measure of inflation is the inflation rate, the annualised percentage change in a general price index.Prices will not all increase at the same rates. Attaching a representative value to a set of prices is an instance of the index number problem.

Cannabis is a genus of flowering plants in the family Cannabaceae . The number of species within the genus is about 150. They are commonly grown for the cannabis plant itself and are grown for its resin. They have a number of common characteristics. Cannabis plants are tall and have a stalk that runs the length of the plant. When mature, the plant will produce a head (the top part of a mature plant) and the flowering stalk will continue into the middle of the plant. The head is usually spherical. Its color can vary from light green to a brown color.

Pope John XXII (; 1244 – 4 December 1334), born Jacques Duèze (or d'Euse), was head of the Catholic Church from 7 August 1316 to his death in 1334.He was the second and longest-reigning Avignon Pope, elected by the Conclave of Cardinals, which was assembled in Lyon through the work of King Louis X's brother Philip, the Count of Poitiers, later King Philip V of France. Like his predecessor, Clement V, Pope John centralized power and income in the Papacy and lived a princely life in Avignon.

The RQ-3 DarkStar (known as Tier III- or "Tier three minus" during development) is an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). Its first flight was on March 29, 1996. The Department of Defense terminated DarkStar in January 1999, after determining the UAV was not aerodynamically stable and was not meeting cost and performance objectives.Design and development The RQ-3 DarkStar was designed as a "high-altitude endurance UAV", and incorporated stealth aircraft technology to make it difficult to detect, which allowed it to operate within heavily defended airspace, unlike the Northrop Grumman RQ-4 Global Hawk, which is unable to operate except under conditions of air supremacy.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration ( NOAA ) is an American scientific and regulatory agency within the United States Department of Commerce, with responsibility for the United States' ocean and marine ecosystems. NOAA is a scientific and regulatory agency charged with protecting and managing the world's coastal and marine ecosystems, and with promoting ocean and atmospheric sustainability through research, science and management activities. NOAA operates under the direction of the Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, and is headed by a four-member Scientific Advisory Board ( SAB ).

Turandot ( , ; see below) is an opera in three acts by Giacomo Puccini, posthumously completed by Franco Alfano in 1926, and set to a libretto in Italian by Giuseppe Adami and Renato Simoni. Turandot best-known aria is "Nessun dorma", which became globally popular in the 1990s following Luciano Pavarotti's performance of it for the 1990 FIFA World Cup.Though Puccini first became interested in the subject matter when reading Friedrich Schiller's 1801 adaptation, he based his work more closely on the earlier play Turandot (1762) by Count Carlo Gozzi.

Bruce Lee (; November 27, 1940 – July 20, 1973), born Lee Jun-fan , was a Hong Kong and American martial artist, martial arts instructor, actor, director, screenwriter, producer, and philosopher. He was the founder of Jeet Kune Do, a hybrid martial arts philosophy drawing from different combat disciplines that is often credited with paving the way for modern mixed martial arts (MMA). Lee is considered by critics, media, and other martial artists to be the most influential martial artist of all time and a pop culture icon of the 20th century, who bridged the gap between East and West.

The University of California , Los Angeles ( UCLA ) is a public land-grant research university in Los Angeles , CA. Founded in 1912 as the University of California (UC) in Los Angeles , UC has grown to a campus of some 3,000 students. With its mission of educating and training students to make leaders in society, UC strives to create the best learning environment for both graduate and undergraduate students in the nation’s third largest urban academic setting. Our Mission

UCLA encourages the creative exploration and application of knowledge in order to advance the knowledge of society.

Pope Leo IV (790 – 17 July 855) was the bishop of Rome and ruler of the Papal States from 10 April 847 to his death. He is remembered for repairing Roman churches that had been damaged during the Arab raid against Rome, and for building the Leonine Wall around Vatican Hill to protect the city. Pope Leo organized a league of Italian cities who fought and won the sea Battle of Ostia against the Saracens.Early careerA Roman by birth, Leo received his early education at Rome in the monastery of St. Martin, near St. Peter's.

A radionuclide (radioactive nuclide, radioisotope or radioactive isotope) is a nuclide that has excess nuclear energy, making it unstable. This excess energy can be used in one of three ways: emitted from the nucleus as gamma radiation; transferred to one of its electrons to release it as a conversion electron; or used to create and emit a new particle (alpha particle or beta particle) from the nucleus. During those processes, the radionuclide is said to undergo radioactive decay. These emissions are considered ionizing radiation because they are powerful enough to liberate an electron from another atom.

While a significant majority of water vessels are powered by diesel engines, with sail power and gasoline engines also popular, boats powered by electricity have been used for over 120 years. Electric boats were very popular from the 1880s until the 1920s, when the internal combustion engine became dominant. Since the energy crises of the 1970s, interest in this quiet and potentially renewable marine energy source has been increasing steadily, especially as more efficient solar cells have become available, for the first time making possible motorboats with an infinite range like sailboats. The first practical solar boat was probably constructed in 1975 in England.

An adverb is a word or an expression that modifies a verb, adjective, another adverb, determiner, clause, preposition, or sentence. Adverbs typically express manner, place, time, frequency, degree, level of certainty, etc., answering questions such as how?, in what way?, when?, where?, and to what extent?. This is called the adverbial function, and may be performed by single words (adverbs) or by multi-word adverbial phrases and adverbial clauses.Adverbs are traditionally regarded as one of the parts of speech.

Pope Leo VI ( 880 – 12 February 929 ) was the bishop of Rome and nominal ruler of the see from 917 to 929. He ruled in the name of Pope Leo V, succeeding the previous pope, Pius I, in this role after the latter's death in 908. In 912, he deposed and exiled the first two of his predecessors, Pope Leo IX and Pope Gregory I, who had also been the co-ruling patriarch of Alexandria, Alexandria being the most important of the three papal sees. When Gregory I died in 914, the position passed to his nephew, Benedict III, who became pope.

Paclitaxel ( PTX ) , sold under the brand name Taxol among others , is a chemotherapy medication used to treat breast, ovarian, prostate, endometrial, head and neck, and some forms of lung cancer . The drug has been used to treat breast, ovarian, colon, kidney and other cancers since the mid-1980s and was approved for use in the US in 1985. The US Food and Drug Administration has approved its use in patients with these cancers since at least 2000. However, the drug is not an ideal treatment for some cancers and is associated with rare but potentially serious adverse events.

The M102 is a light , towable 105 mm howitzer used by the United States Army in the Vietnam War. It has been in service in the U.S. and overseas for over 40 years now. In the 1970's the M102 was developed by the US Army and the U.S. Army Institute of Military Medicine and was the Army's first towed 105 mm howitzer with an improved autocannon design. In the 1990's the M102 was modernized and upgraded to a high-power version called the M102A1 or M102A3. Both variants have been used during combat operations since Operation Desert Storm.

The Alcubierre drive, Alcubierre warp drive, or Alcubierre metric (referring to metric tensor), is a speculative warp drive idea based on a solution of Einstein's field equations in general relativity as proposed by theoretical physicist Miguel Alcubierre during his PhD study at the University of Wales, Cardiff, by which a spacecraft could achieve apparent faster-than-light travel if a configurable energy-density field lower than that of vacuum (that is, negative mass) could be created.Rather than exceeding the speed of light within a local reference frame, a spacecraft would traverse distances by contracting space in front of it and expanding space behind it, resulting in effective faster-than-light travel.

The history of Burgundy stretches back to the times when the region was inhabited in turn by Celts , Romans and Frankish people. In 1025 the Duke of Burgundy (the current duke, a French noble), Robert de Beaumont succeeded his father, Henry III, to the French throne. He was an able military strategist and by the middle of the twelfth century a major player in French politics. By 1130, the duchy was in the hands of a cadet branch of the House of Dreux. This cadet branch was composed of the daughters and sons of Henry III's half-sister, Margaret of Paris.

A funeral home , funeral parlor or mortuary , is a business that provides burial and funeral services for the dead. A funeral parlor might also refer to a funeral parlor specializing in cremation and other services related to the process of cremation. A funeral home or funeral home is usually a place for the final burial of the deceased. A funeral home is also a type of cemetery and contains a funeral cemetery that contains graves for people who have died. Most modern funeral homes are also equipped with mortuary suites that house crematory facilities and are designed to carry out funeral arrangements.

A political prisoner is someone imprisoned for their political activity . The political offense is not always the official reason for imprisonment. Political prisoners usually are imprisoned for the reason that they were part of an organization or group that was deemed an "enemy of the people." They are political dissidents or political opposition, and are normally not held for any political or other crimes that might be considered a "political crime" by the public, but merely because they were part of a designated group that was opposing a person or group whom the general public considered "evil."

The BBC World Service is an international broadcaster owned and operated by the BBC , with funding from the British government. It produces radio and television programmes throughout the world and is currently broadcasting on digital terrestrial television throughout the British Isles. It began transmission on British television in April 1958. BBC World Service was launched as the first 24-hour global television service in 1956, with the first programmes broadcast between 1:00pm and 2:00pm London time. In 1958 the first British television programme was launched by the BBC. In 1968 BBC World Television launched on BBC TV as BBC World.

The Northrop Grumman RQ-4 Global Hawk is a high-altitude, remotely-piloted surveillance aircraft. It was initially designed by Ryan Aeronautical (now part of Northrop Grumman), and known as Tier II+ during development. The RQ-4 provides a broad overview and systematic surveillance using high-resolution synthetic aperture radar (SAR) and electro-optical/infrared (EO/IR) sensors with long loiter times over target areas. It can survey as much as  of terrain per day, an area the size of South Korea or Iceland.The Global Hawk is operated by the United States Air Force (USAF).

Warren Mitchell ( born Warren Misell ; 14 January 1926 – 14 November 2015 ) was a British actor . He played the title role in the original TV series of The Bill. He also appeared in one film, and he had a brief career in British television before making his American debut in 1968. Early life

Misell was born at his family's London home in Ealing, West London. His father was a solicitor, his mother a teacher . He grew up at Ealing Lodge, North London, in the suburb of Barking.

Naval Submarine Base New London is the primary United States Navy East Coast submarine base, also known as the "Home of the Submarine Force." It is located in Groton, Connecticut directly across the Thames River from its namesake city of New London.HistoryIn 1868, the State of Connecticut gave the Navy  of land along the Thames River in Groton to build a Naval Station. Due to a lack of federal funding, it was not until 1872 that two brick buildings and a T-shaped pier were constructed and officially declared a Navy Yard.

Strasbourg ( , , ; ; , ) is the prefecture and largest city of the Grand Est region of France. As of 2012, it has a population of  and an unemployment rate of 1.6%. It has a long river, the Rhône, and two major railway stations, both on the line from Lyon to Bordeaux: Lille-Boulogne-Béarn (LBB), at the head of the Rhône Valley, and Toulouse-Rheims (TBB), on the Seine. Strasbourg was the seat of the First French Empire, during which the French monarchy was established.

Great Barrier Island  lies in the outer Hauraki Gulf, New Zealand,  north-east of central Auckland. With an area of  it is the sixth-largest island of New Zealand and fourth-largest in the main chain. Its highest point, Mount Hobson, is  above sea level. The local authority is the Auckland Council.The island was initially exploited for its minerals and kauri trees and saw only limited agriculture. In 2013, it was inhabited by 939 people, mostly living from farming and tourism and all living off-the-grid. The majority of the island (around 60% of the total area) is administered as a nature reserve by the Department of Conservation.

Brave New World is a dystopian social science fiction novel by English author Aldous Huxley , written in 1931 and first published in 1936. It won the 1939 British Fantasy Award for Best Novel and is also a Hugo Award winning book. It was adapted to film and was also nominated for the Academy Awards in 1941 and 1944. Plot

After the events described in the title, "A New World", the earth is ruled by an overbearing tyrant known as The Ruler. Though The Ruler has been overthrown, The Ruler continues to use his forces of evil.

Coxsackie A virus (CAV) is a cytolytic Coxsackievirus of the Picornaviridae family, an enterovirus (a group containing the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, and echoviruses).Viral structure and genome Coxsackie A virus is a subgroup of enterovirus A, which are small, non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses. Its protective, icosahedral capsid has an external portion that contains sixty copies of viral proteins (VP1,-2,-3) and an internal portion surrounding the RNA genome containing sixty copies of VP4 viral proteins. This capsid mediates cell entry and elicits the humoral immune responses.

Powaqqatsi ( or Powaqqatsi : Life in Transformation ) is a 1988 American non-narrative film directed by Godfrey Reggio and starring Kevin Kline. It's the first part of a trilogy that includes Powaqqatsi: Revolution! (1989), also starring Kline, in which a character named Powaqqatsi is an underground militant revolutionary against the government of a communist country and in which he fights against his own government. The film has received generally negative reviews. Powaqqatsi was produced, co-written and directed by Reggio; it was shot on a soundstage in Los Angeles.

In the history of cryptography, Typex (alternatively, Type X or TypeX) machines were British cipher machines used from 1937. It was an adaptation of the commercial German Enigma with a number of enhancements that greatly increased its security. The cipher machine (and its many revisions) was used until the mid-1950s when other more modern military encryption systems came into use.DescriptionLike Enigma, Typex was a rotor machine. Typex came in a number of variations, but all contained five rotors, as opposed to three or four in the Enigma.

Pietro Mascagni ( 7 December 1863 – 2 August 1945 ) was an Italian composer primarily known for his operas. Born in Milan, he first studied piano and then, in 1885, at the Milan Conservatory, where he was a pupil of Gioachino Ricco. His career as a composer began in 1880 when he won a prize at the International Exhibition in Vienna, which led to an invitation to attend a summer school in France. In 1889–1890, he worked as a conductor and, from 1891–1898, he studied composition with Luigi Cherubini at the Milan Conservatory.

Plotinus ( ; , Plōtînos ; – 270 CE ) was a philosopher in the Hellenistic tradition , born and died during the first century BCE. As a philosopher Platonism played an important role in his life and his works. Although his philosophical works are mostly concerned with questions of the world, he also made major contributions to moral philosophy and psychology. Platonism was largely adopted in ancient Greece, where it enjoyed an early and strong hold. In the Roman period Platonism was greatly diluted, even if it was not completely extinguished, and in the Middle Ages Platonism became the chief philosophy of Renaissance Europe.

Bristol  is a city, ceremonial county and unitary authority in England. Situated on the River Avon, it is bordered by the ceremonial counties of Gloucestershire, to the north; and Somerset, to the south. Bristol is the most populous city in South West England.The wider Bristol Built-up Area is the eleventh most populous urban area in the United Kingdom.Iron Age hill forts and Roman villas were built near the confluence of the rivers Frome and Avon, and around the beginning of the 11th century, the settlement was known as Brycgstow (Old English "the place at the bridge").

Paul Lansky (born June 18, 1944, in New York) is an American composer.BiographyPaul Lansky (born 1944) is an American composer. He was educated at Manhattan's High School of Music and Art, Queens College and Princeton University, studying with George Perle and Milton Babbitt, among others. He received his Ph.D. in music from Princeton in 1973. His doctoral dissertation consisted of an essay titled "Affine music" and a composition of string quartet. Originally intending to pursue a career in performance, during 1965–66 he played the French horn with the Dorian Wind Quintet.

Turtles are an order of reptiles known as Testudines, characterized by a shell developed mainly from their ribs. Modern turtles are divided into two major groups, the side-necked turtles and hidden neck turtles which differ in the way the head retracts. There are 360 living and recently extinct species of turtles, including tortoises and terrapins. They are found on most continents, some islands and much of the ocean. Like other reptiles, birds, and mammals, they breathe air and do not lay eggs underwater, although many species live in or around water.

Civil liberties are guarantees and freedoms that governments commit not to abridge , either by constitution , legislation , or by the use of armed force. They are fundamental rights. Governments are obligated to provide the basic right to personal freedom and personal privacy to the citizens of a state. The right to personal privacy is also called the personal right. Personal privacy means that the state may do whatever it wants to a citizen’s personal life, including the freedom to not have one’s personal data divulged. In our society, the term personal privacy has a different meaning from the one commonly used in the digital world.

The Himalayas, or Himalaya (; Sanskrit: ,  "snow",  "dwelling", "abode"), are a mountain range in Asia separating the plains of the Indian subcontinent from the Tibetan Plateau. The range has some of the planet's highest peaks, including the highest, Mount Everest. Over 100 peaks exceeding  in elevation lie in the Himalayas. By contrast, the highest peak outside Asia (Aconcagua, in the Andes) is  tall.The Himalayas abut or cross five countries: Bhutan, India, Nepal, China, and Pakistan.

Turandot ( , ; see below ) is an opera in three acts by Giacomo Puccini , posthumously completed by Gioachino Rossini . Its libretto was a collaboration between Luigi Cherubini , the composer, and Giuseppe Maria Baffi , the director. The opera premiered on 22 December 1887 at Teatro La Fenice , Venice at a gala performance that was attended by Prince Filippo Strozzi. It was subsequently revived on 2 June 1890 in La Scala in Milan and on 17 April 1893 in La Fenice in Vienna. The premiere of Rossini's last opera, Turandot, took place in Milan on 11 October 1885.

Metaphone is a phonetic algorithm , published by Lawrence Philips in 1990 , for indexing words by their English pronunciation . It works by having a pre-defined dictionary that represents the phonetic rules and the phonetic categories used to describe a word . A word may have more or fewer phonetic rules than this pre-dictionary dictionary , and in that case the algorithm chooses a particular rule . The algorithm then finds the word with the best match to the given dictionary . With this algorithm the user cannot input new words, since they would then be represented by their pronunciation , not their actual word .

Giovanni Paisiello ( or Paesiello ; 9 May 1740 – 5 June 1816 ) was an Italian composer of the Baroque period, active mainly in Naples. Paisiello was born in Naples, where he made his name as a player of the viola da gamba. His career began as a musician with the Naples Royal Court Orchestra and, in the early 1760s, he became a composer; a few years later he moved to Paris, where in 1775 he published his Op. 1, No. 2, the only work of his published in Paris.

Toilet paper (sometimes called toilet tissue) is a tissue paper product primarily used to clean the anus and surrounding anal region of feces after defecation, and to clean the perineal area and external genitalia of urine after urination or other bodily fluid releases. It also acts as a layer of protection for the hands during these processes. It is usually supplied as a long strip of perforated paper wrapped around a paperboard core for storage in a dispenser near a toilet. The bundle is known as a toilet roll,  or loo roll or bog roll in Britain.There are other uses for toilet paper, as it is a readily available household product.

In celestial mechanics , escape velocity or escape speed is the minimum speed needed for a free , non-propelled object to escape in free fall and not fall away. , , , , or . The escape velocity of a rigid body with mass m has been denoted by the symbol ℏ in the literature for a few years, but was originally denoted in the astronomy literature with the symbol λ. The symbol has now become obsolete, so it should no longer be used. The symbol has also been denoted ω in the astronomical literature, and ω/4, 3ω, and 4ω/2 in some books.

Domenico Gaetano Maria Donizetti ( 29 November 1797 – 8 April 1848 ) was an Italian composer , best known for operas. Biography
Born in the Roman city of Lucca in central Italy to a rich musical family; Donizetti attended the grammar school of his uncle, the church historian and composer Domenico Donizetti and studied under the teacher of his own choosing, Vincenzo Bellini. After moving to Naples, he went to France in 1809 and studied there with Jean-Baptiste Massenet and Jean-Baptiste Duprez, with whom he was associated until the end of his life.

The Little Ice Age (LIA) was a period of regional cooling, particularly pronounced in the North Atlantic region, that occurred after the Medieval Warm Period. It was not a true ice age of global extent. The term was introduced into scientific literature by François E. Matthes in 1939. The time period has been conventionally defined as extending from the 16th to the 19th centuries, but some experts prefer an alternative timespan from about 1300 to about 1850.The NASA Earth Observatory notes three particularly cold intervals. One began about 1650, another about 1770, and the last in 1850, all of which were separated by intervals of slight warming.

Strasbourg (, , ;  ;  ,  ) is the prefecture and largest city of the Grand Est region of eastern France and the official seat of the European Parliament. Located at the border with Germany in the historic region of Alsace, it is the prefecture of the Bas-Rhin department.In 2019, the city proper had 287,228 inhabitants and both the Eurométropole de Strasbourg (Greater Strasbourg) and the Arrondissement of Strasbourg had 505,272 inhabitants. Strasbourg's metropolitan area had a population of 790,087 in 2017, making it the ninth-largest metro area in France and home to 13% of the Grand Est region's inhabitants.

The European Organization for Nuclear Research , known as CERN (; ; derived from the name ), is a European research organization that operates the largest particle physics laboratory in the world. Established in 1954, the organization is based in a northwest suburb of Geneva on the Franco–Swiss border and has 23 member states. Israel is the only non-European country granted full membership. CERN is an official United Nations Observer.The acronym CERN is also used to refer to the laboratory, which in 2019 had 2,660 scientific, technical, and administrative staff members, and hosted about 12,400 users from institutions in more than 70 countries.

was the 70th emperor of Japan , according to the traditional order of succession.Go-Reizei 's reign spanned the years 1045–1068.This period, from the late 10th to mid 12th century, has been dubbed the Era of Peace, because the Emperor was known to exercise restraint in the use of his position, and the country was in general in a relaxed state of peace. This era has long been regarded as the golden age of Buddhism. The growth of Buddhism in Japan was due in large part to the increasing power of the Chinese, who began to extend their political and commercial influence in Japan in the 13th century.

See also History of UnitarianismA number of notable people have considered themselves Unitarians , Universalists , and following the merger of Universalists and Unitarians in 1834, the Universalists had become Unitarian Universalists. A Unitarian Universalist

The term Unitarian Universalists is sometimes used by the Unitarian and Universalist traditions, but the word is more often used by people outside their respective communities, especially by the secular or secularists, who use the word "universal" in the sense of "common", and use the term to refer generally to people who are uniting with their religious traditions (see also Universalism in the United States and Religion in America).

A hot air balloon is a lighter-than-air aircraft consisting of a bag, called an envelope, which contains heated air. Suspended beneath is a gondola or wicker basket (in some long-distance or high-altitude balloons, a capsule), which carries passengers and a source of heat, in most cases an open flame caused by burning liquid propane. The heated air inside the envelope makes it buoyant, since it has a lower density than the colder air outside the envelope. As with all aircraft, hot air balloons cannot fly beyond the atmosphere.

Ilona Staller ( born 26 November 1951 ) , widely known by her stage name Cicciolina ( `` little chubby '' ) , is a Romanian singer and composer. She has been an artist since 1967. She was born in Bucharest and graduated from the Faculty of Philology. She has had her first success in 1967 when she recorded a song in Italian for the soundtrack of a film with a title entitled La gente ( The people ). After she won a contest for the title of best Romanian folk singer she entered a talent show hosted by a Romanian singer and won the prize of € 5,000.

The Jagiellonian University ( Polish : Uniwersytet Jagielloński ( UJ ) ) is a public research university in Kraków , in Poland, established by law on January 21, 1993. The University is part of the public universities system of Poland. Overview

The University is based in Kraków and has the status of an independent research institution. It is a fully autonomous institution, which conducts research as well as the education of young professionals. The University is the only research university of Poland. It is one of only two public research institutions in the country.

Commander Keen is a series of side-scrolling platform video games developed primarily by id Software . The series consists of three releases, namely Commander Keen, Keen of the Wastes , and Commander Keen 2 . It also has several spin-offs, including Commander Keen 2: The Warlords, Commander Keen 3 and Commander Keen 2: The Awakening. Reception

Critical reception
The Commander Keen series has received a favorable critical reception from critics. IGN praised the first game, and remarked that "The story is very compelling, and you can easily see how Keen's character development would take a few turns if the story is not done right."

Isis ( ; Ēse ; ; Meroitic : Wos [ a ] or Wusa ) was a major goddess in ancient Near East during the second millennium BC, and possibly the primary deity of the Amarna period culture, which existed in the cities of Amarna in Egypt (c. 2800–2300 BC), and Thebes, in Egypt, from at least the late eighth century BC onward. She had a major role in both the cultic life of Thebes, and, for the worship of her daughter Aten, the cult of Aten in Upper Egypt.

Year 1493 (MCDXCIII) was a common year starting on Tuesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  January–December  January 19 – Treaty of Barcelona: Charles VIII of France returns Cerdagne and Roussillon to Ferdinand of Aragon. March 1 – Martín Alonso Pinzón returns to the city of Bayona in Spain from the  voyage of discovery, sending the first notice about the discovery to the Catholic Monarchs (Christopher Columbus is delayed by a storm in the Azores). March 4 – Christopher Columbus anchors in Lisbon and completes his February 15 letter on the first voyage conveying the news of his discoveries.

Felix Edmundovich Dzerzhinsky ( ; ;  – 20 July 1926), nicknamed "Iron Felix", was a Bolshevik revolutionary and official. Born into Polish nobility, from 1917 until his death in 1926 Dzerzhinsky led the first two Soviet state-security organizations, the Cheka and the OGPU, establishing a secret police for the post-revolutionary Soviet regime. He was one of the architects of the Red Terror and decossackization.Early life Felix Dzerzhinsky was born on 11 September 1877 to ethnically Polish parents of noble descent, at the Dzerzhinovo family estate, about  from the small town of Ivyanets in the Minsk Governorate of the Russian Empire (now Belarus).

Patrick Jake O'Rourke ( November 14 , 1947 – February 15 , 2022 ) was an American libertarian political satirist and writer, and a member of the United States Libertarian Party. He founded the Libertarian Party in 1988 and was its candidate for the 2000 presidential election, and was nominated as the party's presidential candidate in the 2008 Libertarian Party presidential nomination convention. He became the party's second-ranking official in 2002. He held a senior position with the U.S. Federal Election Commission during the 2008 election cycle and the 2011 election cycle.

Year 877 ( DCCCLXXVII ) was a common year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar ) and a Monday. The last Monday was January 17, 2027. Rule 
The day of the week of birth, date, and month of the year, beginning on Tuesday. Beginning on the next day if the date is Saturday or Sunday. In the case of the leap year, the Sunday in the last week of the month after the date of the year, or on the following Monday in the case of a non-leap year.

Stevana "Stevie" Case (born 1976–1977) is an American businesswoman. She is known for competing in the first-person shooter game Quake in the late 1990s, as well as contributing professionally to the video game industry.Competing under the alias KillCreek, she was one of the first notable female esports players, gaining recognition for beating Quake designer John Romero in a Quake deathmatch in 1997. She was the first professional gamer signed to the Cyberathlete Professional League (CPL).Case worked for Ion Storm between 1997 and 2001, conducting quality assurance and level design.

A white cane is a device used by many people who are blind or visually impaired . A white cane is usually made of a material that is comfortable for the user to wear . There are a variety of kinds of cane that are available in the market for the use of the blind , and all of them have their own special features . White cane can be categorized into four kinds of cane in the market . The first kind of cane is made of hard plastic and is used by blind individuals who have poor vision . These canes are very comfortable and comfortable for the user .

Till Death Us Do Part is a British television sitcom that aired on BBC1 from 1965 to 1975 . The title of the programme came from the song Till Death We Do Part by The Rolling Stones . The title was also used in a 1975 version of the music video of "Satisfaction" by The Rolling Stones. Overview
The series first aired in May 1965 and starred Ronnie Corbett, Alan Ladd and Norman Love. Corbett and Love were regulars in the series until 1968, Ladd until 1972 and Ladd and Love both appeared sporadically throughout the remaining years.

SPARC ( Scalable Processor Architecture ) is a reduced instruction set computing ( RISC ) instruction set architecture originally developed by ARM Holdings in 1989. Sparc is one of the most common architectures in use in today's multicore processors. It is an extension of the Aarch64, i.e. an extension of the architecture which is available on the Sparc32, i.e. 32-bit ARM-based Sparc processor. It is currently available in the SPARC-V9 architecture. It is often referred to simply as SPARC. Description 
SPARC was designed to provide a flexible instruction set for software engineers to work on.

A pegmatite is an igneous rock showing a very coarse texture , with large interlocking crystals usually greater in size than are common with the larger pegmatites such as pyroclinions , diorite , and zircon ,
The pegmatites were formed by a series of metamorphic faults. The metamorphic units are thought to form in a series of alternating magma chambers and crystallization basins. The formation of pegmatites is closely related to a host of volcanic processes including:
Volcanic activity, which results in release of large amounts of magma, and therefore large amounts of gases. These gas bubbles rise rapidly towards the surface and expand rapidly.

The San Juan Islands are an archipelago in the Pacific Northwest of the United States between the U.S. state of Oregon and British Columbia. The Islands are the third most northerly point of the North American continent after the U.S. state of Alaska. The archipelago, which comprises four major islands, is  long by  in width. The largest of the San Juan Islands (the largest island is San Juan Island, which is located about  from the North Pacific Coast) is San Juan Island, which was established as a US territory by the Treaty of Paris in 1846, which was signed by President Martin Van Buren and Britain.

Tamar the Great (, lit. "King Tamar") ( 1160 – 18 January 1213) reigned as the Queen of Georgia from 1184 to 1213, presiding over the apex of the Georgian Golden Age. A member of the Bagrationi dynasty, her position as the first woman to rule Georgia in her own right was emphasized by the title mepe ("king"), afforded to Tamar in the medieval Georgian sources.Tamar was proclaimed heir and co-ruler by her reigning father George III in 1178, but she faced significant opposition from the aristocracy upon her ascension to full ruling powers after George's death.

A monopropellant rocket (or "monochemical rocket") is a rocket that uses a single chemical as its propellant.Chemical-reaction monopropellant rocketsFor monopropellant rockets that depend on a chemical reaction, the power for the propulsive reaction and resultant thrust is provided by the chemical itself. That is, the energy needed to propel the spacecraft is contained within the chemical bonds of the chemical molecules involved in the reaction.The most commonly used monopropellant is hydrazine (N2H4), a chemical which is a strong reducing agent. The most common catalyst is granular alumina (aluminum oxide) coated with iridium.

Year 1107 ( MCVII ) was a common year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar (or the Gregorian calendar), and ending on Sunday night ( or Monday if a day with a national holiday falls on a weekend ) of the Chinese calendar. It is not a leap year; the calendar has 23 instead of 24 months, with a year that is 24 years and 10 months. Events

By place

Eastern Europe

By topic

Religion 
 May 12 – Pope Benedict XVI dies of a brain hemorrhage, only the fifth pope since the Second Vatican Council.

William Tyndale (; sometimes spelled Tynsdale, Tindall, Tindill, Tyndall;  – ) was an English biblical scholar and linguist who became a leading figure in the Protestant Reformation in the years leading up to his execution. He is well known as a translator of the Bible into English, and was influenced by the works of prominent Protestant Reformers such as Erasmus of Rotterdam and Martin Luther.Tyndale's translation of the Bible was used for subsequent English translations, including the Great Bible and the Bishops' Bible, authorized by the Church of England.

Delhi ( ; Dillī ; Dillī ; Dêhlī ) , officially the National Capital Territory ( NCT ) of Delhi, was formed in August 1949 and came into existence on 1 January 1952, after the Delhi Durbar Act was enacted. Located in the south-eastern corner of British India in India, the city was declared the 'capital' of India on 15 August 1947, after the British rulers decided to set up the new capital of India, after India won independence. It was the capital of the British Indian state for the duration of its existence on 1 October 1952.

The history of Burgundy stretches back to the times when the region was inhabited in turn by Celts, Romans (Gallo-Romans), and in the 5th century, the Roman allies the Burgundians, a Germanic people originating in Bornholm (Baltic Sea), who settled there and established the Kingdom of the Burgundians.This Burgundian kingdom was conquered in the 6th century by another Germanic tribe, the Franks, who continued the kingdom of Burgundy under their own rule.Later, the region was divided between the Duchy of Burgundy (to the west) and the County of Burgundy (to the east).

was the 75th emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession.Sutoku's reign spanned the years from 1123 through 1142.GenealogyBefore his ascension to the Chrysanthemum Throne, his personal name (his imina) was Akihito (顕仁). Sutoku was the eldest son of Emperor Toba. Some old texts say he was instead the son of Toba's grandfather, Emperor Shirakawa.Chūgū: Fujiwara no Kiyoko (藤原 聖子) later Kōkamon'in (皇嘉門院), Fujiwara Tadamichi’s daughter Hyounosuke-no-Tsubone (兵衛佐局), Minamoto Masamune's adopted daughter First son: Imperial  (1140–1162).

Hugh John Lofting (14 January 1886 – 26 September 1947) was an English author trained as a civil engineer, who created the classic children's literature character of Doctor Dolittle. It first appeared in illustrated letters to his children written by Lofting from the British Army trenches in the First World War.Personal lifeLofting, born in January 1886 in Maidenhead, Berkshire, to Elizabeth Agnes (Gannon) and John Brien Lofting, was of English and Irish ancestry. His eldest brother, Hilary Lofting, later became a novelist in Australia, having emigrated there in 1915.Lofting was educated at Mount St Mary's College in Spinkhill, Derbyshire.

The covalent radius, rcov, is a measure of the size of an atom that forms part of one covalent bond. It is usually measured either in picometres (pm) or angstroms (Å), with 1 Å = 100 pm.In principle, the sum of the two covalent radii should equal the covalent bond length between two atoms, R(AB) = r(A) + r(B). Moreover, different radii can be introduced for single, double and triple bonds (r1, r2 and r3 below), in a purely operational sense.

A tremor is an involuntary, somewhat rhythmic, muscle contraction and relaxation involving oscillations or twitching movements of one or more body parts. It is the most common of all involuntary movements and can affect the hands, arms, eyes, face, head, vocal folds, trunk, and legs. Most tremors occur in the hands. In some people, a tremor is a symptom of another neurological disorder. A very common tremor is the teeth chattering, usually induced by cold temperatures or by fear.TypesTremor is most commonly classified by clinical features and cause or origin.

Year 879 ( DCCCLXXIX ) was a common year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) that is only two years short of 784. At the time it was celebrated, the calendar featured 155 years, 8 months and 15 days. The year 879 ended on Saturday, October 25, when the Chinese calendar was reformed and a new year was introduced beginning on Tuesday, January 1. At the time the calendar was ended, 879 was still the fourth year of the Chinese year with an annual period of 156 years, 8 months and 7 days.

Carnival is a Western Christian festive season that occurs before the liturgical season of Lent. The main events typically occur during February or early March, during the period historically known as Shrovetide (or Pre-Lent). Carnival typically involves public celebrations, including events such as parades, public street parties and other entertainments, combining some elements of a circus. Elaborate costumes and masks allow people to set aside their everyday individuality and experience a heightened sense of social unity. Participants often indulge in excessive consumption of alcohol, meat, and other foods that will be forgone during upcoming Lent.

Bikram Yoga is a system of hot yoga, a type of yoga as exercise, devised by Bikram Choudhury and based on the teachings of B. C. Ghosh, that became popular in the early 1970s. Classes consist of a fixed sequence of 26 postures, practised in a room heated to  with a humidity of 40%, intended to replicate the climate of India. The room is fitted with carpets and the walls are covered in mirrors. The instructor may adjust the students' yoga postures. Choudhury's teaching style was abrasive.

The granny knot is a binding knot, used to secure a rope or line around an object. It is considered inferior to the reef knot (square knot), which it superficially resembles. Neither of these knots should be used as a bend knot for attaching two ropes together.Etymology Called the "granny's knot" with references going back to at least 1849, the knot was so-called because it is "the natural knot tied by women or landsmen".TyingWhen attempting to tie a reef knot (square knot), it is easy to produce a granny knot accidentally.

Norman Quentin Cook (born Quentin Leo Cook; 31st July 1963), also known by his stage name Fatboy Slim, is an English musician, DJ and record producer who helped to popularise the big beat genre in the 1990s. In the 1980s, Cook was the bassist for the Hull-based indie rock band the Housemartins, who achieved a UK number-one single with their a cappella cover of "Caravan of Love". After the Housemartins split, Cook formed the electronic band Beats International in Brighton, who produced the number-one single "Dub Be Good to Me".

The history of Southeast Asia covers the people of Southeast Asia from prehistory to the present in two distinct sub-regions: Mainland Southeast Asia (or Indochina) and Maritime Southeast Asia (or Insular Southeast Asia). Mainland Southeast Asia comprises Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar (or Burma), Peninsular Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam whereas Maritime Southeast Asia comprises Brunei, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Christmas Island, East Malaysia, East Timor, Indonesia, Philippines and Singapore.The earliest Homo sapiens presence in Mainland Southeast Asia can be traced back to 70,000 years ago and to at least 50,000 years ago in Maritime Southeast Asia.

Antioch on the Orontes (; , Antiókheia hē epì Oróntou; also Syrian Antioch) was a Hellenistic city side of the Orontes River. Its ruins lie near the current city of Antakya, Turkey, to which the ancient city lends its name.Antioch was founded near the end of the fourth century BC by Seleucus I Nicator, one of Alexander the Great's generals. The city's geographical, military, and economic location benefited its occupants, particularly such features as the spice trade, the Silk Road, and the Royal Road. It eventually rivaled Alexandria as the chief city of the Near East.

Kevin James Anderson ( born March 27 , 1962 ) is an American science fiction author . He has written science fiction stories for publications ranging from Science Fiction Weekly to Amazing Stories, among others . His most popular stories have appeared in a wide variety of science fiction and fantasy magazines , anthologies and journals . He has also written novels, short story collections and short stories for anthologies and anthologies of his other works . His books have appeared in over 60 magazines . James Anderson

Contents

James Anderson is an American science fiction and fantasy author.

The oxidation state, or oxidation number, is the hypothetical charge of an atom if all of its bonds to different atoms were fully ionic. It describes the degree of oxidation (loss of electrons) of an atom in a chemical compound. Conceptually, the oxidation state may be positive, negative or zero. While fully ionic bonds are not found in nature, many bonds exhibit strong ionicity, making oxidation state a useful predictor of charge.The oxidation state of an atom does not represent the "real" formal charge on that atom, or any other actual atomic property.

Script Creation Utility for Maniac Mansion (SCUMM) is a video game engine developed at Lucasfilm Games, later renamed LucasArts, to ease development on their graphic adventure game Maniac Mansion (1987). It was subsequently used as the engine for later LucasArts adventure games.It falls somewhere between a game engine and a programming language, allowing designers to create locations, items and dialogue sequences without writing code in the language in which the game source code ends up. This also allowed the game's script and data files to be cross-platform, i.e., re-used across various platforms.

Relative density , or specific gravity , is the ratio of the density ( mass of a unit volume ) of a solid phase to the density of a vapor phase. The specific gravities of most solids fall into one of two categories, based on their melting or boiling temperatures. In the former category, all solid materials will melt at temperatures below about 200 °C; in the latter class, all solid solids will boil at the same temperature above about 300 °C. Solids can be classified in many ways. Some examples include:

Inorganic materials, including minerals (e.g.

Scooby-Doo is an American animated franchise comprising many animated television series produced from 1969 to the present, as well as their derivative media. Writers Joe Ruby and Ken Spears created the original series, Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!, for Hanna-Barbera Productions in 1969. This Saturday-morning cartoon series featured teenagers Fred Jones, Daphne Blake, Velma Dinkley, and Shaggy Rogers, and their talking Great Dane named Scooby-Doo, who solve mysteries involving supposedly supernatural creatures through a series of antics and missteps.Scooby-Doo was originally broadcast on CBS from 1969 to 1976, when it moved to ABC.

John Knox , born ( – 24 November 1572 ) was a Scottish minister , Reformed theologian , and writer , and he was born in 1532 in the parish of Newbattle, Roxburghshire, to Adam Knox and Elizabeth MacMinn (MacMinn), a minister . He was educated at the high school of the diocese of Ross and at the grammar school of St Andrews . He then proceeded to the University of Glasgow and was elected to the university's fellowship, being ordained as a minister in February 1556 . He returned to Roxburghshire in 1556 and held this post until he was ordained in September 1560 as the minister of Allandale.

Year 1025 (MXXV) was a common year starting on Friday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  December 15 – Byzantine Emperor Basil II ("Bulgar Slayer") dies in Constantinople after a 50-year reign. Never married, he is succeeded by his brother and co-emperor Constantine VIII who becomes sole ruler of the Byzantine Empire. Constantine calls the Sicilian invasion off. Catapan Basil Boioannes diverts the Byzantine expeditionary force already assembled on Calabria to join the siege of Capua. Europe  April 18 – Bolesław I the Brave is crowned in Gniezno as the first king of Poland.

The History of East Asia generally encompasses the histories of China , Japan , Korea , and Mongolia from prehistoric times to the present day. This is because ancient China was, for the first time in recorded history, the homeland of mankind. This was the earliest of the human civilizations, the Indus Valley Civilization, which is sometimes referred to as the “Greater Asian” region. This is the reason why so many Chinese historical works are translated into English and other languages, such as Korean , Japanese , and Russian .

An inverse multiplexer ( often abbreviated to inverse MUX or IMUX ) allows a data stream to be broken into multiple pieces at different rates. The data stream can be broken into segments with different lengths (or multiple rates) that are sent over a data link. The pieces of data that are received at the receiving side are broken up again. The inverse multiplexer has several interfaces that allow the pieces of data that have been received by the receiving side to be reconstructed. One of these interfaces is, for example, the interface for the physical layer that is used for transmitting physical layer packets.

Alfa Romeo Automobiles S.p.A.  is an Italian luxury car manufacturer and a subsidiary of Stellantis. The company was founded on 24 June 1910, in Milan, Italy. "Alfa" is an acronym of its founding name, "Anonima Lombarda Fabbrica Automobili." "Anonima" means "anonymous", which was a legal form of company at the time, as it was founded by anonymous investors. In the initial set-up phase, in order to have a building to produce cars, the company bought the Portello factory building of Darracq in Milan, which was closing up and selling all its assets.

Tristan Tzara ( ; ; born Samuel or Samy Rosenstock , also known as S. Samyro ; – 25 December 1878) was an English-born Russian-born composer. He was the son of Russian-born Samuel Rosenstock (Samuel; 1818–1891), a German-Jewish music teacher. His musical career began in the 1880s and his works are known primarily as piano pieces for piano and orchestra (especially the piano pieces Schoenberg, Paganini and Chopin) and as piano pieces by Tchaikovsky. Tzara was a friend and pupil of Alexander Scriabin (who taught Tzara).

D'Urville Island , Te Reo Māori name ( 'red heavens look to the south ' ) , is an island located off the coast of south Taranaki. The island is part of the Marlborough Sounds National Park, and is a nature reserve for birdwatching, and an area of high biodiversity and high-elevation birding sites. There is a carpark on the island where you can find a variety of accommodation, dining and entertainment facilities including a small grocery shop, petrol station, a boat launch and boat ramp, a tennis court and public swimming pool.

Dotdash Meredith (formerly About.com) is an American digital media company that publishes articles and videos about various subjects across categories including health, home, food, finance, tech, beauty, lifestyle, travel and education. It operates brands including Verywell, Investopedia, The Balance, Byrdie, MyDomaine, Brides, The Spruce, Simply Recipes, Serious Eats, Liquor.com, Lifewire, TripSavvy, TreeHugger, and ThoughtCo. The digital media company competes with other online resource sites. In August 2012, Dotdash became a property of IAC, owner of Ask.com and numerous other online brands, and its revenue is generated by advertising.

Year 949 ( CMXLIX ) was a common year starting on Monday ( link will display the full calendar )
that corresponds roughly to the year 1000 AD. The exact start date is
synchronic with the year 500 AD, but Western calendars start in 1000 or
1000+ years earlier. The number 949 corresponds to a year that has not yet
been officially recorded. In Western culture, this day is a secular holiday and is celebrated in
Western nations on the first full weekend in February, with many schools
and churches in the United States celebrating this holiday on the Saturday
after.

The San Juan Islands are an archipelago in the Pacific Northwest of the United States between the U.S. state of Washington and Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada. The San Juan Islands are part of Washington state, and form the core of San Juan County.In the archipelago, four islands are accessible to vehicular and foot traffic via the Washington State Ferries system.HistoryArchaeologists use the term "Gulf of Georgia Culture Area" to refer to the San Juan and Gulf Islands, the whole of which shows many archaeological commonalities. The San Juan Islands were part of the traditional area of various peoples of the Coast Salish ethnolinguistic group.

A seed is an embryonic plant enclosed in a protective outer covering . The formation of the seed is part of an embryonic cell division . The division of one type of cell from another is a division of a part of the plant . Seeds develop into plants when they have formed a protective outer covering (seed coat). The seed contains the genetic material for the formation of all new plants . The seed is a source of plant food for animals and plants . A seed is a complete plant , not just the seed that contains the genetic material .

Glam rock is a style of rock music that developed in the United Kingdom in the early 1970s and was performed by musicians who wore outrageous costumes, makeup, and hairstyles, particularly platform shoes and glitter. Glam artists drew on diverse sources across music and throwaway pop culture, ranging from bubblegum pop and 1950s rock and roll to cabaret, science fiction, and complex art rock. The flamboyant clothing and visual styles of performers were often camp or androgynous, and have been described as playing with other gender roles. Glitter rock was a more extreme version of glam.The UK charts were inundated with glam rock acts from 1971 to 1975.

Wind tunnels are large tubes with air blowing through them which are used to replicate the interaction between air and solid matter. They are an excellent way of creating a 3D simulation of an airflow or the movement of material. For example, in the case of building a wind tunnel it is very common to use a wind tunnel as a form of training or education. In order to build a wind tunnel you must first decide what the shape of the tunnel should be. This can be done using the CAD software, but this is usually only an option if it has a 3D CAD program available.

The European Men's Handball Championship is the official competition for senior men's national handball teams of Europe and takes place every two years since 1994, in the even-numbered year between the World Championship. In addition to crowning the European champions, the tournament also serves as a qualifying tournament for the Olympic Games and World Championship. The most successful team is Sweden who have won five titles. Spain, however, have won most medals.HistoryIn 1946, the International Handball Federation was founded by eight European nations, and though non-European nations competed at the World Championships, the medals had always been taken by European nations.

The Australian Secret Intelligence Service  (ASIS) is the foreign intelligence agency of Australia, tasked with the covert collection of information overseas through personal contacts and other means of human intelligence. It is part of the Australian Intelligence Community and is also responsible for counter-intelligence and liaising with the intelligence agencies of other countries. ASIS was formed in 1952 but its existence remained secret within much of the government until 1972. ASIS is compared to the American CIA and the British MI6.ASIS is part of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) portfolio and has its headquarters in Canberra.

A museum ( ; plural museums or, rarely, musea) is a building or institution that cares for and displays a collection of artifacts and other objects of artistic, cultural, historical, or scientific importance. Many public museums make these items available for public viewing through exhibits that may be permanent or temporary. The largest museums are located in major cities throughout the world, while thousands of local museums exist in smaller cities, towns, and rural areas. Museums have varying aims, ranging from the conservation and documentation of their collection, serving researchers and specialists to catering to the general public.

Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Seas  is a classic science fiction adventure novel by French writer Jules Verne.The novel was originally serialized from March 1869 through June 1870 in Pierre-Jules Hetzel's fortnightly periodical, the . A deluxe octavo edition, published by Hetzel in November 1871, included 111 illustrations by Alphonse de Neuville and Édouard Riou. The book was widely acclaimed on its release and remains so; it is regarded as one of the premier adventure novels and one of Verne's greatest works, along with Around the World in Eighty Days and Journey to the Center of the Earth.

Turtles are an order of reptiles known as Testudines , characterized by a shell developed mainly from their ribs . They are capable of jumping , swimming and climbing , and have a strong tail . Contents

Testudines is not a single order or group, rather a group of species of reptiles with an order. It is made up of two different groups of reptiles, namely the turtles (Testudines) and the crocodilians (Sauria, Dermochelys, Crocodylus, Trionychidae). Most Testudines live in the water, while the crocodilians are usually terrestrial animals. Some crocodilians are able to breathe air.

Mycenae ( ; or , Mykē̂nai or Mykḗnē ) is an archaeological site near Mykines in Argolis , north-eastern Peloponnese , Greece, dating to the fifth century b.c.e.. It is now a National Monument, in the western Peloponnese. It has been dated to c. 470–470/470–462 or 480/470–460 based on radiocarbon dates. It is notable as the site of an archaeological site that was inhabited as early as c. 3000 BC, which was abandoned during the Bronze Age II. The site was excavated in the 1960s and is known for having a large necropolis that has been excavated since 1969.

A think tank, or policy institute, is a research institute that performs research and advocacy concerning topics such as social policy, political strategy, economics, military, technology, and culture. Most think tanks are non-governmental organizations, but some are semi-autonomous agencies within government or are associated with particular political parties, businesses or the military. Think-tank funding often includes a combination of donations from wealthy individuals and personal contributions, with many also accepting government grants.Think tanks publish articles, studies or even draft legislation on particular matters of policy or society.

A half reaction ( or half-cell reaction ) is either the oxidation or reduction reaction component of a redox reaction in a biochemical reaction, a biochemical reaction, etc. There are different kinds of half reactions, for example, a first half reaction is the reaction of oxygen with hydrogen ions. A second half reaction is the reaction of hydrogen ions with ammonia or an amine and there are two half reactions, respectively. As a matter of fact, the half reaction in a living cell is called the Krebs cycle. A living cell contains a series of half reactions.

Purple is any of a variety of colors with hue between red and blue. In the RGB color model used in computer and television screens, purples are produced by mixing red and blue light. In the RYB color model historically used by painters, purples are created with a combination of red and blue pigments. In the CMYK color model used in printing, purples are made by combining magenta pigment with either cyan pigment, black pigment, or both.Purple has long been associated with royalty, originally because Tyrian purple dye, made from crushed shells, was extremely expensive in antiquity.

Belarusians , also known formerly as Byelorussians ( from the Byelorussian SSR ) , Belarussians or Belorusians , are an ethnic group of Belarusians who live within the modern day Belarus. Historically the Belarussians and Belarusians have been living in the territories of Belarus since the 17th century. At the time of the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1990, the Belarussians claimed their ancestors had lived in the Dnieper region in eastern Belarus around the Dnepr river before the 13th century, and the region's first settlement is thought to be located in the village of Yagodshany.

A half reaction (or half-cell reaction) is either the oxidation or reduction reaction component of a redox reaction. A half reaction is obtained by considering the change in oxidation states of individual substances involved in the redox reaction.Often, the concept of half reactions is used to describe what occurs in an electrochemical cell, such as a Galvanic cell battery. Half reactions can be written to describe both the metal undergoing oxidation (known as the anode) and the metal undergoing reduction (known as the cathode).Half reactions are often used as a method of balancing redox reactions.

Giuseppe Saverio Raffaele Mercadante (baptised 17 September 179517 December 1870) was an Italian composer, particularly of operas. While Mercadante may not have retained the international celebrity of Gaetano Donizetti or Gioachino Rossini beyond his own lifetime, he composed as prolific a number of works as either; and his development of operatic structures, melodic styles and orchestration contributed significantly to the foundations upon which Giuseppe Verdi built his dramatic technique.BiographyEarly yearsMercadante was born illegitimate in Altamura, near Bari in Apulia; his precise date of birth has not been recorded, but he was baptised on 17 September 1795.

Sir Philip Nicholas Outram Pullman  (born 19 October 1946) is an English writer. His books include the fantasy trilogy His Dark Materials and The Good Man Jesus and the Scoundrel Christ, a fictionalised biography of Jesus. In 2008, The Times named Pullman one of the "50 greatest British writers since 1945". In a 2004 BBC poll, he was named the eleventh most influential person in British culture. He was knighted in the 2019 New Year Honours for services to literature.Northern Lights, the first volume in His Dark Materials, won the 1995 Carnegie Medal of the Library Association as the year's outstanding English-language children's book.

A gas nuclear reactor ( or gas fueled reactor or vapor core reactor ) is a proposed kind of nuclear power plant, with the core of which is filled with natural gas, as opposed to molten salt in a reactor. The core is used in order to generate a gas stream which, in a controlled manner, will be used to drive a turbine, thus producing electrical power. It is important for the power generated to have a very high specific power, and for the steam used to heat the reactor, and thus to heat the reactor to a high temperature.

Gender is the range of characteristics pertaining to femininity and masculinity and differentiating between them . Depending on the context, the term 'women' is also used to refer specifically to women, but in this text it also refers to women who have 'male' characteristics. The gender identity is the self-perception of a person as being of the opposite sex, either male or female. For some individuals, their sense of masculinity or femininity differs from one gender to the other, and as such there may be a gap in self-perception or perception of the gender.

Gaelic football ( ; short name ) , commonly known as simply Gaelic , GAA or Caid , is an Irish-speaking sport, that is played by all levels of Irish speakers and in many other countries, both at club and school level, as well as internationally. It was historically played in a loose, informal way before the formation of clubs. The game has been played for at least five centuries by groups of people from all over Britain and Ireland, most often at fairs and in towns, but it is very much a part of Irish culture.

In electronics , a multiplexer ( or mux ; spelled sometimes as multiplexor ) , also known as a data routing unit (DRU ) , is an element in a multi-channel multiplexer circuit for receiving, processing, and routing a plurality of inputs from the output of one or more digital integrated circuits (or chips or modules) into the input of one or more analog circuits. DRUs are often designed to operate over a single clock frequency, although in the case of a data stream, a DRU may perform all the logic operations and routing of all the signals in the data stream at the same time.

An airport is an aerodrome with extended facilities, mostly for commercial air transport. Airports often have facilities to park and maintain aircraft, and a control tower. An airport consists of a landing area, which comprises an aerially accessible open space including at least one operationally active surface such as a runway for a plane to take off and to land or a helipad, and often includes adjacent utility buildings such as control towers, hangars and terminals. Larger airports may have airport aprons, taxiway bridges, air traffic control centres, passenger facilities such as restaurants and lounges, and emergency services.

ESP most commonly refers to : Extrasensory perception , a paranormal ability Spain ( España ) - ISO three-letter country code Español country code ISO country code Esp

What are ESP? What's ESP? What does it mean? How do I have it? What is ESP? I am not sure, but I have a friend who has it. This is the first time, I think, that ESP is mentioned in a forum. I will tell you what is ESP and what ESP is and let you decide for yourself.

Toilet humour, or potty or scatological humour (compare scatology), is a type of off-colour humour dealing with defecation, constipation, urination and flatulence, and to a lesser extent vomiting and other bodily functions. It sees substantial crossover with sexual humour, such as dick jokes.Toilet humour is commonly an interest of children and young teenagers, for whom cultural taboos related to acknowledgement of waste excretion still have a degree of novelty. The humour comes from the rejection of such taboos, and is a part of modern culture.MusicToilet humour is sometimes found in song and rhyme, particularly schoolboy songs.

A shaped charge is an explosive charge shaped to focus the effect of the explosive 's energy . Different types of shaped charge explosives have been developed in the past, with differing physical and chemical properties . In its simplest form, an explosive is composed of a primary explosive that is a solid . Secondary explosives, which contain secondary or tertiary components , are used to provide a means of effecting a reaction. Secondary explosives may be solid, powdered , granular . The energy of secondary explosives may be transferred by contact to a surface upon which it is supported .

was the 75th emperor of Japan , according to the traditional order of succession.Sutoku 's reign spanned the years from 1472 to 1483, ending in 1483 with the assassination of his son-in-law, Saitō Mitsuyoshi (記川安) on January 15, 1483, which caused the loss of the last male heir. The Emperor was replaced on the throne by his adopted son Prince Yoshinobu (宮久治). In February 1483, Saitō issued the Edo constitution, which gave the Emperor the prerogatives of supreme command and the supreme control over civil government in the Empire.

The Arctic ( or ) is a polar region located at the northernmost part of Earth. The Arctic consists of the Arctic Ocean, adjacent seas, and parts of Alaska (United States), Canada, Finland, Greenland (Denmark), Iceland, Norway, Russia, and Sweden. Land within the Arctic region has seasonally varying snow and ice cover, with predominantly treeless permafrost (permanently frozen underground ice) containing tundra. Arctic seas contain seasonal sea ice in many places.The Arctic region is a unique area among Earth's ecosystems.

Coxsackie A virus ( CAV ) is a cytolytic Coxsackievirus of the Picornaviridae family , an enterovirus ( a group of unicellular alphavirus), which is divided into two major genotypes, A and B . The genome of CAV consists of a positive-stranded RNA (+ssRNA) genome of about 7.5 kb in length, of which 3.4 kb codes for a single polyprotein of 2800 aa in length. A number of distinct proteins, encoded by CAV's 3' UTR have been identified to be involved in pathogenicity. The CAV 3' UTR encodes the polyprotein at the 3' termini and is a target for transcriptional regulation.

Porphyry ( ; , Porphyrios `` purple-clad '' ) may refer to : Porphyry ( geology ) , an igneous rock which is thought to have had a major role in the origin of life. It is a crystalline silicate made from magnesium, silicon, and iron, and is the mineral of choice for the study of its chemical properties. History
Porphyry is thought to have formed early in the earth's crust, and was thought to be the original form of silicon in the primordial universe. Some scientists suggest it may even have been the original form of oxygen, and some suggest it was a precursor to the atmosphere.

The Campeonato Nacional de Liga de Primera División, commonly known simply as Primera División in Spain, and as La Liga in English-speaking countries and officially as LaLiga Santander for sponsorship reasons, stylized as LaLiga, is the men's top professional football division of the Spanish football league system. Administered by the Liga Nacional de Fútbol Profesional, it is contested by 20 teams, with the three lowest-placed teams at the end of each season being relegated to the Segunda División and replaced by the top two teams and a play-off winner in that division.Since its inception, a total of 62 teams have competed in La Liga.

Pas-de-Calais (, "strait of Calais"; ; also ) is a department in northern France named after the French designation of the Strait of Dover, which it borders. It has the most communes of all the departments of France, 890, and is the 8th most populous. The Calais Passage connects to the Port of Calais on the English Channel.
