Pas-de-Calais borders the departments of Nord and Somme and is connected to the English county of Kent via the Channel Tunnel.HistoryInhabited since prehistoric times, the Pas-de-Calais region was populated in turn by the Celtic Belgae, the Romans, the Germanic Franks and the Alemanni.

Year 1045 ( MXLV ) was a common year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar )

This page has incomplete information for year 1045. There is information for 1045-11-28 and 1045-11-29, as well as a page for 1046-10-31 with all the info for that year and for 1045-11-28. For more complete information about the calendar year, see year 1045. Events

January–December
 January 5 – Emperor Gaozu returns to Jiangdao from a tour of the provinces, after which the empress is enthroned as empress. January 4 – The Southern Song Dynasty is established and Emperor Gaozu takes the title Emperor of the Dongyong Dynasty.

A hybrid-propellant rocket is a rocket with a rocket motor that uses rocket propellants in two different phases : one in the propulsion chamber of the rocket engine and another in the rocket body. The rocket body is usually the engine case but can be a metal or plastic casing or an internal container. The propellant in the propellant chamber can be either liquid or solid. Rocket propellants are liquid fuels that use oxygen or liquid oxygen (LOX/LOX+O2) as oxidizer. Other propellants can also be used but are more difficult to produce. The propellant chamber is usually the engine case but can be a container for fuel or solid propellant.

Year 870 (DCCCLXX) was a common year starting on Sunday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  August 8 – Treaty of Meerssen: King Louis the German forces his half-brother Charles the Bald to accept a peace treaty, which partitions the Middle Frankish Kingdom into two larger east and west divisions. Louis receives most of Austrasia (which evolves into the Kingdom of Germany), and Charles receives territory in Lower Burgundy (which evolves into the Kingdom of France). However, large parts of the Frisian coast are under Viking control.

Fermat's principle, also known as the principle of least time, is the link between ray optics and wave optics. In its original "strong" form, Fermat's principle states that the path taken by a ray between two given points is the path that can be traveled in the least time. In order to be true in all cases, this statement must be weakened by replacing the "least" time with a time that is "stationary" with respect to variations of the path — so that a deviation in the path causes, at most, a second-order change in the traversal time.

A beta particle , also called beta ray or beta radiation ( symbol β ) , is a high-energy , high-frequency gamma ray of more than 3 keV that emanates from radioactive decays of certain isotopes of cesium ( ^ 137Cs) and rubidium ( ^ 191Ru )
The beta particle is one of the three main types of high energy gamma rays ( the others being X-rays and gamma rays ), and the first of them to be discovered. It has a wavelength equal to the distance it travels in one oscillation and is emitted from an object when that object undergoes an atomic decay.

Barbecue or barbeque ( informally BBQ in the UK and US , barbie in Australia and braai in South Africa ) is the cooking of food over hot coals. The word is believed to originate from the Anglo-Saxon bār, meaning "fire or hearth" or "brazier" . In the late 18th and early 19th Century British cookbooks, "Braising" is used to describe the process of preparing and preparing foods over a coals, which is thought to have derived from the old English word bar-ber. The process is also called "barrack" or "bar-brel" .

The Campeonato Nacional de Liga de Primera División , commonly known simply as Primera División in Spain , and as simply La Liga, is the premier football league of Spain. The competition has existed since the creation of the country in the 15th century and has had the longest existence of any football competition in the world. It has the second-longest league table in the world behind the English Championship, having been held every season since 1996. Spain has had a variety of leagues in its history. The first league, the Primera, has existed for over 200 years, but there were no official leagues before the Primera Division.

Genus  (plural genera ) is a taxonomic rank used in the biological classification of living and fossil organisms as well as viruses. In the hierarchy of biological classification, genus comes above species and below family. In binomial nomenclature, the genus name forms the first part of the binomial species name for each species within the genus.E.g. Panthera leo (lion) and Panthera onca (jaguar) are two species within the genus Panthera. Panthera is a genus within the family Felidae.The composition of a genus is determined by taxonomists. The standards for genus classification are not strictly codified, so different authorities often produce different classifications for genera.

Edward Higgins White II ( November 14 , 1930 – January 27 , 1967 ) was an American aeronautical engineer and NASA administrator. In the 1940s, Higgins was a member of the NASA Advisory Board and served as its Chairman from 1965 to 1967. He also served as a member of the General Board of the National Aeronautic Association for many years. Higgins was awarded a Legion of Merit by President Eisenhower in 1963, as well as a Gold Medal of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. In 1968, he was awarded honorary membership in the National Space Council.

The National Guard is a state-based military force that becomes part of the reserve components of the United States Army and the United States Marine Corps and, after March 2016, the United States Coast Guard. The term "Reserve" is used generally to refer to a state-run force, such as the Florida National Guard, or to a voluntary force, such as the United States Coast Guard, the United States Coast Guard Reserve or the National Guard of California. On April 26, 2017, President Donald Trump announced a new Department of the Army in the Pentagon that would create the National Guard.

Tamar the Great ( , lit . `` King Tamar '' ) ( 1160 – 18 January 1213 ) reigned from 1198 until her death, she was a woman of remarkable beauty, intelligence, and strength. Although she was married to a man of low birth, it was said that her beauty caused her to attract the attention of kings and nobles and she became the mother of kings, the most powerful being her son Tamar I ( 1198–1207 ) . The story of her birth goes back to the year 1198 when a peasant girl came from the kingdom of the Duchy of Aquitaine .

Dementia manifests as a set of related symptoms , which usually surface when the brain is damaged by injury or disease. These symptoms can appear at any age and can be associated with multiple physical and cognitive problems. These symptoms include: memory loss, difficulty in learning new things, trouble concentrating, disorientation, lack of speech, and trouble understanding or communicating. Memory problems can make it difficult to complete tasks such as learning new things or remembering dates, names, and facts. In some cases, memory loss may be related to other conditions such as head injuries, or diseases that affect the brain.

Felix Edmundovich Dzerzhinsky ( ; ; – 20 July 1926 ) , nicknamed `` Iron Felix '' , was a Russian revolutionary. During the Reign of Terror following the assassination of Alexander Kerensky in July 1881, Russia was the scene of several bloody episodes, and Dzerzhinsky became famous as a leading militant of the revolution movement. He was an active participant in the battles of Petrograd, in which he was killed. Contents show]

Early years: 1798–1799 

Dzerzhinsky (nickname "Iron Felix") was born into a wealthy family as the son of a doctor in St. Petersburg, Russia.

A seal is a device for making an impression in wax , clay , paper , or some other medium, and is typically used to simulate a seal around the rim of a mold in the production of castings and molds for casting molds. The seal is created in the wax by a process known as an anechoic wax, in which wax is softened in an anechoic vessel (a vessel that produces no sound and that contains no air or bubbles), and the softened wax is allowed to solidify before being poured into the mold around the rim.

The Burrows–Wheeler transform (BWT, also called block-sorting compression) rearranges a character string into runs of similar characters. This is useful for compression, since it tends to be easy to compress a string that has runs of repeated characters by techniques such as move-to-front transform and run-length encoding. More importantly, the transformation is reversible, without needing to store any additional data except the position of the first original character. The BWT is thus a "free" method of improving the efficiency of text compression algorithms, costing only some extra computation.

Niacin , also known as nicotinic acid , is an organic compound and a form of vitamin B3 , an important component of red blood cells. Niacin is mainly converted into NAD and nicotinamide in the human body during the process of cell respiration. Although niacin has the function of improving the function of erythrocytes in the whole body, it can not only be converted into NAD but also converted into nicotinamide, which is the first step in the cellular energy pathway. Nicotinamide can then be converted into NAD+ which can be utilized for the energy production in cells, tissues, and organs \[[@B1]\].

Josiah Willard Gibbs (; February 11, 1839 – April 28, 1903) was an American scientist who made significant theoretical contributions to physics, chemistry, and mathematics. His work on the applications of thermodynamics was instrumental in transforming physical chemistry into a rigorous inductive science. Together with James Clerk Maxwell and Ludwig Boltzmann, he created statistical mechanics (a term that he coined), explaining the laws of thermodynamics as consequences of the statistical properties of ensembles of the possible states of a physical system composed of many particles. Gibbs also worked on the application of Maxwell's equations to problems in physical optics.

Yorkshire pudding is a baked pudding made from a batter of eggs, flour, and milk or water. A common English side dish, it is a versatile food that can be served in numerous ways depending on its ingredients, size, and the accompanying components of the meal. As a first course, it can be served with onion gravy. For a main course, it may be served with meat and gravy, and is part of the traditional Sunday roast, but can also be filled with foods such as bangers and mash to make a meal.

Fidelio , originally titled ( Leonore , or The Triumph of Marital Love ) , Op . 72 , is an orchestral suite by John Adams, which was published in 1878. It was composed after Adams’s marriage to Ellen Terry. It was written when she was about 40 years old. The suite consists of five movements, and was inspired by a number of historical events: her first marriage , to John Terry , and his death . The score of this work has four movements and is in C major . There are 11 movements, and it is divided into seven suites each with an aria .

Columbia Business School ( CBS ) is the business school of Columbia University in the City of New York in the United States. The Business School offers graduate programs in several business concentrations, as well as graduate programs for undergraduate students. Columbia Business School is accredited by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools (MASS). The MASS is the largest business college accreditation body in the world, with over 3,000 schools and colleges affiliated with it in the U.S.A. The MBA programs at CBS are part of the MBA program offered by Columbia University's Graduate School of Management.

The following outline is provided as an overview of and topical guide to the history of South Asia:History of South Asia – South Asia includes the contemporary political entities of India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Afghanistan, Bhutan, and the island nations of Sri Lanka and the Maldives.ChronologyJames Mill (1773–1836), in his The History of British India (1817), distinguished three phases in the history of India, namely Hindu, Muslim and British civilisations. This periodisation has been influential, but has also been criticised for the misconceptions it gave rise to.

François Marie Adrien Maurice Mitterrand (26 October 19168 January 1996) served as President of France from 1981 to 1995, the longest time in office in the history of France. As First Secretary of the Socialist Party, he was the first left-wing politician to assume the presidency under the Fifth Republic.Reflecting family influences, Mitterrand started political life on the Catholic nationalist right. He served under the Vichy Regime during its earlier years. Subsequently he joined the Resistance, moved to the left, and held ministerial office several times under the Fourth Republic. Mitterrand opposed Charles de Gaulle's establishment of the Fifth Republic.

Bi-curious is a term for a person, usually someone who is a heterosexual, who is curious or open about engaging in sexual activity with a person whose sex differs from that of their usual sexual partners. The term is sometimes used to describe a broad continuum of sexual orientation between heterosexuality and bisexuality. Such continuums include mostly-heterosexual or mostly-homosexual, but these can be self-identified without identifying as bisexual. The terms heteroflexible and homoflexible are mainly applied to bi-curious people, though some authors distinguish heteroflexibility and homoflexibility as lacking the "wish to experiment with sexuality" implied by the bi-curious label.

Lumbar disc disease is the drying out of the spongy interior matrix of an intervertebral disc in the spine . It is an important and common disorder that causes significant pain, nerve root damage, and disability. This is especially the case for lumbar intervertebral disk herniation, which can be debilitating and lead to spinal stenosis, sciatica , radiculopathy , degenerative changes to the spine, and spinal stenosis. The disc may also be injured or destroyed during surgery or in the course of life, and can become a chronic condition that is difficult to treat.

A U-Boot is a beer cocktail that is made by placing a shot of vodka into a glass of beer, typically a lager. It is popular in Germany, Poland, North Macedonia, and Flanders. In Germany, the liquor korn is sometimes used instead, while in Flanders and the Netherlands, jonge jenever is preferred.It is called a U-Boot (German abbreviation of Unterseeboot, "submarine") because the shot glass of vodka sinks to the bottom of the glass of beer. The shot glass then "surfaces" when the cocktail is drunk.Preparation Place a shot glass on upside down glass and fill it with vodka.

The putamen (; from Latin, meaning "nutshell") is a round structure located at the base of the forebrain (telencephalon). The putamen and caudate nucleus together form the dorsal striatum. It is also one of the structures that compose the basal nuclei. Through various pathways, the putamen is connected to the substantia nigra, the globus pallidus, the claustrum, and the thalamus, in addition to many regions of the cerebral cortex. A primary function of the putamen is to regulate movements at various stages (e.g. preparation and execution) and influence various types of learning.

The Hoysala Empire was a Kannadiga power originating from the Indian subcontinent that ruled most of what is now Karnataka. It was overthrown between 1665 and 1668 by the Mughal emperor Bahram Khan. The Mughal empire, founded by Bahram Khan in 1565, consisted of India and much of Central India, and it lasted until the decline of the Mughal Empire in 1717 when the British took over the throne. The British replaced the Mughal Empire with a new Mughal-dominated empire in India. The British restored Hinduism to the empire, which had been previously destroyed.

Cranial nerves are the nerves that emerge directly from the brain (including the brainstem), of which there are conventionally considered twelve pairs. Cranial nerves relay information between the brain and parts of the body, primarily to and from regions of the head and neck, including the special senses of vision, taste, smell, and hearing.The cranial nerves emerge from the central nervous system above the level of the first vertebrae of the vertebral column. Each cranial nerve is paired and is present on both sides. There are conventionally twelve pairs of cranial nerves, which are described with Roman numerals I–XII.

Year 1073 ( MLXXIII ) was a common year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar and a leap year beginning on Sunday of the Gregorian calendar. Events 
<center>

January–March
 January 19 – Emperor Guangwu is succeeded by his son Hezuo as the emperor of the Western Jin dynasty. January 23 – Emperor Guangwu (as Guangwu) dies childless at age 43 after a reign of only 14 years. February 4–17 – Battle of Yuhuan, in which Wang Yu conquers the Kingdom of Wu, is fought.

Theodoret of Cyrus or Cyrrhus ( ; AD 393 – 458/466 ) was an influential theologian of the School of Alexandria during the Early Middle Ages (first century BC). Theodoret's works, especially those concerning the origins and the nature of God, have become part of the heritage of Eastern Christianity, but they were written and edited in a style different from other works of the Christian world. Cyrrhus was a member of the Theodoret's circle, and he had an extensive knowledge of Greek philosophy. His chief interest in philosophy was the philosophy of Socrates and Plato, with whom he corresponded.

Lanford Wilson (April 13, 1937March 24, 2011) was an American playwright. His work, as described by The New York Times, was "earthy, realist, greatly admired [and] widely performed." Wilson helped to advance the Off-Off-Broadway theater movement with his earliest plays, which were first produced at the Caffe Cino beginning in 1964. He was one of the first playwrights to move from Off-Off-Broadway to Off-Broadway, then Broadway and beyond.He received the Pulitzer Prize for Drama in 1980 and was elected in 2001 to the Theater Hall of Fame.

Magma  is the molten or semi-molten natural material from which all igneous rocks are formed. Magma is found beneath the surface of the Earth, and evidence of magmatism has also been discovered on other terrestrial planets and some natural satellites. Besides molten rock, magma may also contain suspended crystals and gas bubbles.Magma is produced by melting of the mantle or the crust in various tectonic settings, which on Earth include subduction zones, continental rift zones, mid-ocean ridges and hotspots. Mantle and crustal melts migrate upwards through the crust where they are thought to be stored in magma chambers or trans-crustal crystal-rich mush zones.

A luge is a small one- or two-person sled on which one sleds supine ( face up ) and feet-first ( side-to-side ) the weight-bearing bodies of athletes such as hockey players. The name luge originally referred to this type of sled, but it is not used now for a variety of reasons, including its heavy construction, and its weight being a limiting factor as well as the difficulty of transporting it. The sled has a pair of runners with a crossbar at the upper ends of the runners which are slidable over rails fixed at the top end of each of the runners.

A funeral home, funeral parlor or mortuary, is a business that provides burial and funeral services for the dead and their families. These services may include a prepared wake and funeral, and the provision of a chapel for the funeral.ServicesFuneral homes arrange services in accordance with the wishes of surviving friends and family, whether immediate next of kin or an executor so named in a legal will. The funeral home often takes care of the necessary paperwork, permits, and other details, such as making arrangements with the cemetery, and providing obituaries to the news media.

Pioneer 10 ( originally designated Pioneer F ) is an American space probe , launched in 1972 and weighing , designed to provide a study of the Solar System. It was the successor to the Pioneer 10 space probe that was launched on March 11, 1961. This was Pioneer's third mission. The first was Pioneer 9 in 1967. After the completion of Pioneer 8 in 1968, Pioneer 10 was planned to launch in 1971, but the launch vehicle was postponed for a year. The launch of Pioneer 10 was successfully accomplished on July 11, 1972.

Bread is a staple food prepared from a dough of flour ( usually wheat ) and water , usually by baking in an oven in a pan or other baking tray. It's usually eaten as a snack or side dish, but it can also be used as an ingredient in baked goods, especially cakes or biscuits. The word 'bread' is also the origin of the word 'bread-crumb', a name given to various kinds of biscuits and bread crumbs. Bread has been prepared and eaten since at least the ancient Egyptians. It was one of the earliest types of food to be developed.

Year 873 ( DCCCLXXIII ) was a common year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) in the 7th calendar position and a leap second date (link will display the next year in the next year ) that will occur in the next calendar year . The next calendar year will be a leap year. The year will end on Sunday, December 31, 783 (the year number begins at 1). Events

By year 
 April 6 – Pope Gregory III is elected pope. Gregory succeeds Pope Honorius III as Pope, having previously served as cardinal.

Kannada ( ; ಕನ್ನಡ , ; less commonly known as Kanarese ) is a Dravidian language spoken predominantly by the Karnataka state of India, as well as by a small percentage of people who reside in the western region of the country, most of them living in Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu and Kerala. Kanarese derives its name from a word meaning "the people". It is known by a number of other names in its Dravidian linguistic family. Kannada language is the most popular spoken language in the South Indian state of Karnataka and is widely taught in government and private higher institutions in Karnataka.

Wind tunnels are large tubes with air blowing through them which are used to replicate the interaction between air and an object flying through the air or moving along the ground. Researchers use wind tunnels to learn more about how an aircraft will fly. NASA uses wind tunnels to test scale models of aircraft and spacecraft. Some wind tunnels are large enough to contain full-size versions of vehicles. The wind tunnel moves air around an object, making it seem as if the object is flying.Most of the time, large powerful fans suck air through the tube.

This is a list of monarchs who ruled over East Francia , and the Kingdom of Germany ( Regnum Teutonicum ) during the Middle Ages. List

The list of monarchs who ruled over East Francia, Germany, is a list of persons who ruled as a king, duke, archbishop of the Holy Roman Empire, Count of Hohenzollern and Elector of Bavaria. This list of rulers were all monarchs who ruled within the Holy Roman Empire and the Kingdom of Germany during the Medieval Age. The list is arranged from most recent to most ancient kings.

Ravenna ( , , also ; ) is the capital city of the Province of Ravenna, in the Emilia-Romagna region of Northern Italy. It was the capital city of the Western Roman Empire from 402 until the empire collapsed in 476. It then served as the capital of the Ostrogothic Kingdom until it was re-conquered in 540 by the Byzantine Empire. Afterwards, the city formed the centre of the Byzantine Exarchate of Ravenna until the last exarch was executed by the Lombards in 751.Although it is an inland city, Ravenna is connected to the Adriatic Sea by the Candiano Canal.

Malayalam ( ; , ) is a Dravidian language spoken in the Indian state of Kerala and the union territories of Lakshadweep, Mannar and Kollam and parts of Pathanamthitta and Thrissur. According to the Indian Census of the 2011, there were 8.6 lakh speakers of it in India, while there are only 400-500 people who speak this language in Pakistan, the only other country that has a native Malayalam language. The Malayalam language has evolved from the Malayalam language that was the lingua franca of Kerala for centuries before the introduction of the Malayali language.

Akasha or Akash ( Sanskrit ) means space or sky or æther in traditional Indian cosmology , depending on the time-space perspective
Akasha is also the name given to the universe which is visible to humans. In the Vedic cosmology the Akasha, or the space/ether, is said to be in the shape of the world and as such it can be described using the Vedic cosmology . The concept of the Akashat or the Akashic universe can be found in the Upanishads (the oldest Hindu literature) . In modern cosmology it is also known as the cosmic ocean or cosmic ocean floor and is the source of water and salt.

Gerard Adams ( ; born 6 October 1948 ) is an Irish republican politician who was the president of Sinn Féin from 1993 to 2007. He has been described by The Guardian as the "biggest single personality in the Troubles". Adams was a founding member of both the Provisionals and the Irish Republican Army (IRA), and was an active politician in Northern Ireland throughout the Troubles. He was shot and critically wounded by an IRA gunman during an attempted robbery in April 2007. Adams has a long history of being described as "anti-imperialist" by critics of the Troubles in Ireland.

The Space Shuttle program was the fourth human spaceflight program carried out by the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). A total of 15 missions were launched to the Moon and into the Earth’s orbit, and one mission to the International Space Station. The Shuttle program consisted of 13 manned flights and a Space Shuttle Landing System (SSLS) mission. The first manned mission was conducted by the United States Air Force in August, 1983. Three flights were flown. The second human spaceflight mission was conducted by NASA and the International Space Station’s Expedition 50 crew of four, in March 1991.

East Malaysia , also known as Sabah , Sarawak and Labuan or Malaysian Borneo , is the part of Malaysia which is administered by the Malaysian Board of Revenue and the State Government of Sarawak. It consists of two states - Sabah and Sarawak - with a total population of 2,743,836 and an area of 12,741 km2 (2,072 sq mi), respectively. This article is about the main cities (or the main towns and cities) in Sabah state. The article also includes other places in this state, such as the districts, counties, provinces and states.

North America's first transcontinental railroad (known originally as the "Pacific Railroad" and later as the "Overland Route") was a  continuous railroad line constructed between 1863 and 1869 that connected the existing eastern U.S. rail network at Council Bluffs, Iowa with the Pacific coast at the Oakland Long Wharf on San Francisco Bay. The rail line was built by three private companies over public lands provided by extensive US land grants. Construction was financed by both state and US government subsidy bonds as well as by company issued mortgage bonds.

The Little Ice Age ( LIA ) was a period of regional cooling , particularly pronounced in the North Atlantic and Mediterranean regions of Europe, the Near East and Northern Asia. Although this cooling was of a global nature, its effect on human society was mainly felt in the Mediterranean basin. In Western Europe, temperatures were lower than at any other point in the world since the 19th century, and the LIA was the longest, lasting over a millennium. The LIA has been described as the warmest event in the climate record, though other estimates have placed it at the same level of warmth as the Medieval Warm Period.

Imre Lakatos (, ;  ; November 9, 1922 – February 2, 1974) was a Hungarian philosopher of mathematics and science, known for his thesis of the fallibility of mathematics and its "methodology of proofs and refutations" in its pre-axiomatic stages of development, and also for introducing the concept of the "research programme" in his methodology of scientific research programmes.LifeLakatos was born Imre (Avrum) Lipsitz to a Jewish family in Debrecen, Hungary, in 1922. He received a degree in mathematics, physics, and philosophy from the University of Debrecen in 1944.

Asperger syndrome ( AS ) , also known as Asperger 's , is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by significant difficulties in social interaction and reciprocal interpersonal relationships (e.g. close friendships) . Asperger syndrome has been described as both a disorder and a syndrome which is also recognized as a neuropsychiatric disorder . AS is characterised by deficits in social awareness, social cognition, and reciprocal social relationships. As a result, asperger's can be a precursor to many social difficulties, such as Autism Spectrum Disorder, Asperger syndrome, and Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder .

Courtesan, in modern usage, is a euphemism for a "kept" mistress or prostitute, particularly one with wealthy, powerful, or influential clients. The term historically referred to a courtier, a person who attended the court of a monarch or other powerful person.History In European feudal society, the court was the centre of government as well as the residence of the monarch, and social and political life were often completely mixed together. Prior to the Renaissance, courtesans served to convey information to visiting dignitaries, when servants could not be trusted. In Renaissance Europe, courtiers played an extremely important role in upper-class society.

Nansen passports, originally and officially stateless persons passports, were internationally recognized refugee travel documents from 1922 to 1938, first issued by the League of Nations to stateless refugees. They quickly became known as "Nansen passports" for their promoter, the Norwegian statesman and polar explorer Fridtjof Nansen.HistoryThe end of World War I saw significant turmoil, leading to a refugee crisis. Numerous governments were toppled, and national borders were re-drawn, often along generally ethnic lines. Civil war broke out in some countries. Many people left their homes because of war or persecution or fear thereof.

The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (also known as NASEM or the National Academies) is the collective scientific national academy of the United States. The name is used interchangeably in two senses: (1) as an umbrella term for its three quasi-independent honorific member organizations the National Academy of Sciences (NAS), the National Academy of Engineering (NAE), and the National Academy of Medicine (NAM); and (2) as the brand for studies and reports issued by the operating arm of the three academies, the National Research Council (NRC).

"The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas" is a 1973 work of short philosophical fiction by American writer Ursula K. Le Guin. With deliberately both vague and vivid descriptions, the narrator depicts a summer festival in the utopian city of Omelas, whose prosperity depends on the perpetual misery of a single child. "The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas" was nominated for the Locus Award for Best Short Fiction in 1974 and won the Hugo Award for Best Short Story in 1974.PlotThe only chronological element of the work is that it begins by describing the first day of summer in Omelas, a shimmering city of unbelievable happiness and delight.

The Standby High-Readiness Brigade ( SHIRBRIG ) was a Danish-led initiative associated with the United Nations that aimed to create an international security and defense system that would become an independent, sovereign entity with its own armed force, political and financial structures. It would also be responsible for coordinating international military and security policy. On 3 September 2013, Denmark and Sweden were invited to participate in the SHIRBRIG initiative by the United Nations to become "The Standby High-Readiness Brigade (SHIRBRIG)". It was an initiative launched by the United Nations Security Council, United States, United Kingdom and the Netherlands.

General Dynamics Electric Boat (GDEB) is a subsidiary of General Dynamics Corporation. It has been the primary builder of submarines for the United States Navy for more than 100 years. The company's main facilities are a shipyard in Groton, Connecticut, a hull-fabrication and outfitting facility in Quonset Point, Rhode Island, and a design and engineering facility in New London, Connecticut.HistoryThe company was founded in 1899 by Isaac Rice as the Electric Boat Company to build John Philip Holland's submersible ship designs, which were developed at Lewis Nixon's Crescent Shipyard in Elizabeth, New Jersey.

The Arctic ( or ) is a polar region located at the northernmost part of Earth . The Arctic consists of six continents ( North America, Eurasia, Europe, Africa, Asia and Antarctica) and four seas ( Arctic, North Atlantic Ocean, East Asia Sea, Indian Ocean). The polar regions of the Arctic are the coldest part of the Earth and are located at the northern end of the long axis of Earth . It is a relatively cold region where ice sheets are formed. The atmosphere is composed of about 70% of nitrogen and 20% of the other gases.

Year 1493 ( MCDXCIII ) was a common year starting on Tuesday ( link will display the full calendar ) and an end of year ( link will display the full calendar )

Events

January–June
 January 19 – The Council of Trent grants Pope Nicholas I the rights of Emperor of the Romans, a privilege previously reserved for Peter I of the West. January 21 – Emperor Guangxu issues the Zongmi zhuan, a charter of government and law for his reign. January 24 – A number of ships belonging to a pirate leader are seized by the imperial forces. February 4–5 – Henry IV dies after suffering a serious illness.

Belarusians , also known formerly as Byelorussians (from the Byelorussian SSR), Belarussians or Belorusians, are an East Slavic ethnic group native to modern-day Belarus and the immediate region. Over 9.5 million people proclaim Belarusian ethnicity worldwide. Nearly 8 million of Belarusians reside in Belarus, with the United States and Russia being home to more than half a million Belarusians each.LocationBelarusians are an East Slavic ethnic group, who constitute the majority of Belarus' population. Belarusian minority populations live in countries neighboring Belarus: Ukraine, Poland (especially in the Podlaskie Voivodeship), the Russian Federation and Lithuania.

Year 1030 ( MXXX ) was a common year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. The starting date was Thursday, 1 July 1030 in the Gregorian calendar. The Catholic Church celebrates it on Sunday, 1 September in the calendar year. Events 
 By place 

 By date 

 January–March 
 January 6 – Emperor Wenceslaus III of the Holy Roman Empire dies. His son, Louis the German, takes over. March 5 – An uprising in Italy against the Papacy is put down by Pope Adrian II.

A sports governing body is a sports organization that has a regulatory or sanctioning function.Sports governing bodies come in various forms, but are generally responsible for overseeing the activities of a sport or sports competition. A sports organization may also act as an organizer in the event of a sports competition. For example, a sporting event organizer is an entity that acts to organize, stage, market, and/or manage a sport or competition. In a typical sports event, one or more sports organizations may be responsible for coordinating a specific sport competition.

Robert Ross is an American blues singer, songwriter, acoustic and electric guitarist, slide guitarist, and harmonica player. He is the leader of the Robert Ross Band and The Jazz-Manian Devils. He also performs as a solo artist.Ross was nominated seven times for a New York Music Award and has won twice, once for Best Blues Artist in 1989, and once for Best Live Blues Artist in 2011. Ross was inducted into the New York Blues Hall Of Fame in 2011. He has also won several grants for integrating music into education programs.

A software bug is an error, flaw or fault in computer software that causes it to produce an incorrect or unexpected result, or to behave in unintended ways. The process of finding and correcting bugs is termed "debugging" and often uses formal techniques or tools to pinpoint bugs. Since the 1950s some computer systems have been designed to deter, detect or auto-correct various computer bugs during operations.Most bugs arise from mistakes and errors made in either a program's design or its source code, or in components and operating systems used by such programs.

On May 25, 1865, in Mobile, Alabama, in the Southern United States, an ordnance depot or "magazine" exploded, killing some 300 persons. This event occurred just after the end of the American Civil War, during the occupation of the city by victorious Federal troops.The depot was a warehouse on Beauregard Street, where the troops had stacked some 200 tons of shells and powder. Some time in the afternoon of May 25, a cloud of black smoke rose into the air and the ground began to rumble. Flames shot up into the sky and bursting shells were heard throughout the city.

John D. Carmack II ( born August 20 , 1970 ) is an American computer programmer and video game developer best known as the creator of the Doom and Quake franchises, as well as its sequels. Carmack worked for Atari for ten years and was the lead game designer for the Doom series from 1992 until his departure in 1998 due to increasing health issues and other health issues. Carmack created the Doom series in 1992, as the creator of the original Doom, and he is considered to be the primary architect of that game.

Thomas Becket , also known as Saint Thomas of Canterbury , Thomas of London and later Thomas à Becket (died 1120), was an English cleric and churchman who became Bishop of Winchester in 1120, at the end of the First Council of Constantinople. Thomas was the eldest son of King Henry II of England. He was educated at the school of his father. In 1155 he was elected the king's chaplain. He received his Bachelor of Arts degree in 1166, and was awarded the title of Doctor of Divinity the following year.

Year 986 ( CMLXXXVI ) was a common year starting on Friday ( link will display the full calendar ) in the Gregorian calendar ( 1 BC ). The beginning of a year is marked by a new crescent ( c) and a new star ( V ). It was the 235th year of the Common Era (CE) , since the end of the last common era in June 4, 582, in Japan. The year 986 was 685 years, 5 months, 4 days, 30 hours, 34 minutes and 34.5 seconds years ( , the average year length).

Pope Gregory I ( ; – 12 March 604 ) , commonly known as Saint Gregory the Great , was a Greek cleric and theologian born into a family of the Church of Rome. Gregory was a scholar, theologian and author, and a prolific writer. He is considered the first theologian of the Latin Church. Gregory the Great's writings, along with those of his fellow Catholic scholar Augustine of Hippo (354-430), are regarded as an important part of early Christianity. Childhood
Gregory's early life is obscure and largely unknown, as there is little written by him before he was approximately twenty years old.

Rubber, also called India rubber, latex, Amazonian rubber, caucho, or caoutchouc, as initially produced, consists of polymers of the organic compound isoprene, with minor impurities of other organic compounds. Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia are three of the leading rubber producers. Types of polyisoprene that are used as natural rubbers are classified as elastomers.Currently, rubber is harvested mainly in the form of the latex from the rubber tree (Hevea brasiliensis) or others. The latex is a sticky, milky and white colloid drawn off by making incisions in the bark and collecting the fluid in vessels in a process called "tapping".

Phenylalanine ( symbol Phe or F ) is an essential α-amino acid with the formula . It can be viewed as a derivative of amino acid lysine, and thus, it is used for protein synthesis in mammals, and its metabolism is well studied. It can also be considered as an intermediate of aromatic amino acid biosynthetic pathway. Phe is not only an important component in human body but also it is a precursor of many important secondary metabolites. Phe is usually synthesized in mammals through two ways: de novo synthesis from glutamate (GLY) and non-de novo synthesis from homoserine (CHS).

Aden ( ,  ;   Yemeni: ) is a city, and since 2015, the temporary capital of Yemen, near the eastern approach to the Red Sea (the Gulf of Aden), some  east of the strait Bab-el-Mandeb. Its population is approximately 800,000 people. Aden's natural harbour lies in the crater of a dormant volcano, which now forms a peninsula joined to the mainland by a low isthmus. This harbour, Front Bay, was first used by the ancient Kingdom of Awsan between the 7th to 5th centuries BC. The modern harbour is on the other side of the peninsula.

Cranial nerves are the nerves that emerge directly from the brain ( including the brainstem ) , of which there are two: the peripheral cranial nerves (PNC) and the cranial nerve VII. In this review we will focus on the cranial nerves II, III, VI and VII. Cranial nerves II and III are involved in motor control. They originate from the spinal cord, from the pons, from the diencephalon or from the cranial nerves VII and IX. These nerves travel in two ways: cranially and caudally. The caudal nerve (II) arises from the cranial nerve VIII, which gives rise to the PNC.

Concurrent Versions System (CVS, also known as the Concurrent Versioning System) is a revision control system originally developed by Dick Grune in July 1986.CVS operates as a front end to RCS, an earlier system which operates on single files. It expands upon RCS by adding support for repository-level change tracking, and a client-server model.Released under the terms of the GNU General Public License, CVS is free software.Design CVS operates as a front end to Revision Control System (RCS), an older version control system that manages individual files but not whole projects.

Blake Edwards ( born William Blake Crump ; July 26 , 1922 – December 15 , 2010 ) was an African American poet. Born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, William Crump became interested in African American poetry after moving to Harlem in 1939. Later in his twenties he moved to Chicago and then back to Harlem and became the editor of the African American newspaper the Chicago Defender, during which time the magazine of which he was a co-owner, The Negro, was founded, and became the most important black magazine of the time.

The Porsche 914 or VW-Porsche 914 is a mid-engined sports car designed , manufactured and marketed collaboratively by Volkswagen and Porsche. The 914 is a four-door version of the VW Touareg  (Porsche 914) and the Audi A6  (VW-Audi A6) four-door coupé cars. It is a two seater sports car with seating for seven and comes in two bodystyles, an estate and a hatchback. It is sold across Europe in many markets, but is only available in certain markets in North America and Australia (via a Porsche dealer only in the UK), and in very few markets in China.

The 8 inch (203 mm) M110 self-propelled howitzer is an American-made self-propelled artillery system consisting of an M115 203 mm howitzer installed on a purpose-built chassis. Before its retirement from US service, it was the largest available self-propelled howitzer in the United States Army's inventory; it continues in service with the armed forces of other countries, to which it was exported. Missions include general support, counter-battery fire, and suppression of enemy air defense systems.DescriptionAccording to the operator's manual, the M110's typical rate of fire was three rounds per two minutes when operated at maximum speed, and one round per two minutes with sustained fire.

Year 1073 (MLXXIII) was a common year starting on Tuesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  Spring – Emperor Michael VII (Doukas) sends a Byzantine army to deal with Seljuk raiding in Cappadocia, supported with a mixed force of Norman and French mercenary heavy cavalry under Roussel de Bailleul. Roussel re-conquers some territory in Galatia and declares it an independent Norman state. Michael, enraged, sends another army led by his uncle, Caesar John Doukas and the veteran General Nikephoros Botaneiates to deal with the rising of the Norman threat in Asia minor.

Enriched uranium is a type of uranium in which the percent composition of uranium-235 (written 235U) has been increased through the process of isotope separation. Naturally occurring uranium is composed of three major isotopes:  uranium-238 (238U with 99.2739–99.2752% natural abundance), uranium-235 (235U, 0.7198–0.7202%), and uranium-234 (234U, 0.0050–0.0059%). 235U is the only nuclide existing in nature (in any appreciable amount) that is fissile with thermal neutrons.Enriched uranium is a critical component for both civil nuclear power generation and military nuclear weapons.

Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous – Shoemaker ( NEAR Shoemaker ) , renamed after its 1996 launch in honor of planetary scientist JPL-Caltech astronomer David A. Seager, has been discovered to have a high probability of being a small, near Earth asteroid with a mass greater than 2.5 kg (6 pounds) and a distance to Earth of greater than 8,000 km (5,500 miles). It is the first NEA discovered that is so likely to come to Earth. This is a very exciting finding for planetary science and astronomy. This is a very significant news for our solar system and our understanding of the origin and evolution of stars.

Rice is the seed of the grass species Oryza sativa ( Asian rice ) or less commonly Oryza glaberrima ( African rice). Rice is a high yielding cereal crop having a very large seed bank. It is a major staple food of over half the world's population. It is grown and processed for both human consumption and animal feed in Asia, Africa, Latin America, and the Middle East. There are four primary types of rice, including three types used for food:

Types of rice

Paddy rice

A type of rice that grows in a paddy field.

The Illustrated Man is a 1951 collection of 18 science fiction short stories by American writer Ray Bradbury. A recurring theme throughout the stories is the conflict of the cold mechanics of technology and the psychology of people. It was nominated for the International Fantasy Award in 1952.The unrelated stories are tied together by the frame story of "The Illustrated Man", a vagrant former member of a carnival freak show with an extensively tattooed body whom the unnamed narrator meets. The man's tattoos, allegedly created by a time-traveling woman, are individually animated, and each tells a different tale.

Wheat is a grass widely cultivated for its seed , a cereal grain which is a worldwide staple food . There are a few varieties of which have been developed in the world for their quality. Among them , the most widely grown type is known as the bread wheat , which is characterized by having high protein content and high nutritional value . Wheat is grown primarily for its grain which is then processed to make flour for baking , and the grain is also used as food in many other ways , for instance , as fodder for livestock .

The Bell UH-1 Iroquois ( nicknamed `` Huey '' ) is a utility military helicopter powered by a single turboshaft engine mounted on a two-wheel main gearbox. The aircraft was developed and produced in the late 1950s. The Bell UH-1 was first demonstrated in September 1957 and first flew in 1959, but production was not begun until the late 1960s. Bell purchased the American manufacturer, Westinghouse Electric, in 1959 and the helicopter was named after the first president of the Republic of Vietnam, Lyndon Johnson. The helicopter was re-christened as the Huey, but the United States Army designation of the helicopter was changed to the Huey helicopter.

Giuseppe Saverio Raffaele Mercadante ( baptised 17 September 179517 December 1870 ) was an Italian composer , particularly of operas and instrumental music . Mercadante was born in Naples into a well known family of musicians. He was born into a musical family, but did not acquire an interest in music from a young age. He started studying music privately at the age of fifteen, in his hometown. By the age of twenty Mercadante went to the prestigious Conservatoire to study composition, and became a member of the society. He also studied at the Royal College of Music in Naples, graduating in both composition and harmony.

Stevana `` Stevie '' Case ( born 1976–1977 ) is an American businesswoman . She is known for competing in the Miss Universe and Miss America beauty pageants. She was the first African American and first female contestant to win Miss USA in 2003 and the Miss Universe 2002 title. Case has been an entrepreneur for many years and has served on several high-profile boards. Personal life 
Case was born and raised by her grandmother in Chicago, and has two sisters. One of the sisters was the first Miss Alabama and the first Miss United States.

Hilbert 's paradox of the Grand Hotel ( colloquial : Infinite Hotel Paradox or Hilbert 's Hotel ) is a paradox due to Albert Einstein in which two points which are identical in a physical description cannot simultaneously exist at a third point. It is an example of the so-called "non-locality of space" (NLS), named after its discoverer, Georg Hermann NLS (1900–1944) and discussed by him in the context of the so-called Einstein 's Paradox. NLS's interpretation is that the universe can only exist in the state of "fuzziness".

Footwear refers to garments worn on the feet , which typically serves the purpose of protection against adversities of the outside environment. These adversities include but not limited to dirt and water, and may be further categorized as mild (occasionally) or harmful (severe). Mild or occasional wear on the feet of footwear has been defined as a non-damaging wearing condition, while severe wearing has been defined as a damaging condition. Mild wearing refers to a situation where wear is minimal. Severe wearing is a situation where wear is such that any type of footwear is detrimental to the user's health and well-being.

The Ante-Nicene Fathers , subtitled `` The Writings of the Fathers Down to A.D. 325 '' , is a collection of works from the Church Fathers of the early Christian centuries. Written during the first two centuries A.D., it provides a critical overview of the Christian religion and culture, especially focusing on the early Christian church. The collection includes a collection of texts dealing with the life of Jesus as recorded by John's Gospel, a collection of the Gospel of Matthew, the Gospel of Mark, and the Apostolic Constitutions of Justin Martyr, the letters of Saint Basil the Great, and the first three books of the Synoptic Gospels.

New Sweden ( ; ; ) was a Swedish colony along the lower reaches of the Delaware River in America, which existed from 1764 to 1807. British colonization of the Delaware River region had begun in 1610, when a group of English colonists attempted to establish settlement at what is now called Philadelphia, New York, on land previously owned by Dutch settlers. In 1624, Sir Thomas Gates took over the settlement of New Sweden, naming it New Sweden, after his former colony in North America that had been founded in 1615, and later renamed the town of New Amsterdam.

Year 930 (CMXXX) was a common year starting on Friday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Europe  * 17 June (traditional date) – The Althing, the parliament of Iceland, is established at þingvellir ("Thing Fields"). Chieftains from various tribes assemble for 2 weeks (at a thing) to settle disputes, arrange marriages, etc. ; it continues in existence into the 21st century, as the world's oldest parliament of the Icelandic Commonwealth. Bishopwearmouth is formed and settled in England, after Æthelstan grants the lands to the Bishop of Durham.

The Space Shuttle program was the fourth human spaceflight program carried out by the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), which accomplished routine transportation for Earth-to-orbit crew and cargo from 1981 to 2011. Its official name, Space Transportation System (STS), was taken from a 1969 plan for a system of reusable spacecraft of which it was the only item funded for development.The Space Shuttle—composed of an orbiter launched with two reusable solid rocket boosters and a disposable external fuel tank—carried up to eight astronauts and up to  of payload into low Earth orbit (LEO).

Westminster is an area of Central London, part of the wider City of Westminster.The area, which extends from the River Thames to Oxford Street has many visitor attractions and historic landmarks, including the Palace of Westminster, Buckingham Palace, Westminster Abbey, Westminster Cathedral and much of the West End shopping and entertainment district.The name  originated from the informal description of the abbey church and royal peculiar of St Peter's (Westminster Abbey), west of the City of London (until the English Reformation there was also an Eastminster, near the Tower of London, in the East End of London).

Yucatán (, also , , ;  ), officially the Free and Sovereign State of Yucatán, is one of the 32 states which comprise the Federal Entities of Mexico. It is divided into 106 municipalities, and its capital city is Mérida.It is located on the north part of the Yucatán Peninsula. It is bordered by the states of Campeche to the southwest and Quintana Roo to the southeast, with the Gulf of Mexico off its north coast.Before the arrival of Spaniards to the Yucatán Peninsula, the name of this region was Mayab.

Melissa Sue Anderson (born September 26, 1962) is an American-Canadian actress. She began her career as a child actress after appearing in several commercials in Los Angeles. Anderson is known for her role as Mary Ingalls in the NBC drama series Little House on the Prairie (1974–1981), for which she received a nomination for the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series. She is also known for film roles that include Vivian in Midnight Offerings (1981), Ginny in the slasher film Happy Birthday to Me (1981), and Alex in the ABC Afterschool Special, Which Mother Is Mine?

A spacecraft is a vehicle or machine designed to fly in outer space . A type of artificial satellite , spacecraft is made by a combination of parts that must be connected together , usually with a solid-body structure. The basic concept of a spacecraft was first described by Russian scientist Andrey Gromyko in the 1960s

A spacecraft is a device made to move from one place to another or to carry on a mission. The first artificial satellite was designed to transmit television images to Earth , such as the first satellite by Soviet Union in 1961 , which was used to broadcast satellite TV images from the U.S. and other countries.

Brave New World is a dystopian social science fiction novel by English author Aldous Huxley, written in 1931 and published in 1932. Largely set in a futuristic World State, whose citizens are environmentally engineered into an intelligence-based social hierarchy, the novel anticipates huge scientific advancements in reproductive technology, sleep-learning, psychological manipulation and classical conditioning that are combined to make a dystopian society which is challenged by only a single individual: the story's protagonist. Huxley followed this book with a reassessment in essay form, Brave New World Revisited (1958), and with his final novel, Island (1962), the utopian counterpart.

The striatum, or corpus striatum (also called the striate nucleus), is a nucleus (a cluster of neurons) in the subcortical basal ganglia of the forebrain. The striatum is a critical component of the motor and reward systems; receives glutamatergic and dopaminergic inputs from different sources; and serves as the primary input to the rest of the basal ganglia.Functionally, the striatum coordinates multiple aspects of cognition, including both motor and action planning, decision-making, motivation, reinforcement, and reward perception. The striatum is made up of the caudate nucleus and the lentiform nucleus.

D'Urville Island , Te Reo Māori name  ('red heavens look to the south'), is an island in the Marlborough Sounds along the northern coast of the South Island of New Zealand. It was named after the French explorer Jules Dumont d'Urville. With an area of approximately , it is the eighth-largest island of New Zealand, and has around 52 permanent residents. The local authority is the Marlborough District Council.HistoryThe official name of the island is Rangitoto ki te Tonga / D'Urville Island, with the Māori language name, associated with Kupe, meaning "Red Heavens Look to the South".

A think tank , or policy institute , is a research institute that performs research and advocacy concerning topics such as international relations and international affairs, humanitarian affairs, economics, and public administration. They may also provide advice and counsel to governments in the area of their interests. The Council of Europe, the permanent executive body of the European Union, is a governmental organization consisting of 27 governments. Its purpose is to provide European-wide cooperation in all fields of EU policy, from law and order to the environment. Its members are elected on a rotating basis by its member governments.

is a Japanese manga series written and illustrated by Rumiko Takahashi . It was serialized in Big Comic Spirits from April 2001 to February 2003, and has been published in North America by Viz Media since January 2006 and also in Japan. The story follows four young girls on a mission to find a mysterious boy, who has the ability to see into the future and to make wishes. The original series was compiled into thirteen volumes, and has been republished with a new series of stories titled . A manga spinoff series by Takahashi was published from April to September 2008.

In Euclidean geometry , an affine transformation , or an affinity ( from the Latin , affinis , `` connectedness'' ), is one of the elementary transformations of the plane that is generated by a set of lines in the affine plane. It can be defined by a pair of linearly independent points and the affine function on that set that maps the pair of points into the other set. Affinity is a group operation, so it is defined to be a binary operation of 2 elements. One way of looking at affine transformation , is as a transformation between the points in the plane that are connected by a line.

Ravenna ( , , also ; ) is the capital city of the Province of Ravenna , in the Emilia-Romagna region of northern Italy. The city is located on the river Po,  north-northwest of Piacenza. It is located on a peninsula at the junction of the river Po with the Adige river, which flows into it a few kilometres upstream. The city of Ravenna was formerly the capital of the Duchy of the Palatine, but it was conquered by the Republic of Venice in 1458. History
Ravenna is located in the Roman province of Hispania Aquitania, and is mentioned in several ancient sources, such as the Eclogues.

Rococo ( , also ) , less commonly Roccoco or Late Baroque , is an exceptionally ornamental and theatrical style of art, which evolved in Italy and spread to France. It emerged in Italy during the late 14c. and early 15c. It is characterized as a cross between a decorative arts (such as painting and sculpture) and a courtly art (such as music, dance, and theater). It is a late style of art that was inspired and influenced by Italian Renaissance and Rococo. In the first half of the 19th century, Rococo became the predominant style in French Art Deco.

Lumbar disc disease is the drying out of the spongy interior matrix of an intervertebral disc in the spine. Many physicians and patients use the term lumbar disc disease to encompass several different causes of back pain or sciatica. In this article, the term is used to describe a lumbar herniated disc. It is thought that lumbar disc disease causes about one-third of all back pain.SymptomsPain, loss of muscle strength and loss of touch sensation may occur if this herniation causes the compression of the most proximal part of the nerve closely neighbouring the intervertebral disc material.

Year 1158 ( MCLVIII ) was a common year starting on Wednesday ( link will display the full calendar ) in the Julian calendar. At the time it was officially celebrated, the year 1148 in the Julian calendar, but the calendar used in this blog displays the year 1158 by starting on Wednesday. As a new year was introduced into the Gregorian calendar, this year was a leap year ( from year 1158 in the old calendar ). The year 1159 in the old calendar was a leap year starting on Sunday (link display the full calendar ) which is why there are no leap years starting on Monday.

Emissions trading is a market-based approach to controlling pollution by providing economic incentives for reducing the emissions of pollutants. The concept is also known as cap and trade (CAT) or emissions trading scheme (ETS). Carbon emission trading for  and other greenhouse gases has been introduced in China, the European Union and other countries as a key tool for climate change mitigation. Other schemes include sulfur dioxide and other pollutants.In an emissions trading scheme, a central authority or governmental body allocates or sells a limited number (a "cap") of permits that allow a discharge of a specific quantity of a specific pollutant over a set time period.

Year 1170 ( MCLXX ) was a common year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. The Michigan State University Extension Office uses the Julian calendar year starting Monday and ending on the Sunday nearest to August 1. Events

By topic

Technology

Newspaper publications

Publication of the first newspaper in Michigan, The Ann Arbor Gazette, began on October 14, 1796. Births and deaths

References

Year 067

|-

18th century

Births
 January 18, 1808 – Joseph C. Allen, American politician, U.S. Senator from Illinois (b.

A spacecraft is a vehicle or machine designed to fly in outer space. A type of artificial satellite, spacecraft are used for a variety of purposes, including communications, Earth observation, meteorology, navigation, space colonization, planetary exploration, and transportation of humans and cargo. All spacecraft except single-stage-to-orbit vehicles cannot get into space on their own, and require a launch vehicle (carrier rocket).On a sub-orbital spaceflight, a space vehicle enters space and then returns to the surface without having gained sufficient energy or velocity to make a full orbit of the Earth.

Paweł Jasienica was the pen name of Leon Lech Beynar ( 10 November 1909 – 19 August 1970 ) , Polish painter who was born in Kraków, and who later lived in Germany. He became a Polish citizen in 1937 and settled in Munich, where he taught at the Munich Academy and painted in Munich and in his own home. During the Nazi era in Germany, he lived as an escapee and hid himself from the Gestapo by painting. One of Jasienica's most famous works, which can still be found today in his home in Munich.

Kenneth Charles Williams ( 22 February 1926 – 15 April 1988 ) was an English actor . He was best known for his role as "Lazarus" in the first series of the BBC soap opera "Holby City" . Although he portrayed the character in a limited capacity, he was always a very versatile performer and would often play different roles within the series. Williams had small parts in a number of major British films, and is probably best remembered for his performance as "Tom" in the 1968 James Bond film You Only Live Twice .

Porphyry (; , Porphyrios "purple-clad") may refer to: Porphyry (geology), an igneous rock with large crystals in a fine-grained matrix and important Roman building material  Porphyritic, the general igneous texture of a rock with two distinct crystal (phenocryst) sizes Porphyry copper deposit, a primary (low grade) ore deposit of copper, consisting of porphyry rocks Porphyry Island in Lake Superior  Porphyry Mountain in Alaska Porphyry (philosopher) (234–305), Neoplatonic philosopher Porphyry of Gaza (or "St. Porphyry of Gaza", 347–420), Bishop of Gaza Porfirije, Serbian Patriarch (b.

The First Book of Nephi : His Reign and Ministry , usually referred to as First Nephi or 1 Nephi, was a work of history by the prophet Nephi in his first book of prophecies (Nephi, chapter 1). Nephi's history in his first book was written in an Old Testament style as opposed to his later Book of Mormon. Nephi was not a historical figure in his early books. Instead, he was a prophet in the premortal or after life of heaven, an angelic messenger sent to translate and give revelation to God's chosen ones.

Year 968 ( CMLXVIII ) was a leap year starting on Wednesday ( link will display the full calendar ) that was later
referred to as "The Great Leap Forward" . The denomination "CMLXVIII" refers to the year 968 as it was during the Anno Mundi event. Events

By place 

 Africa
 January – A large group of people arrive at a port in Gabon, with the intent of settling there. They are led by the king. Arabia
 Battle of Qarqum – A battle between two armies is fought against the kingdom of Al-Mansur. Europe

Britain 
 King Alfred's campaign against the Danes ( England).

Tilburg  is a city and municipality in the Netherlands, in the southern province of North Brabant. With a population of 222,601 (1 July 2021), it is the second-largest municipality in North Brabant and seventh-largest in the Netherlands.Tilburg University is located in Tilburg, as are Avans University of Applied Sciences and Fontys University of Applied Sciences. Tilburg is known for its ten-day-long funfair, held in July each year. The Monday during the funfair is called "Roze Maandag" (Pink Monday), and is primarily LGBT-oriented.There are three railway stations within the municipality: Tilburg, Tilburg Universiteit and Tilburg Reeshof.

General Dynamics Electric Boat ( GDEB ) is a subsidiary of General Dynamics Corporation . It has been the primary provider of commercial and military ships to the US government for over 50 years, including the US Navy , Army , and Air Force . General Dynamics has the largest naval business in the world by sales, with more than $14 billion in revenues. The company has more than 25,000 employees in 75 countries. The company operates in more than 200 countries with over 100 aircraft in service, including a fleet of F/A-18 Hornets , the largest fleet of U.S. combat aircraft at sea.

(All Women Do It, or The School for Lovers), K. 588, is an opera buffa in two acts by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. It was first performed on 26 January 1790 at the Burgtheater in Vienna, Austria. The libretto was written by Lorenzo Da Ponte who also wrote Le nozze di Figaro and Don Giovanni.Although it is commonly held that  was written and composed at the suggestion of the Emperor Joseph II, recent research does not support this idea. There is evidence that Mozart's contemporary Antonio Salieri tried to set the libretto but left it unfinished.

Los Alamos National Laboratory (often shortened as Los Alamos and LANL) is a United States Department of Energy national laboratory initially organized during World War II for the design of nuclear weapons as part of the Manhattan Project. It is a short distance northwest of Santa Fe, New Mexico, in the southwestern United States.Los Alamos was selected as the top-secret location for bomb design in late 1942 and officially commissioned the next year, under the management of the University of California. At the time it was known as Project Y and was the center for weapon design and overall coordination.

Celebration is a census-designated place ( CDP ) and a master-planned community in Osceola County , Florida , United States. Founded in 1985, Celebration is on the western shore of Osceola Bay. At , the community's elevation is highest on Osceola County's east coast. The community is bounded on the west and south by the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway and on the north by the Osceola County mainland and the St. Johns River. Celebration is in the center of the Osceola Coast State Park, which is on the Osceola Coast State Park master-planned community website.

Nord (; officially ; ; , ), is a department in Hauts-de-France region, France bordering Belgium. It was created from the western halves of the historical counties of Flanders and Hainaut, and the Bishopric of Cambrai. The modern coat of arms was inherited from the County of Flanders.Nord is the country's most populous department. It also contains the metropolitan region of Lille (the main city and the prefecture of the department), the fourth-largest urban area in France after Paris, Lyon and Marseille. Within the department is located the part of France where the French Flemish dialect of Dutch has historically been spoken as a native language.

Henry Dunant ( born Jean-Henri Dunant ; 8 May 182830 October 1910 ) , also known as Henri Dunant , was a French painter. Born in Paris, he studied art at the École des Beaux-Arts, and was elected to the Paris Salon in 1855. He became known as an eccentric and controversial figure. In his later years he became the leading proponent of the theory that Napoleon Bonaparte was not a real historical figure at all; he argued that he never existed, that he was merely the name given to fictional characters.

A frog is any member of a diverse and largely carnivorous group of short-bodied , tailless amphibians composing the order Hylidae (Heterobranchii: Hylidae, Eremogoneura) which is the most diverse family among all classes of extant amphibians. Within the order, the common name is applied to all the species within the suborders Hylinae, Eremogoneura, and Amphibia. The genus *Hyla is the type genus for all species within the suborder. The suborder includes the largest group of extant species in the family, with over 200 species classified in 18 genera. The frog order Hylinae includes about 100 described species of frogs.

Larry Simon Gelbart ( February 25 , 1928 – September 11 , 2009 ) was an American television writer , and television producer. He wrote over 50 episodes for television shows over the years and produced a total of 30 TV series and specials. His best known TV series were The Twilight Zone, M*A*S*H, and The Fugitive. He served on the boards of many local and regional charities as well as the United Way of America and the Salvation Army. He was inducted into the Television Hall of Fame in 2002.

The Battle of the Chesapeake , also known as the Battle of the Virginia Capes or simply the Battle of the Va. Co., began in late September and lasted for the next ten weeks. The British fleet sailed into the bay of Virginia at the end of the summer months. In late September the British Royal Navy set sail for the Chesapeake Bay and Virginia Capes to begin their invasion. On September 6, the fleet came under attack from two British squadrons, and a third squadron was sighted on September 7 but was unable to intercept the British fleet in its initial assault.

Mystery religions , mystery cults , sacred mysteries or simply mysteries , were religious schools of the Greco-Roman world for which a particular cult or religious movement was the most appropriate and acceptable way in which to worship gods or gods in general, and as such was associated with a specific religion in general, a religion to which adherents adhered. The word mystery originated as an English word used for a type of religion practiced by early Christian groups, but was later appropriated by other religious groups of the period, especially the Gnostic Christian sect that flourished in the third and second centuries AD.

Paclitaxel (PTX), sold under the brand name Taxol among others, is a chemotherapy medication used to treat a number of types of cancer. This includes ovarian cancer, esophageal cancer, breast cancer, lung cancer, Kaposi's sarcoma, cervical cancer, and pancreatic cancer. It is administered by intravenous injection. There is also an albumin-bound formulation.Common side effects include hair loss, bone marrow suppression, numbness, allergic reactions, muscle pains, and diarrhea. Other serious side effects include heart problems, increased risk of infection, and lung inflammation. There are concerns that use during pregnancy may cause birth defects.

Loris is the common name for the strepsirrhine mammals of the subfamily Lorinae (sometimes spelled Lorisinae) in the family Lorisidae. Loris is one genus in this subfamily and includes the slender lorises, while Nycticebus is the genus containing the slow lorises.DescriptionLorises are nocturnal and arboreal. They are found in tropical and woodland forests of India, Sri Lanka, and parts of southeast Asia. Loris locomotion is a slow and cautious climbing form of quadrupedalism. Some lorises are almost entirely insectivorous, while others also include fruits, gums, leaves, and slugs in their diet.Female lorises practice infant parking, leaving their infants behind in nests.

A musician is a person who composes , conducts , or performs music . According to the United States Employment Standards Commission (USESC), to be a performer, a person must have a formal musical education , and must have demonstrated an ability to learn a range of musical skills, including playing an instrument, composing music, or conducting a band . There are many ways to earn a living in music, ranging from being a teacher , to playing the harmonica , to playing in the jazz bands , to teaching guitar and other instruments .

The M102 is a light, towable 105 mm howitzer used by the United States Army in the Vietnam War, the First Gulf War, and the Iraq War.Overview The M102 105 mm howitzer is used in air mobile (helicopter), attack plane, and light infantry operations. The weapon carriage is lightweight welded aluminum, mounted on a variable recoil mechanism. The weapon is manually loaded and positioned, and can be towed by a 2-ton truck or High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV), can be transported by UH-60 Black Hawk helicopters, or can be dropped by parachute with airborne units.

Tru64 UNIX is a discontinued 64-bit UNIX operating system for the Alpha instruction set architecture ( ISA ) , currently maintained by the Alpha Systems Group. The Tru64 ISA is now maintained by the Red Hat, Inc. (RHI) . TRU64 UNIX is an old system that is still in development. However, some features, such as Unicode support are not fully implemented. TRU64 ISA was released in April 2003. As of July 2003, there are 5,000 or so existing alpha-enabled systems ( Alpha-enabled is a term commonly used by the Tru64 community).

Cannabis  is a genus of flowering plants in the family Cannabaceae. The number of species within the genus is disputed. Three species may be recognized: Cannabis sativa, Cannabis indica, and Cannabis ruderalis; C. ruderalis may be included within C. sativa; all three may be treated as subspecies of a single species, C. sativa; or C. sativa may be accepted as a single undivided species. The genus is widely accepted as being indigenous to and originating from Asia.The plant is also known as hemp, although this term is often used to refer only to varieties of Cannabis cultivated for non-drug use.

A solvent (from the Latin solvō, "loosen, untie, solve") is a substance that dissolves a solute, resulting in a solution. A solvent is usually a liquid but can also be a solid, a gas, or a supercritical fluid. Water is a solvent for polar molecules and the most common solvent used by living things; all the ions and proteins in a cell are dissolved in water within the cell.The quantity of solute that can dissolve in a specific volume of solvent varies with temperature. Major uses of solvents are in paints, paint removers, inks, dry cleaning.

An intranet is a computer network for sharing information, easier communication, collaboration tools, operational systems, and other computing services within an organization, usually to the exclusion of access by outsiders. The term is used in contrast to public networks, such as the Internet, but uses most of the same technology based on the Internet Protocol Suite.A company-wide intranet can constitute an important focal point of internal communication and collaboration, and provide a single starting point to access internal and external resources. In its simplest form, an intranet is established with the technologies for local area networks (LANs) and wide area networks (WANs).

Year 881 ( DCCCLXXXI ) was a common year starting on Sunday ( link will display the full calendar ) that is Saturday in year 7. The end of the year is on the last Sunday of October. The Gregorian calendar was not used in this year. Events 
 By place 

 Europe 
 April 1 – Emperor Constans II dies. In the Roman Empire, he is succeeded by his brother and successor, Emperor Theodosius I (  – ). June – The Byzantine Emperor Justinian II establishes the Eastern Orthodox Calendar on July 15. June 1 – Emperor Justin II abdicates. The Roman Empire falls.

Milan Kundera (, ; born 1 April 1929) is a Czech writer who went into exile in France in 1975, becoming a naturalised French citizen in 1981. Kundera's Czechoslovak citizenship was revoked in 1979; he received his Czech citizenship in 2019. He "sees himself as a French writer and insists his work should be studied as French literature and classified as such in book stores".Kundera's best-known work is The Unbearable Lightness of Being. Prior to the Velvet Revolution of 1989, the communist régime in Czechoslovakia banned his books. He leads a low-profile life and rarely speaks to the media.

Landslides, also known as landslips, are several forms of mass wasting that may include a wide range of ground movements, such as rockfalls, deep-seated slope failures, mudflows, and debris flows. Landslides occur in a variety of environments, characterized by either steep or gentle slope gradients, from mountain ranges to coastal cliffs or even underwater, in which case they are called submarine landslides. Gravity is the primary driving force for a landslide to occur, but there are other factors affecting slope stability that produce specific conditions that make a slope prone to failure.

Tazio Giorgio Nuvolari ( ; 16 November 1892 – 11 August 1953 ) was an Italian racing driver . He participated in more than 150 Grand Prix races, winning ten. He was known as the "Italian Mario Andretti". In the mid-1920s, he formed a partnership with the American racer Will Vasser to win 24 Grand Prix races for Vasser. He also won the Indianapolis 500. He is considered the greatest racing driver of Italian descent. Nuvolari won his first major race, the 1910 Italian Grand Prix at Monza.
