In 1914 he won the French Grand Prix and in 1917 he won the Italian Grand Prix.

A tremor is an involuntary , somewhat rhythmic , muscle contraction and relaxation involving oscillations or twitching movements of one or more parts of the body, like the arms or legs, often in an unnatural and jerky way. The origin and cause is still not completely known. In some cases it may be associated with epilepsy. What causes a tremor? What causes the tremor? What is a tremorgenous event? What is tremorgenous movement? What is the best cure for tremor and tremor-like movement? What can cause a tremor? What causes tremor

What can cause a tremor?

In the 1980s , the telecommunications industry expected that digital services would follow much the same pattern as voice services, namely, they would become increasingly inexpensive and ubiquitous. However, this has been far less the case. Digital technology, such as digital television and the Internet, are not as inexpensive as many had predicted, and so they are less available to consumers. The telecommunications industry has been trying to convince the consumer that the Internet, and the use of digital services, is something that the consumer should pay for, but it’s still not true.

Westminster is an area of Central London , part of the wider City of Westminster.The area , which extends from Clapham in the north, to Whitecross Road in the south, has long been part of the City of London, though it was previously in the County of Middlesex.The area covers a total area of around , and is part of the Metropolitan Borough of Westminster.The name Westminster comes from the Roman city of Vindex, which was located in the same area as the Palace of Westminster and St Paul's Cathedral, the seat of the UK Parliament.

The governor general of Canada is the federal viceregal representative of the . The is head of state of Canada, head of government of Canada, and head of government of Canada of the Commonwealth of Canada. Governor General (Canada)

Overview

The official title that the governor general of Canada is the holder of the position. Governor General of Canada (Ottawa) Act, 2005

The Official Title of the Ottawa Act,2005, is the title for the act which is the current title for the title that the Governor General of Canada holds in the country.

The Soma cube is a solid dissection puzzle invented by Danish polymath Piet Hein in 1933 during a lecture on the history of solid geometry. It consists of a 5×5 square, divided into seven cubes. It is the smallest of all the known cubes, and the smallest of all the cubes of any given size. Although it was originally called the 'Soma Cube', it is commonly referred to as the “Soma Cube” or “Cube cube” because it was described in the 1931 book A History of Plane Geometry by Danish polymath Piet Hein.

Pope Leo XI (; 2 June 153527 April 1605), born Alessandro Ottaviano de' Medici, was head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 1 April 1605 to his death. His pontificate is one of the briefest in history, having lasted under a month. He was from the prominent House of Medici originating from Florence. Medici's mother opposed his entering the priesthood and sought to prevent it by having him given secular honours, but after her death he eventually was ordained a priest in 1567.

Year 1030 (MXXX) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  Emperor Romanos III Argyros decides to retaliate upon the incursions of the Muslims on the eastern frontier. He leads a Byzantine expeditionary force (20,000 men) to secure Antioch. The Mirdasid emir Shibl al-Dawla Nasr of Aleppo sues for peace, but Romanos refuses to negotiate and leads his army against Aleppo, against the advice of his generals. The Byzantine army encamps near Azaz, where they are encircled by the Mirdasids' Bedouin troops, who cut off the Byzantines from food and water.

Patrick Jake O'Rourke (November 14, 1947 – February 15, 2022) was an American libertarian political satirist and journalist. O'Rourke was the H. L. Mencken Research Fellow at the libertarian Cato Institute and a regular correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly, The American Spectator, and The Weekly Standard, and frequent panelist on National Public Radio's game show Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me! He was a columnist at The Daily Beast from 2011 to 2016.He authored 16 books, including three that made The New York Times Best Seller list.

Isotope separation is the process of concentrating specific isotopes of a chemical element by removing other isotopes. The use of the nuclides produced is varied. The largest variety is used in research (e.g. in chemistry where atoms of "marker" nuclide are used to figure out reaction mechanisms). By tonnage, separating natural uranium into enriched uranium and depleted uranium is the largest application. In the following text, mainly the uranium enrichment is considered. This process is crucial in the manufacture of uranium fuel for nuclear power plants, and is also required for the creation of uranium-based nuclear weapons.

Great Barrier Island lies in the outer Hauraki Gulf , New Zealand , north-east of central Auckland . With an estimated area of over , it is the world's largest active volcano, rising to  high, and it is the second largest on New Zealand. The island's summit, Mount Ruapehu, stands about  high, with a base of , and a diameter of up to . The volcano's crater lies about  beneath the water's surface and contains an underground lake. Although the island has an alpine climate, it receives little precipitation. The average annual temperature is -0.6 °C .

In chemistry, a nucleophile is a chemical species that forms bonds with electrophiles by donating an electron pair. All molecules and ions with a free pair of electrons or at least one pi bond can act as nucleophiles. Because nucleophiles donate electrons, they are Lewis bases. Nucleophilic describes the affinity of a nucleophile to bond with positively charged atomic nuclei. Nucleophilicity, sometimes referred to as nucleophile strength, refers to a substance's nucleophilic character and is often used to compare the affinity of atoms. Neutral nucleophilic reactions with solvents such as alcohols and water are named solvolysis.

Adenine ( symbol A or Ade ) is a nucleobase ( a purine derivative ) . It is one of the most abundant purines found in living systems. Adenine is found in all living organisms, except for yeast. Adenine plays a variety of roles in metabolism, synthesis of nucleic acids (deoxynucleosides and deoxynucleotides), and transport of metabolites. Adenine can also be converted to a variety of other compounds, including ATP and AMP, but these are rare. Adenosine is an analog of adenosine, and is a purine nucleobase.

The following outline is provided as an overview of and topical guide to the history of South Asia : History of South Asia: India and Sri Lanka. For a detailed account of South Asia's history by its people, geography, and languages, please see History of South Asia by its people, geography and languages. Also, see South Asia : A Geographical, Historical, and Social History

South Asia: India and Sri Lanka has a long history. Many South Asian states, both Hindu and Buddhist were established in the Indus Valley between 2000 and 1800 CE.

Classless Inter-Domain Routing ( CIDR ) is a method for allocating IP addresses and for IP routing . The Internet Engineering Task Force ( IETF ) has developed the CIDR standard as a means to define these features. CIDR addresses begin with a prefix, or “tag”. A prefix can contain an integer value, representing a 32 bit address, which has to be added to a domain name by the DNS system, to create the prefix-prefix value of a CIDR . CIDR address prefixes ( and sub prefixes) are added in an arbitrary order.

Glam rock is a style of rock music that developed in the United Kingdom in the early 1970s and was later developed internationally, particularly in the USA. It is a style of music that developed around the 1970s and 1980s, inspired by the glam metal and hard rock genres. Glam metal is a sub-genre of heavy rock music that has gained a following in the United Kingdom, the United States, and the United States during the 1970s. Its roots can be traced back to the glam metal, which was first introduced to the United Kingdom in the 1960s.

The Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) is a non-UN intergovernmental organization located in The Hague, Netherlands. Unlike a judicial court in the traditional sense, the PCA provides services of arbitral tribunal to resolve disputes that arise out of international agreements between member states, international organizations or private parties. The cases span a range of legal issues involving territorial and maritime boundaries, sovereignty, human rights, international investment, and international and regional trade. The PCA is constituted through two separate multilateral conventions with a combined membership of 122 states.

Don Carlos is a five-act grand opera composed by Giuseppe Verdi to a French-language libretto by Joseph Méry and Camille du Locle, based on the dramatic play Don Carlos, Infant von Spanien (Don Carlos, Infante of Spain) by Friedrich Schiller. In addition, several incidents, of which the Forest of Fontainebleau scene and auto-da-fé were the most substantial, were borrowed from Eugène Cormon's 1846 play Philippe II, Roi d'Espagne. The opera is most often performed in Italian translation, usually under the title Don Carlo. The opera's story is based on conflicts in the life of Carlos, Prince of Asturias (1545–1568).

The Illustrated Man is a 1951 collection of 18 science fiction short stories by American writer Ray Bradbury . A series of 12 novellas, each one dealing with a different facet of science-fiction storytelling, Bradbury created the collection as a tribute to his favorite scientist, Stephen Jay Gould . The Illustrated Man has never been out of print, as it has sold more than 300,000 copies worldwide and is the most popular Bradbury book in the US and Australia. The Illustrated Man was Bradbury's only novel published since 1950 and has been cited as one of the most influential books in the history of American science fiction.

Montague Rhodes James  (1 August 1862 – 12 June 1936) was an English author, medievalist scholar and provost of King's College, Cambridge (1905–1918), and of Eton College (1918–1936). He was Vice-Chancellor of the University of Cambridge (1913–15).James's work as a medievalist and scholar is still highly regarded, but he is best remembered for his ghost stories, which some consider among the best in the genre. He redefined the ghost story for the new century by abandoning many of the formal Gothic clichés of his predecessors and using more realistic contemporary settings.

Eugène Adrien Roland Georges Garros ( ; 6 October 1888 – 5 October 1918 ) was a French pioneering aviator and the first person to fly a powered airplane across Europe, and in the Atlantic Ocean, without refueling for the entire trip. Born to an affluent family in Bordeaux as the youngest son, Garros grew up as a keen sportsman with an interest in horses, fencing, shooting, sailing, and flying, but his love for the sea and aviation began to fade with the onset of World War I when his mother left Paris for the northern French city of Rouen to care for her sick husband.

Tilburg is a city and municipality in the Netherlands , in the southern province of North Brabant . With a population of over 200,000 residents , it is the largest municipality in the province . In terms of population it is the second most densely inhabited city and the third most densely populated city outside of the Netherlands. The city of Tilburg was founded in the 11th century by the people of Frisian origin, but it became an important seaport and a commercial center in the early 15th century . It was founded on the trade route to the Mediterranean coast of the Mediterranean .

Lingerie ( , , ) is a category of primarily women 's clothing including undergarments ( mainly brassieres ) , lingerie , and swimwear. It is a type of fashion that has evolved over several centuries, to become more professional and high fashion. Some of these women's fashion items are created in the same time period by different designers with different designs, colors, and materials. Contents

It originated in the Middle Ages as a form of court fashion for ladies in Europe and the Mediterranean. [3] The term "livery" was used by men in the 19th century to describe the garments worn by women.

The AGM-114 Hellfire (AGM stands for air-to-ground missile) is an air-to-surface missile (ASM) first developed for anti-armor use, but later models were developed for precision drone strikes against other target types, and have been used in a number of actions aimed to "destroy high-value targets." It was originally developed under the name Heliborne laser, fire-and-forget missile, which led to the colloquial name "Hellfire" ultimately becoming the missile's formal name. It has multi-mission, multi-target precision-strike ability, and can be launched from multiple air, sea, and ground platforms, including the Predator drone.

New Zealand consists of more than six hundred islands , mainly remnants of a larger land mass now beneath the surface of Earth's oceans. Almost all of the world's remaining land masses are connected to the South Pacific Ocean by narrow channels known as straits: the narrow channel that stretches between New Zealand and Australia cuts through the western half of the islands, and another cuts through the northern island of New Zealand, and the southern one of Australia, and the two separate straits between New Zealand and Australia are called the Tasman Straits, the largest of these straits.

Numismatics is the study or collection of currency,  including coins, tokens, paper money, medals and related objects.Specialists, known as numismatists, are often characterized as students or collectors of coins, but the discipline also includes the broader study of money and other means of payment used to resolve debts and exchange goods.The earliest forms of money used by peoples is referred to as "Odd and Curious", but the use of other goods in barter exchange is excluded, even where used as a circulating currency (e.g., cigarettes in prison).

An anti-tank guided missile (ATGM), anti-tank missile, anti-tank guided weapon (ATGW) or anti-armor guided weapon is  a guided missile primarily designed to hit and destroy heavily armored military vehicles. ATGMs range in size from shoulder-launched weapons, which can be transported by a single soldier, to larger tripod-mounted weapons, which require a squad or team to transport and fire, to vehicle and aircraft mounted missile systems.Earlier man-portable anti-tank weapons like anti-tank rifles and magnetic anti-tank mines, generally had very short range, sometimes on the order of metres or tens of metres.

The Viking program consisted of a pair of identical American space probes , Viking 1 and Viking 2 , which flew into the inner Solar System to conduct science experiments for the Viking 1 telescope. In July and August of the year 2000, Viking 1 was put in an eccentric orbit around the Sun at a perihelion of 12.4 million km. Viking 1 is now in an orbit slightly beyond this point, having made two passages around the Sun, including one as close as . On August 26, 2002 Vikings 2 made an Earth flyby with an orbit of 12.5 to 14.0 million km.

Nuclear engineering is the branch of engineering concerned with the application of breaking down atomic nuclei ( fission ) or fusing atoms ( fusion ) to create a new substance with the appropriate chemical or physical characteristics. It deals with research and development work in the physical, chemical, and nuclear sciences related to fusion and fission and related technologies and devices. Nuclear research is the most important and fastest growing component of all of science and technology. With the explosive growth of the American nuclear power industry and the development of nuclear research, there is a greater need to study the safety and health of nuclear power plants ( NPP ).

Dresden ( , ; Upper Saxon : Dräsdn ; ) is the capital city of the German state of Saxony-Anhalt, and the largest city in eastern Germany. Its name is a patronymic derived from the German place-name  ("son of") (see Dräsdn in other languages). History

1st century
The earliest documented mention of Dresden is by the Roman historian Pliny the Younger, who describes it in the 1st century AD:

The Roman name of Drusus is also found in the records of the Ostrogoths, but is most likely a local dialect name rather than a Roman one.

Dekker 's algorithm is the first known correct solution to the mutual exclusion problem in concurrent programming . The solution is applicable to concurrent systems that can perform many concurrent I/O actions simultaneously. Dekker was born in 1981 and is a senior software engineer with the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Gaithersburg, MD. His work has been featured in The Economist and other publications. He holds a master's degree from Carnegie Mellon University, and a doctoral degree from the University of Toronto. His current work involves software verification and implementation, particularly for concurrent I/O systems that run asynchronously and asynchronously parallel.

Monte Cassino ( today usually spelled Montecassino ) is a rocky hill about southeast of Rome , in the Latin city of Rome , which is considered the most important hill of the Italian Peninsula. It has a commanding view of the Tiber Valley and the Pincio River. Monte Cassino can be accessed by road, but it is rarely climbed. The name of Cassino is derived from the Celtic name for the hill, Castel, meaning 'Castle Hill.' Location

The site of Monte Cassino was located on the summit of Cassino d'Alba on a high rocky ridge in the northern part of Rome.

Kenneth Charles Williams (22 February 1926 – 15 April 1988) was an English actor. He was best known for his comedy roles and in later life as a raconteur and diarist. He was one of the main ensemble in 26 of the 31 Carry On films, and appeared in many British television programmes and radio comedies, including series with Tony Hancock and Kenneth Horne, as well as being a regular panellist on BBC Radio 4's comedy panel show Just a Minute from its second series in 1968 until his death 20 years later.Williams grew up in Central London in a working-class family; he claimed his father spoke as a cockney.

The lion (Panthera leo) is a large cat of the genus Panthera native to Africa and India. It has a muscular, deep-chested body, short, rounded head, round ears, and a hairy tuft at the end of its tail. It is sexually dimorphic; adult male lions are larger than females and have a prominent mane. It is a social species, forming groups called prides. A lion's pride consists of a few adult males, related females, and cubs. Groups of female lions usually hunt together, preying mostly on large ungulates.

Year 976 (CMLXXVI) was a leap year starting on Saturday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.Events  By place  Byzantine Empire  January 10 – Emperor John I Tzimiskes dies at Constantinople, after returning from a second campaign against the Abbasids in Syria. He is buried in the Church of Christ Chalkites, and succeeded by his 18-year-old nephew Basil II, who becomes sole ruler of the Byzantine Empire. The administration remains in the hands of Basil Lekapenos (an illegitimate son of the late Emperor Romanos I). Europe  June – Emir Abu'l-Qasim launches a raiding expedition into Byzantine Italy from Sicily.

The word comes from the Japanese word for logographic characters of the Chinese script , which were made a major component of the Chinese pinyin written system until the nineteenth century. Pinyin began in the ninth century with the introduction of the character for 新 (now pronounced ‘zhēng’ or ‘ch’ in Chinese) to replace one of the five main characters in the Pinyin alphabet: 吉, 啓, 劫, 口, 辭. The first three were originally used for writing Chinese characters, but soon they became obsolete as writing systems evolved.

Harriet Tubman ( born Araminta Ross , March 10 , 1913 ) was an American abolitionist and political activist . She founded the Union League of Philadelphia , which served as a center of abolitionism. Tubman is also known for her role in the founding of The Underground Railroad . Early Life

Abolitionist, Civil War era

Abolitionist and Civil War patriot

Araminta Ross was born in Baltimore on March 10, 1913 and grew up in a middle class environment. In 1932, Ross married Charles Tubman. She joined the Civil Liberties Union of the United States and helped organize the Civil Liberties Union League .

Show jumping, is a part of a group of English riding equestrian events that also includes dressage, eventing, hunters, and equitation. Jumping classes are commonly seen at horse shows throughout the world, including the Olympics. Sometimes shows are limited exclusively to jumpers, sometimes jumper classes are offered in conjunction with other English-style events, and sometimes show jumping is but one division of very large, all-breed competitions that include a very wide variety of disciplines. Jumping classes may be governed by various national horse show sanctioning organizations, such as the United States Equestrian Federation in the USA or the British Showjumping Association in Great Britain.

In music performance and notation , legato ( ; Italian for `` tied together '' ; French lié ; German Leid ), is a musical device that was developed by the composer Franz Liszt in the mid nineteenth century for use in writing out music scores. Originally designed to assist a player in reading music notation, the device became widely used throughout the musical world and in music education. Contents

The device is designed to be used in several ways, primarily by musicians to assist them in the practice of playing and reading music.

Year 1103 ( MCIII ) was a common year starting on Thursday ( link will display the full calendar ) of the Julian calendar. The actual start time varied from year to year, with the last official start time not being identified until 1582  (link) . The Gregorian calendar started on Tuesday ( link ) , while the Julian calendar began on Thursday (link). In years starting on a Saturday or Sunday, the day is still observed as a Saturday or Sunday, regardless of whether it is a Saturday or a Sunday by leap year rules.

The Maunder Minimum , also known as the `` prolonged sunspot minimum '' , was a period around 1645 to 1730 in Europe , which saw a massive period of solar maximum. In the 1640s solar activity fell to its lowest state in over two millennia. For the next 20 to 40 years solar activity was relatively calm, but after around 1650 it suddenly began to become stronger. It was during the Maunder Minimum in the late 18th to early 19th century that we started to see a dramatic increase in solar activity, which lasted for approximately 30 years until around 1820, then fell below the average for at least a century.

Gender is the range of characteristics pertaining to femininity and masculinity and differentiating between them. Depending on the context, this may include sex-based social structures (i.e. gender roles) and gender identity. Most cultures use a gender binary, having two genders (boys/men and girls/women); those who exist outside these groups may fall under the umbrella term non-binary. Some societies have specific genders besides "man" and "woman", such as the hijras of South Asia; these are often referred to as third genders (and fourth genders, etc.).

Juan Moreno y Herrera–Jiménez ( born 30 July 1948 ) , known as Jean Reno , is a French actor, best known as the protagonist of Jean Reno : La Noche de los Tres (1967), as well as for a series of television commercials and for playing the protagonist in many movies, such as  El Señor de los Caminos (1952), El Roto (1958), La Hacienda del Mariflores (1959) and La Única Familia (1961). In the 1960s he played several roles in television dramas such as , La Guerre de la Cabeza and  El Efecto del Sol.

The putamen ( ; from Latin , meaning `` nutshell '' ) is a round structure located at the base of the brain and situated in the midbrain, roughly halfway between the forebrain and the midbrain \[1\] (Fig. [2a](#fig02){ref-type="fig"}). The putamen receives inputs from the basal forebrain, which has a rich network of neural tracts and a large variety of cell types, as well as receives excitatory input from the medial septum and nucleus accumbens (NAcc) and inputs from the amygdala, hippocampus and orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) \[2\].
